He lived at Winthrop in the State of Maine.— This afternoon I attended with my family at St. John’s church where Mr Pyne read the evening service for the third Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Matthew 7.20— [“]By their fruits ye shall know them.” He began by observing that the judgment of the world was apt to require too much of Christianity by making it responsible for the faults and errors of its votaries— After some preliminary remarks he divided the discussion of his subject into three parts 1. What the world may justly expect from professing Christians 2. What it does require of them and 3. The practice incumbent on them in the fulfilment of their duties. He confined himself now to the first and second points, leaving the third for hereafter I walked this evening to Mr Gurley’s but Mr Davis was out.

24. IV:30 Monday.  I received last Friday a Letter from George R. Davis of Troy, New-York, asking my opinion if there was any thing in the course of David L. Seymour on the question of reconsideration upon the reconsideration of the Eastern harbour Bill, after the veto—that evinced any want of good faith or calculated to defeat a constitution at two thirds vote to pass the bill— Mr Seymour has been charged with this in a Troy newspaper, and Mr Davis, his neighbour and friends wants testimony to refute the Slander. Mr Davis was lodging at Mr Gurley’s on Pennsylvania avenue, and wrote me that he proposed to leave the City for home this day. I called last Evening at Mr Gurley’s to see him but he was out. He came here this morning, and I told him that before answering his Letter, I wished to see the Article in the Troy Newspaper containing the charge against Mr Seymour, but he had it not, and could state only the general purport of it. I told him that I could readily and cheerfully certify that I never for an instant entertained a suspicion of insincerity on the part of Mr Seymour, when the Speaker by what I thought a shameful collusion, cut off all reconsideration of the Eastern harbour bill, by deciding that the main question upon the previous question moved by Mr Seymour, applied to the passages of the bill, when not five minutes before Seymour had moved the previous question only upon an assurance from Linn Boyd, then in the Speaker’s chair that the main question would be on Seymour’s motion to postpone the reconsideration of the Bill from Tuesday to Thursday— This was a knave’s trick. I remonstrated against it in vain. If Mr Seymour had resented it vehemently I believe he would have shamed the Speaker out of it and the bill might have passed by a two thirds vote— Mr David L. Seymour was embarrassed by his reluctance to break with his Southern democratic allies; and submitted to the iniquitous decision of the Speaker which smothered all reconsideration of the bill. Mr Davis in substance admitted all this, and will be satisfied with my testimony to my belief in the sincerity of Mr Seymour— I was hard worked all this day in retrieving my arrears of diary run up in the last days of the Session— Towards Evening I walked to Mr Frye’s expecting to find my family there, but was disappointed— I found there however Mr and Mrs Moody with their infant daughter recently recovered from the scarlet fever— Walter Hellen was also there. I asked Mr Frye for a statement of his accounts as my agent here, and came home with Mr and Mrs Moody in their carriage—

25. V. Tuesday.  I called this morning at the Department of State and had a long conversation with the Secretary John C. Calhoun. I repeated the enquiry concerning the Documents required by the Government of Massachusetts from that of the Province of New Brunswick. He said the pressure of other business in the Department had delayed the renewed demand upon the British Minister for these papers, which he said he proposed to make next week— I then enquired about a memorial of James Crosby, and 90 others addressed to him and a printed copy of which has been sent to me.— It complains of enactments of duties by the Legislature of the Province in contravention to an article of the Ashburton Treaty— He said there was no doubt that it was a plain violation of the Treaty— And on this also he should address Mr Pakenham— My last enquiry was whether the call of the House of Representatives adopted at my motion on Friday the 14th. of this months, for the Instructions to George W. Erving in 1814 and afterwards during his mission to Spain had been answered— Mr Markoe told me that the Resolution of the house had not been received—another of the Clerks said it was not received until two hours after the final adjournment of the house, so that it cannot be answered till the next Session of Congress.— But Mr Calhoun immediately offered to send to my house for my inspection the two folio of manuscript Volumes of Instructions to the Ministers of the United States in Europe—which I accepted— And in the Letter of Instruction from James Monroe Secretary of State of 30. May 1816. I find the following passage “On the cession, by the Spanish government of all claims to territory Eastward of the Mississippi, he (President Madison) is willing should it be indispensably necessary to establish the Sabine from its mouth to its source as the boundary in that extent, between the United States and the Spanish Provinces; leaving the residue of their boundaries to be settled by Commissioners to be hereafter appointed by both governments.” other parts of that instruction are not less important, and have never before been published— Dr Müller the pastor of the English Lutheran Church came this afternoon with the subscription book for the church— Y. B. Page, brought me from the Secretary of the Senate and Clerk of the house one copy of the American Archives fourth Series fourth vol— Mr Lawrenz whose cotton manufactory I visited at Pittsburgh was here with his wife, accompanied by Mr and Mrs Hubbard of Massillon, Ohio. My wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter with Mary Cutts, took tea and spent the Evening at Mrs Frye’s— I walked there and came home with them.

26. IV.30. Wednesday.  On Sunday the 6th of September 1840 I passed the day at Cornwallis in Nova Scotia. In the morning I sallied forth in search of a church, and as I walked, a man in a chaise with one horse passing by me stop’d and offered me a seat with him which I accepted and went with him to church— His name was Harris— He was a respectable magistrate of the place, and he called on me this morning, being on a summer excursion into the States. He told me candidly that he did not think what he had seen of this Country, equal to Nova Scotia— The town of Cornwallis, is one of the most fertile spots in the province; a great portion of it having been reclaimed from the Sea— I continued my preparations for departure, and returned to the Congress Libraries, books which I had taken out to use. Among those that I may want again are Howell’s State trials vol. 20. for the case of the Negro Somerset— It is also in Capel Loft’s reports but not so fully reported— Barnewall and Cresswell’s Reports, 2, p 448 The case of Forbes and Cochrane— And Haggard’s admiralty Reports 2. 94— Case of the slave Grace—in which Lord Stowell did his worst to reverse the decision of Mansfield in the case of Somerset, as Mansfield reversed the decision of Lord Hardwick twenty years before him.— I returned also the Volume of Thompson’s Alcedo, and took out Black’s translation of Humboldt’s Political Essay on the Kingdom of New Spain. 4 Vols 1822. “Dernieres Decouvertes dans L’Amerique Septentrionale, de M. de la Sale, Mises au jour par M. le Chevalier Tonti, Gouverneur du Fort Saint Louis, aux Islinois. Paris 1697.— Journal Historique du dernier Voyage que feu M. de la Sale fit dans le Golfe de Mexique, pour trouver l’embouchure, et le cours de la Riviere de Missicipi, nommee a présent la Riviere de Saint Louis, qui traverse, la Louisiane— Ou l’on voit l’Histoire tragique de sa mort, et plusieurs choses curieuses du nouveau monde—par Monsieur Joutel, l’un des compagnons de ce Voyage, redigé et mis en ordre par Monsieur de Michel.[”]— Paris 1713.— And a Translation of this work, london 1714. I returned to Asbury Dickins the Journal of the Senate for the 3d. Session of the 27th. Congress which they had lent me, at the commencement of the recent Session, and Dickens gave me three copies of the proceedings of the Senate on the Treaty for the annexation of Texas.— The pamphlet Speech of W. C. Rives on the Tariff, and Major Graham’s map, of our Northeastern boundary as settled by the Ashburton Treaty— I ascertained that George W. Erving was not nominated as chargé d’Affaires to Constantinople. David Porter was nominated Consul General at Algiers 1829. Chargé d’Affaires to Constantinople 1831—Minister Resident in 1839. an increase of rank and pay for the sole purpose of petting him; and now they have given his widow an outfit as a posthumous gratuity— I paid a visit this Evening to Mr Pakenham whom I found with his family at dinner.

27. IV:30. Thursday.  Fahrenheit 90— Potowmac Bath.  This day set in the extreme heat of the summer—the trial of the climate to my Constitution. A burning Sun— The thermometers in my chamber at 90 and a light breeze from the Southwest, a fan delicious to the face, but parching instead of cooling the skin— I have been a full month for a river bath without daring to take it— This morning at 5. I went in the Barouche to my old favourite spot—found the tide unusually high— All my station rocks occupied by young men, except one, and that surrounded by the tide, already upon the ebb.— I had some difficulty to undress and dress, but got my bath—swam about 5 minutes, and came out, washed and refreshed— It was my exercise for the day— After returning home I did not again pass the sill of the street door— I continued the process of packing up books and papers to send to Quincy— I found the blue chests N. 11. and 14 with their keys, and another, blue chest without key or number.— The chest furnished me by the Postmaster of the house holds not half the books and documents accumulated in the second and third Session of the 27th. Congress— On opening the blue chest N. 11. and the one unnumbered which had not been opened for several years, I found a mass of old Letters and secret documents of which I must if life and health be indulged me till the next Session of Congress make a thorough and systematic revisal— On a cursory glance at Humboldts New Spain I find at Vol. 2. p. 229. Chapter 8. Section 10. Intendancy of San Luis Potosi, notice of the claim of the United States to Texas under the Louisiana Treaty; and the very distinct opinion of the author against it.— I find also two important facts to be hereafter noted— First, in Joutel’s Narrative of La Sale’s last voyage—of his death by a musket ball fired by a man of his own company named Duhaut, on the 19th. of March 1687. page 201— Secondly in Tonti’s book published in 1697.—p. 329 speaking of his own wanderings in the Country of the Nanadiches,—he says, “Nous quittames leur pays le 29 du Mois de Mai (1690) et nous avançames jusqu à une journée des Palaquessons. Ce sut là que nous apprimès que la derniere Colonie etablie par M. de la Sale sur les bords de la Mer Mexique, n’aiant pu se maintenir dans une parfaite Union, s’etoit toute dispersée; que les uns s’etoient confondus avec les Sauvages, et que les autres avoient pris le parti de remonter vers les habitations Francoises.”— [“]C’est pour quoi n’aiant pas cru devoir les aller chercher ou ils n’etoient plus, je me resolus de revenir sur mes pas”— In the same book p. 192 is the account of La Sale’s first discovery on the 7th. of April 1683 of the Mouth of the Mississippi river, descending from Canada, the Lakes and the Illinois— Mr and Mrs Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us, and Doctor Frye was here this evening.— I answered a very strange Letter lately received from Thomas F. Marshall, who seems disposed to make a witness of me against Henry Clay.—

28. IV:15. Friday  Fahrenheit continuously at 90.  The extreme heat of the weather reduces my condition to a state little above mere vegetation— I have had for a succession of years repeated invitations to deliver a Lecture before the Lyceum at Frankford 6. miles North of Philadelphia; and have repeatedly promised at some time to comply with this request— I had concluded to go to Philadelphia next Wednesday—to devote the Evening to the Frankford Lyceum—return then to Philadelphia, and pass the 4th. in quiet there— But as the time appraches difficulties are started— I am so much debilitated and prostrated in physical strength by the heat, that I feel an invincible repugnance to undertake a speech in public before strangers— So I postpone our departure for home till Monday the 8th. of next Month, and halt only for the Night at Philadelphia— This morning I had a visit from my old friends, Richards and Ha-lilio. Ambassadors from the Sandwich Islands; now on their return from their Mission to England and France. They succeeded in obtaining from the Governments of both those Nations professed acknowledgments of them as a Sovereign Independent Nation—but in the mean time—Lord George Paulett, commander of the British took possession of the Islands in the name of Queen Victoria— This measure effected on the 25th. of February 1843. was disavowed by the Queen, and on the 31st. of July 1843. King Kamehameha the third, was restored to the sovereignty of the Islands by treaty with commodore Richard Thomas Commander of the British line of Battleship Dublin. But I learn by a private Letter from our Commissioner to the Islands dated at Honolulu, 19 and 23. Feby 1844. that on the 5th. of that Month the English Corvette Hazard arrived there from St. Blas and Mazatlan having on board the English Consul-General Mr Miller, who shortly after concluded with the king a Treaty, by one Article of which English subjects are to enjoy in the Islands all the privileges of natives—by another not more than 5 per cent duties are to be levied upon Articles imported from England, without reciprocity; and by a third, the British Consul is authorised to appoint the jury for the trial of any British subject, charged with any crime— Mr Richards was conscious that these Articles were scarcely compatible with the pretensions of a Government to absolute Sovereignty and Independence; and admitted our right to claim for citizens of the United States the benefit of all these Articles, as much as if they had been concluded with us— These Commissioners had not yet seen the Secretary of State, or the President, who returned this day from New York with a wife of 22. Julia Gardiner, daughter of David Gardiner of Long Island, who was killed by the bursting of the gun in the Princeton last February. They were married by bishop Onderdonk, in the Church of the Ascension, the day before yesterday, at New-York.

29. IV. Saturday.  The summer heat and its enervating spell continues— I walked this morning to my old bathing station upon the strand of the Potomac river and bathed and swam for about 10 minutes, and then walked home— From the practice of personal ablution and the exercise of swimming I cannot totally abstain, for I believe they have promoted my health and prolonged my life many years. And yet the experience of late years has compelled me gradually to disuse them— But my great anxiety now, is having much to do, and to be doing nothing.— I called at the Globe Office, and saw Mr Kane the book-binder of that establishment— He has my file of Documents for the 3d. Session of the 27th. Congress; they are not complete, and I requested him before binding them to send to Mr French the sub-Clerk of the house, to have the missing papers supplied. I returned to the Globe office a remnant of the numbers of the Congressional Globe of 1842—found among my loose papers since I returned the rest— I called at the Patriotic Bank, and left my book there to be balanced. Then at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and saw Mr Gales— I took a paper of the 27th. containing my Card to take leave of all invitations to public meetings.— It contains also a remarkable speech of W. S. Archer in the Senate against the advice and consent to ratify the Treaty for the annexation of Texas to the United States. At the Office of the Clerk of the House, French was not there— I requested of the Clerk who was there a copy of the memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr, and 179 citizens of Pennsylvania, praying for an alteration of the naturalization Laws, so as to require 21 years of residence by foreigners before admitting them to all the privileges of native Americans— This was the first memorial presented to the house on the subject— I moved its reference to the judiciary Committee but it was laid on the table by yeas and nays. 15 days after it was at my motion taken up from the table and referred to the Committee on the judiciary— The clerk promised me a copy for Monday next with the names of the signers. I shall see whether the Editors of the National Intelligencer will publish it— I declared in the house that I should not hold myself bound to support the demand in the house; but at the next Session on the native American party will be heard in both houses, and the proceedings of house on this first memorial, will have a material influence upon the debate. Mr Frye came this afternoon and gave me the accounts of his agency for my private affairs in this City— They have remained unsettled several years till I am afraid to look at them— I have shrunk from the task too long. I walked this afternoon to the President’s grounds, and heard there the music of the Marine band— Met there Mr and Mrs Morris son and daughter of John C. Spencer, beau Laurence, B. O. Tayloe, Mr Pyne and General Daniel Parker who pointed to old Cooper at Galabrun’s door.

30. V. Sunday.  Cooler— Fahrenheit down to 84. At the second Presbyterian Church, Mr Knox preached from Matthew 23.33. “How can ye escape the damnation of hell?”— He read the whole chapter of tremendous denunciation of Woe, eight times repeated against the Scribes and Pharisees, for their hypocrisy.— This discourse was held almost immediately before the arrest, trial, sentence and execution of the Messiah— It is in this chapter also that occurs the pathetic, and affecting prediction of the destruction of Jerusalem— There is no mention of pharisees in any book of the old Testament— Nor in the apocryphal books— But they are found in the New Testament as a profession, of half Priests, half Lawyers, invested with authority, for Jesus says they sit in Moses seat and with his bitterest reproaches upon them, he enjoins upon his disciples implicit obedience to their authority— The believed the resurrection, the existence of Angels and Demons, and the retributions of a future state— They veiled their vices therefore with hypocrisy, and made great show of rigid and austere virtue— He charges them with prevarication, cruelty, extortion and excess, all under the disguise of hypocrisy— And this was the class of man, of whom he demanded how can ye escape the damnation of hell? Is it a suitable enquiry to make of Christians in communion with the church? It is inconceivable to me, how men of decent character can suffer themselves to be treated from week to week like the vilest malefactors— It seems to me as if the preacher considered himself as a chaplain to a penitentiary, discoursing to the convicts.— After dinner at St. John’s church Mr Pyne read the evening service for the 4th. Sunday after Trinity and preached the remainder of his Sermon, begun last Sunday from Matthew 7.20. “By their fruits ye shall know them.”— The divisional part which he had left for consideration this day, was the third and last— The extent to which the world does hold the deportment of the Christian man, by which he appeared to understand the Christian minister responsible to them— He said they were often censured for not wearing an unalterably cheerful appearance and he assigned various reasons why the Christian man should were an appearance of gravity— Sometimes he said they were censured for the opposite property of hilarity unbecoming the Christian profession, which he considered equally unreasonable. The discourse was upon the whole a dissertation upon the injustice of the judgments of the world, and upon the duty of maintaining a spirit of independence against them; indicating a consciousness of the necessity of self-vindication. I answered this evening a Letter received last January, from a young man named Thomas W. T. Curtis, enclosing, a mutilated copy of my Vision—in the hand-writing of Mary Frazier.

1. V. Monday  Mr Pakenham the British Minister called on me this morning and I had a long and very free conversation with him, not upon his negotiations here, of which no mention was made either by him or me— He seemed anxious to know whether a special Session of Congress would be called as has been much rumoured but recently as if by authority denied— Immediately after the rejection by the Senate of the annexation Treaty Henderson who had come post-haste as Minister Plenipotentiary to sign it started post haste back it was said to prevent the abandonment of the project by the Texians, and to negotiate a popular movement there, still to cram down the annexation— I told Mr Pakenham, that I had seen with great pleasure in the Parliamentary papers of 1839 and 40. lent me by Mr Fox, the avowal by Lord Palmerston in a despatch to Lord Howard de Walden that to promote the abolition of Slavery throughout the world was a fixed and settled system of the British Government.— I had seen in the same papers the negotiations with all Europe and all America, especially with the Pope and the Bey of Tunis all tending to the same result— I told him of the visit of Andrews the Texian and of Lewis Tappan to me before they went to England last Summer— That Mr Andrews had communicated his designs to me, and I had expressed to him my doubts of his success. I had expressed the same doubt to Mr Tappan, and told him I thought the British Government would in this case sacrifice their principles to their policy— Mr Lewis Tappan without authority from me had apprized Lord Aberdeen of this opinion of mine, and Lord Aberdeen had protested against it but it had proved correct— The abolition of Slavery in Texas without war or bloodshed had been completely within the power of Great Britain, but her Government had failed to carry out their own principles.— They disclaim and concede too much. They parry carte and tierce to avoid the issue tendered them, and which they must meet— This was not the general character of English diplomacy. It was usually bold, open, explicit, stubborn— I could not perceive it in Lord Aberdeens disavowals nor in Mr Charles Elliots recent Letter to President Houston— Mr Pakenham took no offence at what I said, and spoke with much caution and reserve in return— He seems afraid of the English principles themselves, and fearful that the use of them would be to put edge tools in the hands of children— I called at Dyer’s auction room— At the Patriotic Bank, and at the Office of the Clerk of the House where I was furnished with a copy of the native American Memorial of A. De Kalb Tarr and 179 others with the names— I met Persico there, and he asked me to take him home to Fullers hotel—which I did— He afterwards brought me a bust of John Nelson, the present Attorney General, to look at his Visits from Mrs Carroll and Mrs Madison Cutts.

2. IV:30. Tuesday.  The heat by the thermometer has abated but the sultriness of the atmosphere keeps me still in a state which seems to myself like suspended animation. I sent this morning two blue chests N. 11. and 14. with the chest containing the documents of the 2d. and 3d. Sessions of the 27th. Congress, to Georgetown where they were ship’d in the Brig William L. Jones Samuel R. Davis, Master, for Boston— I made out with the help of my granddaughter Mary Louisa my account as Executor of the Will of Thomas B. Johnson, and took it to the judge of the orphan’s court. Nathl. P. Causin— He examined the vouchers and admitted them all, after at first objecting that a promissory Note for 150 dollars should have been sworn to by M. A. Giusta. He concluded to pass it without requiring the oath. I left my account and vouchers, upon which the Register Edward N. Noah is to make the Statement of the account in the form practised at the Office, and in which it is passed by the judge— I have kept the accounts at the Patriotic Bank, where I found this morning a balance in my favour on my Executor’s account of 626.63. which I drew in bills of the Bank— On re-examination of the account that I had delivered, an omission of four items with which I should have charged myself—two of them were on my bank book, but had escaped my attention— The other two were notes protested at the bank, and taken out and delivered to Mr Dyer for collection. I called yesterday and this day at Dyer’s auction room, but he was not there.— I visited also Mr Peter Force to enquire about the delivery of the 3d. Volume of the American Archives, but only ascertained where I must enquire further— Force had a bound copy of the 5th. volume of the American Archives; but they are not yet generally bound for delivery. And there is yet a 6th. Volume to complete the fourth series, extending only from the 19th. of April to 1774 to the 4th. of July 1776— He proposes then to take up the 3d and the 5th. series conjointly— I despatched my answer to Thomas W. T. Curtis of Rye New Hampshire and returned to him the mutilated copy, in Clara’s hand-writing of my vision— Did she give it away before her death? or leave it to her sister or her husband? why should I enquire? Miss Cutts was here this evening— There was a light thunder shower yesterday and a heavy shower without thunder this afternoon.— I took a short walk at evening twilight, but the weather is so languishing that I barely made out to finish a short note, for publication with my closing list of petitions for this Session— The note is on the memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr, and 179 native Americans, which on the 31st. of May the house laid on the table and on the 15th. of June took up and referred to the judiciary Committee.

3. IV:45. Wednesday  Mr Lewis Johnson came to enquire if I had again spoken to the first comptroller of the Treasury concerning the remnant of claim of the heirs of William Otis— I told him I had been at the Comptroller’s Office to see him but he was not there— I proposed to go there again on Friday— He proposed that Mr Fendall should go with me, to which I assented, and he will request Mr Fendall to call on me at 10. Friday morning.— I settled accounts at Kinchy’s and Clagett’s. Saw R. W. Dyer who told me he had received the money on Milburn’s and Turner’s notes and would send it to me in the course of the day— I received at the Bank of Washington 90 dollars for the quarter’s interest on the Washington Corporation 6. per Cents.— Then at the Orphan’s Court, I added to my statement of account with the Estate of Thomas B. Johnson the 4 items which had been omitted, and took it to have it adjusted in conformity with the account as stated by the Register to which he then swore me.— At the Patriotic Book, I exchanged three of their 100 dollar Bills for an order upon the Bank of America in New-York. Then at the Office of the National Intelligencer I left with Mr Gales, my closing list of Petitions, presented by me to the House at the recent Session of Congress, with a Note upon the Memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr and 179 citizens of Pennsylvania, praying for an alteration of the naturalization Laws, so as to require 21 years residence for admission to the rights of suffrage; and a copy of the Memorial itself with the names of the signers and the endorsements of the Clerk shewing the first and second disposal of it by the house. Gales promised that the whole should be published in the Intelligencer on Saturday Morning, and I desired him to send me half a dozen copies of that day’s paper.— Gales said there was a new phase of the Texas question— Some new suspicion of British interference to abolish Slavery in Texas, prompted by Robert Walsh, now turned into a hack slave-driver, in one of his Letters published in the Intelligencer. There had been two Cabinet Meetings and it was the meerest chance that there had not been a call for an extra Session of Congress.— He said that Waddy Thompson was now here again.— He attended a whig meeting at Albany, a few days after the close of the Session of Congress; and there declared himself opposed to the annexation of Texas now and at any time— He is now at Fuller’s Hotel, and was hesitating whether to come out immediately with a publication in the Intelligencer, or to wait till his return to South Carolina— Gales told him there was no moment like the present moment and furnished him with several documents that he wanted; and he is now writing for publication— I walked after dinner half way to the race ground and back— My wife is confined to the chambers and my own condition is not much better— I began this evening an answer to J. Wingate about the statistical memorial, but shall not have time to finish it before I return to Quincy, and who knows what will occupy me there?— The blunders of the census and their consequences call for the bow and the shaft of Ulysses, and I have nothing but the telum im belle, sine ictu of Priam.

4. IV:30 Thursday.  Independence day 68.  I had received from the Committee of arrangements of the Philodemic Society of Georgetown College an invitation to attend at 1. O’Clock P.M. this day at the delivery of an Oration by one of its members, and at an entertainment given by the faculty of the College, and the Society— One of my reasons for remaining in this city after the close of the Session of Congress till this day shall be past, was to escape from all the celebrations to which I was or might be invited; the noise and bustle and excitement and ranting of this day having become irksome to me. I intended nevertheless to attend this oration and entertainment at the Georgetown College, but my driver took an holiday for himself and disappointed me— I was however well pleased with my disappointment, passed the day very quietly at home till close upon Sunset when I strolled out for an hour, and on returning stop’d at Mrs Madison’s and took leave of her for the summer— Morning and evening visitors, as by the margin; chiefly military Officers, who had been in grand costume to pay their devoirs to the President— The wedding visit last Saturday and that of Independence day came so close together that the attendance this day was thin— Captain Tyler and his bride are the laughing stock of the city. It seems as if he was racing for a prize banner to the nuptials of the mock heroic— The Sublime and the Ridiculous.— He has assumed the war power as a prerogative; the veto power as a caprice; the appointing and dismissing power as a fund for bribery, and now under circumstances of revolting indecency, is performing with a young girl from New-York the old fable of January and May.— I wrote this day a Letter toBarnes and A. de Kalb Tarr in answer to that which they addressed to me with the memorial calling for alteration of the naturalization laws— It took all the leisure of the day and when written was too long. The native Americans are falling into the blunders of the abolition Societies. They have an excellent cause which they will ruin by mismanagement— The Native Americans, like the anti-masons will have a momentary and limited success; but the staff will break in their hands and lay them in the dust. My wife has been several days unwell, and is confined to the chambers— Rather unwell myself.

5. IV:15. Friday  Mr Fendall called on me at 10 this morning, and I went with him to the Treasury Department where Mr George M. Bibb of Kentucky was the day before yesterday was installed as Secretary. Our business was with the first Comptroller James W. M’Culloh; and to urge the allowance of the remnant of claim for interest on the accounts of William Otis— His objection was that Francis S. Key, the Counsel for the claim, now deceased had chosen to have it settled without advancing this demand, and that it was now too late to go behind that settlement— He offered however to refer it again to the present Attorney General John Nelson; but intimated that his opinions with regard to the allowance of claims were far less indulgent than those of his predecessor the late Hugh S. Legaré— I went to the Capitol to return to the Congress Library all the books that I had borrowed there, but found it closed; the days of keeping it open during the recess of Congress being Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday instead of Tuesday and Friday as I had supposed— I left the books with Mr French of the House Clerk’s Office who promised to have them returned to the Library to-morrow— I took a few further Articles of Stationery, and the third Volume of the American Archives to complete my set.— French promised to send me to Quincy the remaining sheets of the Journal as they shall be delivered from the printers, and the diplomatic correspondence with Spain from 1816 to 1819 not yet printed— I called at the orphans court, and enquired of the judge respecting the distribution of the balance remaining in my hands of Mr Thomas B. Johnson’s property undevised; being according to the statement of the Register and to which I was sworn by him 492 dollarscents— The judge said it must be distributed between the five surviving sisters in equal portions, with a sixth equal share to be divided between the two surviving children of the eldest sister the first Mrs Hellen.— There being only a grand child of Mrs Pope living, by the statute of distributions no part of the property comes to her— Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary-Louisa dined and spent the day at Mr Frye’s— My wife is much indisposed and confined to the chambers— I dined alone— Revised my Letter to W. D. Barnes and A. De Kalb Tarr, and struck out of it a whole page of red pepper very palatable yesterday, but flat, stale and unprofitable to day. Examined Mr Frye’s account, and drew up a petition to the judge of the orphan’s Court, stating the balance of Mr T. B. Johnson’s undivided property in my hands, naming the heirs entitled to it, and requesting an order for the distribution of it among them.

6. IV:15. Saturday  Mr Lewis Johnson came to take leave before my departure. Mr Fendall had told him the result of our conference with the first comptroller. I determined to postpone leaving this city from Monday till Wednesday next; partly on account of my wife’s illness for which Dr. Thomas is in attendance, and partly to finish as far as possible the settlement of Mr T. B. Johnson’s estate as his executor— I went first to the orphan’s court with my petition for an order of distribution of 480 dollars of the balance in my hands among the heirs of Mr Johnson being 80 dollars for each of the five surviving sisters, and 40 dollars for each of the two children of the first Mrs Hellen, the eldest sister.— The Register told me I could obtain the order from the judge at his house 11th. between G and H. Streets. I went there, and the judge entered upon my petition, an order to the Register to make out an order of distribution accordingly.— I then took my petition with this direction of the judge upon it, back to the Register, who thereupon made out the order of distribution which he sent me in the course of the day.— At the Bank of Washington I received Bills for 53 dollars 55 cents upon the check of R. W. Dyer which he sent me yesterday— At the Office of the National Intelligencer, I took 6 copies of the paper of this day, containing my closing list of Petitions, presented by me at the recent Session of Congress to the house of Representatives, with the note upon the memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr and 179 citizens of Pennsylvania, praying for alteration of the naturalization Laws. I enclosed one of these papers in my Letter to W. D. Barnes, and A. de Kalb Tarr; and one to my Son, for the long Letter of Waddy Thompson junr. against the annexation of Texas, and the annexation Treaty.— I met Mr Thompson at the Intelligencer Office, and had a long conversation with him and Mr Gales, on the subject— Thompson is a South-Carolina planter, owner of 100 Slaves, and religiously believes that Slavery was made for the African race and the African race for Slavery.— He opposes the annexation of Texas on Southern grounds as a Southern man— So did Calhoun—so did M’Duffie. So did Hamilton, all now rabid annexationists— Thompson will be converted like them. He knocks down Walker, Wilkins and C. J. Ingersoll with their own Maul. But he smuggled through Congress the acknowledgment of Texas, prematurely— He is as cunning as four yankees, as sly as four quakers, and just now admires the People of Massachusetts too much.— I hope his Letter will be eminently useful at the present crisis, and devoutly pray that he, and Benton, and the Princeton gun, may be instruments for the deliverance of my Country.

7. V. Sunday.  A new protestant Episcopal church has been built in our neighbourhood, called the Church of the Epiphany, under the charge of the Revd. John W. French, who was chaplain to the house of Representatives at the special Session of Congress in 1841. and since then has preached some time in Georgetown, and later here in Washington, till he has gathered a flock and become their pastor perhaps not in the most regular order of apostolican succession— They have not even waited for the consecration or dedication of the church, which is yet unfinished, but in which he performed publish worship for the first time, this day.— He read the morning prayer with the litany and short communion for the fifth Sunday after Trinity— He preached from Psalm 122.1. “I was glad when they said unto me, let us go into the house of the Lord.”— It was an elaborate and regular dedication sermon, in which he enumerated all the reasons which a Christian has for being glad when he is summoned to go into the house of the Lord— The blessing of constant and faithful attendance upon public worship— This is a subject upon which it becomes a man to be distrustful of his own motives. The pleasure of attending upon the ordinances of religion may be an impulse of self righteousness, any thing but virtue. Attendance upon public worship for the purpose of homage to our own maker is the bare performance of duty—for the purpose of receiving instruction and reproof is just and reasonable; for the purpose of seeing and being seen of men, is vanity and hipocrisy, for mere curiosity, is idleness; and for the purpose of carping upon the performances of the preacher is an abusive exercise of faculties given for self improvement and gratitude to God— Mr French preached without notes. There is no pulpit, and he came from behind the desk with frequent exhibition of his person—his gesticulation was graceful; his elocution fluent, his delivery earnest and impressive— He gave notice that he would administer the communion the next Lord’s day, but did not add the usual exhortation of the episcopal prayer-book to partake of it. After dinner at Saint John’s church, Mr Pyne read the evening prayers for the same day and preached from Psalm 119.18. [“]Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things, out of thy law”— Mr Pyne is a very acceptable preacher— Mr Cutts and his daughter Mary spent part of the Evening with us—and Mr Charles B. King.

8. IV:30. Monday  One of the greatest dangers in this world to a man’s moral honesty is the possession of money belonging to others. The temptation to use it as his own, is perpetually recurring; and when thus used it becomes at once a debt and a privation of the means of paying it— In my ordinary concerns I have upon an average three calls for money every day— If I have money of others at hand, and none of my own, it is so convenient to borrow for the present payment that the future call to refund is overlook and debt, burdensome debt is unwarily contracted— On making up my first account of the Execution of Mr Thomas B. Johnson’s Will, I found a balance of 503 dollars 27 cents in my hands undevised— But the practice at the Orphan’s Court is that the Register makes up the account in his own way; and he accordingly made out my account, with a balance of 492:78. to which he put me upon oath— I gave him notice that the balance of my own statement was larger, and that I should credit the Estate for the difference in my second account— To disburden myself as far as possible of this balance I concluded to pay off the portions due to all the heirs now here, for which purpose I exchanged the order from the Patriotic Bank on the Bank of America at New-York, which I had taken for 300 dollars and took one for 100 dollars, and the other 200 dollars in bills of the late banks of this City— I drew also the remaining balance of 58.43. of the deposit for Mrs John Adams.— I then called on Mrs Adelaide Hellen at her house, paid her 80 dollars, and took her receipt. Then on Mr Frye at the paymaster general’s office—paid him 160 dollars for the portions of Mrs Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith for which they afterwards sent me their receipts— I had already those of my wife, of Johnson Hellen, and of Mrs John Adams.— There remains now only that of Mrs Boyd, which I cannot yet obtain— And I still owe 100 dollars to my wife and 140. to Mrs John Adams.— I returned to the Department of State The two Volumes of Instructions to Ministers of the United States in Europe, and two printed Volumes of English diplomatic collections which I had borrowed last Year. I enquired of Mr Calhoun if any answer had yet been received about the papers to be obtained from the Province of New-Brunswick— None— While I was with Mr Calhoun, he received a Note from the President requesting his immediate attendance at a Cabinet Meeting, about the horrible and bloody riots at Philadelphia— At the War Department I requested the re-entrance of the name of Robinson as an applicant for a Cadet warrant. Mrs Frye and Mrs Smith were here this Evening— Walk over the Tiber.

9. IV:30. Tuesday  I made up my second account of execution of the will of Mr Thomas B. Johnson, and without waiting to take copies of them, carried them with the vouchers to the judge of the Orphan’s Court, at the City Hall— The vouchers were received and the account to which I was sworn was allowed— There remains nothing further to be done but payment of 80 dollars to Mrs Boyd for the final settlement of the Estate—and the fulfilment of my trust as the executor of the Will— At the Patriotic Bank, I balanced my last account there—took a second order for 100 dollars, and a third of 62.50, for my wife on the Bank of America at New-York— I called at the National Intelligencer Office, but neither Mr Gales nor Mr Seaton was there— I returned home and occupied the remainder of the day in packing up for departure— Though I have ship’d three chests of books and papers to go round by water, and take two trunks with me chiefly filled also with papers, I leave behind a number sufficient to fill another large chest, and among them many which I shall most urgently need— My projects of employment for the remainder of the Summer and the next Autumn weigh heavily upon my spirits; with a deep apprehension that I shall fail to carry all or any of them into useful execution; and a profound conviction that the time for my departure is at hand, and that the preparation for closing all my accounts with this world cannot much longer be delayed— I had received a Letter from Judge Jacob Burnet of Cincinnati, Ohio and one from his son G. W. Burnet, who is going to Europe, for the benefit of his health— They ask for Letters of introduction; a request of the import of which the most intelligent people of this country have not the most distant conception— I wrote for Mr Burnet two short Letters, to Edward Everett, and to our Consul at London, Thomas Aspinwall— We further postponed our departure till the afternoon of to-morrow, to go no farther to morrow than Baltimore— The riots in the City of Philadelphia between the Native Americans, and the Irish Roman Catholics, have blazed up into a civil War, with this most extraordinary result that the Catholic Irish are invariably the first aggressors, and the civil and military authorities, are bandied in shooting down the Natives— In the course of Sunday Night and before day light yesterday morning; not less than 30 Native Americans and 8 or ten militia men were killed in battle array— There has been much mismanagement in the measures of the authorities to subdue the insurrection— Richard and Mary Cutts were here this Evening, and two of the daughters of General Jesup— The heat of the weather is oppressive.

properties.dateline: From Washington to Baltimore Wednesday 10 July 1844
properties.text: 10. IV:30. Wednesday  We had concluded to take the afternoon train of Cars, and to proceed no father upon our journey this day than Baltimore— We were of course occupied all the morning in packing up— We dined at 3. O’Clock— Mary Cutts with us to take leave— Mrs Talbot, confined to her bed by indisposition sent to me for an autograph sign-manual for Mr Bushby in England, and for a line upon a sheet of flower embroidered note-paper for herself— Mrs Thornton came in to take leave of the Ladies and sent me some lines of her own. At half past 3. I went in to Mr Parris’s and took leave of him and his daughter Sarah— Thomas Dumphy took us in his hack to the Rail-road depot, and at 4. P.M. we were seated in the Cars and started for Baltimore— My wife, my son John’s widow Mary Catherine, and her daughter Mary-Louisa, form our company, with my yankee friend Benjamin F. Andrews, and the mulatto boy Williamto help us— At the Depot we met Mrs Wilkins, wife of the Secretary of War, and her daughter, going home. General Scott and two young Ladies going to his seat in New-Jersey; but they were in different Cars and we saw no more of them. In two short hours we were at Baltimore, and came in a hack to Barnum’s. He himself died some months since, but his establishment survives, in charge of his Son— The heat kept us from strolling. I met Dr Semmes in the reading room— I received a note from A. A. Phelps of Boston, and afterwards a visit with Mr Gallagher a lawyer of this place, to consult me what to do for the Revd. Charles T. Torrey, in jail here, upon a charge of enticing Slaves to run away, and under a demand to be delivered up from the Governor of Virginia, for a like crime there— Bail might be taken for the Maryland Offence, but not while the Virginia bolt impends. I advised to take out a writ of habeas corpus returnable to the circuit Court of the United States—to bring the whole case before Chief Justice Taney and in the event of an adverse decision by him, appeal to the Supreme Court of the United States— They said so they would do— The case is unique. I told them that upon this matter of Slavery the Law of the Free and the Slave States is in direct conflict, and referred them to the cases of the Antelope and of the Amistad captives.

properties.dateline: From Washington to Baltimore Wednesday 10 July 1844
properties.text: 10. IV:30. Wednesday  We had concluded to take the afternoon train of Cars, and to proceed no father upon our journey this day than Baltimore— We were of course occupied all the morning in packing up— We dined at 3. O’Clock— Mary Cutts with us to take leave— Mrs Talbot, confined to her bed by indisposition sent to me for an autograph sign-manual for Mr Bushby in England, and for a line upon a sheet of flower embroidered note-paper for herself— Mrs Thornton came in to take leave of the Ladies and sent me some lines of her own. At half past 3. I went in to Mr Parris’s and took leave of him and his daughter Sarah— Thomas Dumphy took us in his hack to the Rail-road depot, and at 4. P.M. we were seated in the Cars and started for Baltimore— My wife, my son John’s widow Mary Catherine, and her daughter Mary-Louisa, form our company, with my yankee friend Benjamin F. Andrews, and the mulatto boy Williamto help us— At the Depot we met Mrs Wilkins, wife of the Secretary of War, and her daughter, going home. General Scott and two young Ladies going to his seat in New-Jersey; but they were in different Cars and we saw no more of them. In two short hours we were at Baltimore, and came in a hack to Barnum’s. He himself died some months since, but his establishment survives, in charge of his Son— The heat kept us from strolling. I met Dr Semmes in the reading room— I received a note from A. A. Phelps of Boston, and afterwards a visit with Mr Gallagher a lawyer of this place, to consult me what to do for the Revd. Charles T. Torrey, in jail here, upon a charge of enticing Slaves to run away, and under a demand to be delivered up from the Governor of Virginia, for a like crime there— Bail might be taken for the Maryland Offence, but not while the Virginia bolt impends. I advised to take out a writ of habeas corpus returnable to the circuit Court of the United States—to bring the whole case before Chief Justice Taney and in the event of an adverse decision by him, appeal to the Supreme Court of the United States— They said so they would do— The case is unique. I told them that upon this matter of Slavery the Law of the Free and the Slave States is in direct conflict, and referred them to the cases of the Antelope and of the Amistad captives.

11. IV:30. Thursday.  I enter this day on the 78th. year of my age; and but for a blessed dispensation of almighty God, it would have been the last day both of my own life, and of that of my dear and ever beloved wife. Phelps, and had a long conversation with him concerning Charles T. I enquired if other, and more employed to argue the whole case before the chief Justice as the Circuit judge and then before the Supreme Court of the United States— He said that Reverdy Johnson, and M’Mahon had been mentioned. I thought that sound opinions on the subject of Slavery, and an undaunted spirit to assert and maintain them were indispensable qualifications for any person selected for that argument, and I recommended that the counsel might be specially requested to study and refer freely to the case of the Negro Somerset in Howell’s State Trials to the case of the Antelope in Wheaton, and to my Review of it in the argument for the Amistad captives— To Mr Baldwin’s argument in that same case; and to Lord Stowell’s decision in the case of the Slave Grace, and I said that having a great personal regard for Mr Torrey I should happy if I could furnish his counsel with any information which might be useful for his defence.— We left Baltimore at 9. A.M in the train of Cars for Philadelphia, which city we reached about 4 in the afternoon, and found yet in amphibious state between mob and martial Law— We concluded to proceed immediately to New-York. Miles—there landed, and proceeded in the train of Cars through Trenton, New Brunswick, Elizabethtown and Newark to Jersey City— The Sunset between Trenton was glorious, equal to anything I ever beheld— As I witnessed the departing luminary, and the peace and quiet and felicity of all around me, I thought of Washington and Trenton, and the 25th. of December 1776 and a feeling of inexpressible joy, filled my Soul— Between 10 and 11. we alighted from the cars on an unrailed floor, raised about 4 feet above the ground. walking on this floor, dark as midnight, I stept unawares off the floor, and pitched over, and drew my wife, whose arm was linked in mine over after me. Blessed be God neither neck nor limb of either of us was broken— We were enabled after an hour of delay to cross the ferry to New-York, and reached the Aston house before midnight.

properties.dateline: New-York— Steamer Rhode Island Long-Island Sound Friday 12 July 1844.
properties.text: 12. V.30. Friday  The sensation which I suffered last night by the shock of my own fall, instantly succeeded by that of my wife was such as I never in my life experienced before, and which I have no words to describe; while falling I had the distinct idea that I was killed— A shriek from my wife, and the consciousness that she too was killed had in it a thrill of horror of which I knew not that the human frame was susceptible. My fall was so disposed that my left hip first met the earth tip’d me over upon the right side and laid me sprawling, but neither my head nor my body struck the earth— I instantly rose, feeling pain only on the hip and that not severe—but the terror for my wife, no pang of death could surpass. She had fallen forwards. Her cloathing had protected her from any shock to the body, but her left wrist was sprained and the recoil from the ground struck her breast; broke the glass of the breastpin, and slightly bruised a spot on the upper side of her chin below the lip. She had fainted and was senseless. Several men came to our assistance— They took her up and carried her into one the house sheds of the railroad company where were benches to sit upon. A physician was sent for, but as she soon came to and appeared not to be much hurt that order was countermanded— The other passengers had crossed the river in the Steam-ferry boat, and that boat in about half an hour returned. My wife had then so far recovered that she was able to be led to the boat; we crossed the river, and a hack took us to the Astor house. They gave us two bed-rooms on the first floor, and before midnight we were lodged for the Night, still unknowing how much we were injured but grateful that our lives and limbs had been spared— After a restless and agitated Night my wife felt the pain of the blow on the breast more than last Night— The skin was not broken on my hip but the bone was painful and sore, and a spot on my hip and thigh as large as a common dinner table plate is crimson with extravasated blood. It was bathed with vinegar, but as it did not pain me much I walked out—called upon Mr Lewis Tappan, and had some conversation with him respecting the case of Mr Torrey. At the Bank of America, I received in its bills 262.50 on the orders from the Patriotic Bank at Washington— At the door of the Bank I met Mr Sedgwick with a passing salutation— On returning to the Astor house, the inflammation upon my hip was so exasperated as to produce spasms in the calf of my leg— I was obliged to lie down, and to have the part rubbed with cold vinegar— After an hour of rest I took a Cab and went to N. 122 Bleecker Street where I found Mr Edward S. Marchant Portrait Painter. He had charged me 200 dollars for copies of two small profiles of President Washington and my father— I objected to this price and offered him 100 dollars about double their worth for the two—which with some reluctance he accepted, and gave me a receipt in full— I returned to the Astor house. My wife—Mary Louisa and the Servants without waiting to dine came on board the Steamer Rhode-Island— I came on board after dinner, and at 5 we departed for Stonington.

properties.dateline: Stoningon.— Providence— Boston— Quincy. Saturday. 13. July 1844.
properties.text: 13. XII.30. Saturday  Before I left the Astor house yesterday, Dr J. M. Wainwright twice called to see me. The first time I was lying down and did not see him—the second I met him in the passage just as the ladies were leaving the house to go on board the Steamer— I had time but to shake hands with him and part— The case was the same with Mrs De Windt, who was in the city, from cedar grove, and is publishing a book. Mr Charles Parker brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr Lewis Tappan. They are raising a subscription to print 50000 copies of Mr Sedgwick’s Veto, of the Evening Post in pamphlets; and Mr Parker wants a commendatory Letter upon the pamphlet from me addressed to him. I declined, but took the proposal for consideration— At dinner at the Astor house, I sat next to Mr Samuel May of Boston who was going to Saratoga— At 5 P.M. The Steamer Rhode-Island, Captain S. Thayer left the Battery pier— N. 1— The Cleopatra, for Norwich loosening from the other side of the pier at the same moment— We took the lead little more than the length of the boat and held it till the darkness of Night parted us.— The weather was of the most exquisite beauty of Nature— We had about 300 fellow passengers, not one of whom did I see that I knew. Mary said she met and held conversation with Mrs James Lloyd of Boston. We had two State-rooms, each with two berths— I had scarcely time to remark how the bark cleaved the glassy surfaced waters of Long-Island Sound Sunset past 7. By dark, about 9. I turned in to my berth—steeped my senses in forgetfulness, and at half past 12 the bell sounded Stonington in ten minutes. We landed from the boat, scrambled an ascent into the Cars— Sat a full and tedious half hour; perhaps three quarter, waiting for the transportation of the baggage from the boat to the train of cars— Started at half-past one— Crossed the river by daylight, before Sunrise to Providence— Entered the new train of Cars, and as the Clocks had struck six—alighted at the Depot at the foot of Boston Common— We engaged the Carriage from the United States Hotel— Breakfasted at that house; and at half past eight this morning landed at my own house in Quincy; blessing divine providence that we are once more safe at home, though snatched as burning brands from the fire. My Son, his wife, daughter and four Sons were with us in a few minutes all well— John Kirke and his wife were also here to welcome us— The Ladies were so much exhausted with fatigue and 3 sleepless Nights that they soon retired to bed. I walked up the hill and dined with my Son and his family. I limp with considerable difficulty and some pain. Afternoon visit from Mr Quincy, President of Harvard University. He came from Cambridge to pass the day to-morrow, with his daughter Mrs Waterston. She with her husband, and his two Aunts Ruthven are here to pass the Summer, at the President’s Country Seat.
