14 IV:30 Sunday.  Neither my wife nor myself can yet ascertain the extent to which we have been personally injured by that terrific fall of Thursday Night, on alighting from the Cars at Jersey City. The shock upon her nerves jar’d her whole frame, and suspended all consciousness and animation for nearly ten minutes— The stroke upon the breast broke the glass of the breast pin, and the stricture on the breast is yet sore and feverish. She kept her bed all day yesterday; last Night and this day till evening. She sent for Dr Woodward who came, and applied leeches to her breast; from which she obtained some relief. The suffusion of blood on and around my left hip looks frightful—the pain is slight and passing away, but the cords of the leg are growing stiffer, and make me limp. I rode to and from Meeting, both parts of this day. Mr Lunt preached in the forenoon from 1. Corinthians 12.21. “And the eye cannot say unto the hand, I have no need of thee: nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.” This is in substance the old Roman Fable of Menenius Agrippa, which I suppose Paul borrowed from his familiar acquaintance with Roman history. Mr Lunt noticed as one of the striking characteristics of the Scriptures, that they deliver instruction, in the form of parables and fables— He noticed especially those of Jotham to the men of Shechem, and those of Nathan to David— They are undoubtedly among the most impressive parts of the Bible; narrative enlists the imagination—narrative takes hold of the sympathies, and strikes its roots into the Memory— It exercise all those faculties too in the process of composition, and is by all odds the most difficult part of writing— Mr Lunts discourse was an argument upon the mutual dependence of all the members of a community upon one another, and he closed with an illustration of his own, introducing a dialogue of self-glorification and disparagement, between the roots and leaves and blossoms of trees, which will leave the whole sermon fresh on my memory, and keep in preservation the didactic parts. Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse was from Philippians 4.8. [“]Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think of these things.” A general exhortation to truth, justice, honesty, a modification of honesty, purity, another, loveliness, and good report—virtue and praise— Mr Lunt considered these several specifications in succession— He has improved much in his mode of delivery, using much more action, and animating his discourse even to vehemence. None of our Ladies attended public worship; and Mrs Charles Adams was confined at home this afternoon. Charles passed the evening here. My mind was not sufficiently settled to enable me to devote all the day to the most suitable occupations—

15. IV:30 Monday.  The fall at Jersey city, is yet severely felt, both by my wife and by myself; and still we know not how long and how far it will continue to be felt.— She is better this day; but still confined to her chamber. I am yet lame, and crippled, for walking. Patience, Resignation and blessing for the escape of us both from heavier calamity is the dictate of duty. In other respects, I luxuriate with delight in the tranquility and indolent repose of home— But indolence is waste and loss of time— This fable of Menenius Agrippa, stole upwards of hour of my time, in hunting for it, first in Livy, where, by the Index to the Bipont Edition Vol 13. I found it Book 2.32. and then in Shakespear’s Coriolanus, where it is charmingly dramatised in the first Scene— Mr Lunt paid me a visit this afternoon; and brought back the first Volume of Warton’s History of English Poetry; which belongs to the Adams town Library. Mr. Lunt had borrowed the 3. Volumes last autumn with the intention of preparing a course of Lectures on English Literature— Mr Lunt retains the 2d. and 3d. volumes of Warton, but has not accomplished his purpose of preparing a course of Lectures on English Literature. Well executed it would be a work of great usefulness; but it would be too large—too complicated— Warton’s history refers only to a very small fragment of the subject. It is the History of English Poetry from the close of the 11th. to the commencement of the eighteenth century, from 1100 to 1700. It comes not even down to the school of Queen Ann’s age— It is preceded by two Dissertations— One upon the origin of romantic fiction in Europe; and the other on the introduction of learning into Europe— Mr Lunt remarked that Warton’s subject does not embrace Shakespear, and although he does not wholly overlook the drama, he treats it very superficially— I observed that it would be difficult to give much interest to English Literature before the age of Elizabeth, but that a philosophical disquisition upon the genius and characters of the cotemporaries Shakespear, Spenser and Bacon would be rich in results— I spoke also of my published remarks on Shakespears Juliet, Lear, Desdemona, and Hamlet: and lent him a volume of miscellanies containing my replication upon the character of Desdemona— My Son came this afternoon, with four Deeds from the Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Estate of lots of land in Charlestown—one to Andrew Hall, two to J. W. Whitten and one to Edward Adams—to be executed— I went with him this Evening to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s to execute and acknowledge them before him as a Justice of Peace; but he said that although his commission had been renewed since it had expired; he had not taken the Oaths under the new Commission, and was therefore not qualified to take the acknowledgment of Deeds: so that we were obliged to defer the Execution to some other time— Mr Greenleaf was taking his new made hay prematurely put into the barn, out of it again, under symptoms of spontaneous combustion.

16. V. Tuesday.  Soon after I rose this morning it began to sprinkle, so lightly that for nearly an hour I thought it a mere transient shower; but it continued and increased to a moderate steady rain till between 2 and 3 afternoon when it held up without clearing off— I was confined to the house by the weather and by my lameness. My wife was very sick, last night and all this day— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine. He and his wife passed a short evening here— My time is never tedious when I have my books around me; but there are so many and upon subjects so different, like baits upon a bundle of fish hooks, that I make after all, no profitable use of my time. After bringing up the arrears of this diary I commenced writing an address to my Constituents to give them an account of my conduct in the discharge of their trust— But precisely because this was the first and most burdensome task which I had imposed upon myself for the first moments of leisure at home, I found it insupportably irksome, and barely commenced and abandoned it— Menenius Agrippa and his fable occurred to me again and looked for and found it in Wrangham’s Langhornes Plutarch, and there I was referred to Dionysius Halicarnassensis for the most detailed account of the whole story. This I am yet to examine— I looked into the first volume of Warton’s history of English Poetry; found myself wading into deep waters, and for fear of losing my foothold immediately withdrew.— The charm of Lord Bacon was irresisible— I took up the first volume of his works in 5. quarto volumes—London 1765. and began upon his Life by David Mallet— I mean to pursue this steadily: a few pages every day. So strange a person—the wisest—greatest—meanest of mankind— Is there not instruction in every incident of such a man’s life— I see his relations with his father, Sir Nicholas Bacon Lord keeper—with Elizabeth and James—with the Cecils father and son, with Essex, and Coke, on the winding Staircase of human affairs. A short portion of this was a dose for meditation— After dinner in rummaging over the chests of old pamphlets which I would assort in some order, I pounced upon a collection of Documents numbered 155. dated Department of State April 15. 1818. and marked as referred to in the Report of the Secretary of State of the 14th March, accompanying the message to the House of Representatives of that date— This pamphlet contains the whole correspondence of the Negotiation of Charles Pinckney and James Monroe with the Spanish Government at Aranjuez from January to May 1805. concerning the claims of the United States founded on the Louisiana Treaty— P. 15 of this pamphlet marks the first assertion of our claim to the perdido, and the Bravo—page 20. proposes an article for adjustment of the boundary—p. 88. Don Pedro Cevallos 13. April 1805 Pinckney and Monroe answer 20. April 1805. p. 95. 98. 99. 100. Proposal of the Colorado—p. 105. by Pinckney and Monroe.

17. IV:15. Wednesday.  Still crippled— But I walked with my Son, to Mr Lemuel Bracket’s and there we executed and acknowledged the four Deeds of the Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Estate, of certain lots of land in Charlestown— I deposited in the Quincy Stone Bank, the order of the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington upon the Merchant’s Bank at Boston— We went into the adjoining burying yard, where the family tomb has now my name now carved on a granite stone in advance over its iron doors.— There are already the remains of ten relatives of the family deposited there without any inscription—but on the granite side wall, there are spaces for two, marble tablets on which their names and years may be inscribed. I visited the monuments erected by my father over the graves of his father and grandfather his mother and grandfathers third and last wife. Of the first and second there is no memorial left— They are doubtless there. An unclaimed Tomb is there believed to be that of my great grandfather whose name I bear, is there, but no trace of him or his wife— The monument of the Minister has been repaired, and some of the inscriptions first made upon it. Norton Quincy only son of my great grand father, whose funeral from my father’s, now my own house I attended in September 1801. was buried in this tomb, but his name was not until the recent repair incribed on it— Anna Fiske, daughter of Thomas Shepard, wife first of Daniel Quincy, and secondly of Moses Fiske, died 24. July 1708 and was buried in this tomb, but her name is not inscribed upon it— Which appears by extracts from Fairfield’s journal, published in the Appendix to Mr Lunt’s two century discourses. She was the mother of my great-grandfather— During the remainder of the day I was idling. Resumed the reading of David Mallet’s life of Lord Bacon; which as it proceeds excites more and more of curiosity— The degree of his obsequiousness and servility to Elizabeth and her favourite Essex, and his subsequent treachery and cruelty to Essex— Then the baseness of his submission to James and to Buckingham— His venality and corruption as Chancellor and his ignominious abandonment of self-defence upon his trial—with his transcendent Genius, his overruling passion for the liberal arts and the advancement of Science, and his indefatigable application to studious labour there is a combination of qualities equally astonishing and painful. Unbounded admiration and heart sickening contempt; how can they be entertained at once for one and the same person? We had evening visits from the Revd. Mr Waterston and his wife, and also from Mr Beale and his two daughters Ann and Caroline— Mr and Mrs Lunt, were likewise here this afternoon, but I did not see them— My business was wholly neglected— I looked into Banier for Minerva and Pallas.

18. IV.15 Thursday.  My wife was so far recovered as to be able to leave her chamber, and my lameness is gradually and slowly subsiding— I visited my garden, and nursery and seminary, but the winter’s frost, and Summer’s drought have killed so many of my trees, that I lose my interest in the cultivation of them— If it be possible to pursue with consistency any cultivation of plants, and be absent from them, from six to eight months of every year, I have not been able to discover the secret.— The result of fifteen years of observation and study of the nature and growth of trees, has not furnished me with any knowledge which I could turn to improvement in the art of raising or preserving them.— My Son went to Boston this morning, and after an early dinner, his wife with their daughter Louisa Catherine, their Son Charles Francis and Mary-Louisa, departed for an excursion of ten days, to Stockbridge and to Lebanon Springs. Mrs John Adams went with them as far as Boston, and returned with Louisa C. Smith who is to pass the Summer with us. Elizabeth C. Adams also came and took tea with us— She returned last evening from a visit to her relations at Portland— I finished reading the life of Francis Bacon, Baron Verulam and Viscount St. Albans, by David Mallet, prefixed to the Edition of his works in 5 volumes Quarto.— And I began the perusal of his works.— This man was a prodigy and a paradox— He should be studied as a Chronometer or a steam-engine should be studied— As a piece of moral and intellectual mechanism. Why did I not so study him fifty years ago? and of what use will it be for me to study him now? Indulgence of curiosity— A longing thirst for knowledge— A refuge from the sickening realities of life, and desponding anticipations of the future, may perhaps carry me through this undertaking. The general reflection upon the life of Bacon is the melancholy aspect of great vicissitudes of Fortune— His transcendent talents, rapacious ambition, and disgusting sycophancy combined to raise him to the pinnacle of opulence, of honours and of power. The causes of his downfall were his connivance with briberies practiced by his servants, and with whom he shared the plunder— But James the first himself, and his minion Buckingham were deeply implicated in the charges upon which he was convicted, and it was more of their sins than of his own that he bore the penalty— James remitted successively all the parts of the sentence against him, and although he had been declared incapable of holding any office of trust whatever, he was yet summoned to the first Parliament of Charles the first in 1625— It does not appear that he attended— He died at the Earl of Arundel’s house in Highgate on the 9th. of April 1626. at the age of 64.— He was married after the age of 40, but never had a child and his wife survived him 20 years— After the remission of his fine he was severel pinched with penury and his supplicatory Letter to the king for relief is agonizing.

19. IV. Friday.  Two young men, one named Salisbury from New-York, and the other Nelson from Boston, came out for mere curiosity to see the house— They were going away without enquiring for me, but I went out and spoke to them Salisbury said he had come from New-York, to see Boston on Bunker’s hill, and this house. I had also friendly visits from Mr John Whitney and Mr Josiah Brigham— I walked before dinner to the Post Office to despatch 3 letters and for exercise— But my thigh bone is yet sore, and the sinews are strained by walking— The extravasation of blood has spread downwards to the calf of the leg, and laterally to the left side of the loins, looking dark and threatening— The confinement to the house is tedious; I endeavour to cheer it by reading and travelled this day through the two Books of Francis Bacon, of the Proficience and advancement of Learning—human and divine— The work is dedicated to king James the first, and its introduction inspires a mingled sentiment of admiration of the boldness and grandeur of the design, which it announces, and of heart ache at the depth of degradation to which it sinks in servile adulation with which it besmears the king— It is presented as in the Nature and analogy of a free will offering from a worshiper to his Deity, alluding first to the daily sacrifices, and the occasional oblations of the Levitical Law—to which he likens the faithful performance of the duties of his official employments, and then proposing a voluntary superaddition of tribute appropriate to the transcendent learning of the king the wisest the greatest the most perfect monarch that ever sat upon a throne— And this was James the first! And this unparalleled royal learning should not only prove the glory of the then present age, but should be transmitted down to after ages as an imperishable monument for the benefit and admiration of Mankind— And this work was not the consummation of that mighty purport itself—but a mere outline of a plan to turn the royal cogitations to its atchievement— The stupendous magnitude of this undertaking; the courtly cunning ingenuity and meanness of suggesting it to the king as if it was an enterprize of his own, the lofty consciousness of its sublimity, and the sly implied disclaimer of it, as any thing more on the part of the author than a mere speculative hin to be moulded into form and substance are all deserving of profound meditation—of more than I can give.— He proceeds then to enumerate and to refute the objections against learning.— Of Divines— Of Politicians— As arising from the Fortunes, Manners, or Studies of Learned men— He discusses the Diseases of Learning, the peccant humours, which have not only given impediment to the proficience of Learning but have given also occasion to the traducement thereof— And he closes the book with a copious and cheering exhibition of the dignity of Learning—a theme upon which I follow him with delight.— The style is a continuous, and perpetual citation of classical and scriptural quotations. I rode this afternoon, with the Ladies, and little Arthur, as a substitute for exercise.

20. IV. Saturday.  Rain again, all the former part of this day, which together with my sore limb confined me to the house. Mr. Cole is the Editor of a weekly journal, called the Boston Cultivator—and came to invite my subscription to the paper, of which he left one of last Saturday as a sample— I declined for the present alledging the multitude of Newspapers which I daily receive, as more than I know what to do with. We had some conversation about farming, of which he agreed with me, that a man absent eighth months of the year from his farm could know very little— In the Boston Newspapers of this morning, I noticed that the Brig William L. Jones, Captain Davis, arrived yesterday from Georgetown, and I sent Benjamin with a waggon to Boston, and he brought out the three chests of books and papers, which he had ship’d on the 2d. of this month— I made some progress in reading Bacon, on the advancement of Learning. Finished the first and began the second book— In the dedication to king James, gross as his adulation is, it is not random praise— He extols him for four specific virtues—a virtuous disposition, a virtuous ambition—a virtuous observation of the Laws of marriage, and a virtuous and most Christian desire of Peace— These were real virtues of James’s character, and they are genuine king-becoming graces.— and it is piteous to reflect that with all these virtues and with all that learning for which he was not less famed, his character as a king and as a man is universally despised— He was weak—  For the fulsomeness of the flattery, I was seeking some excuse and it occurred to me that in monarchical Governments, this beplastering of the mighty man is conventional and formal; like your humble servant at the close of a Letter, or the greetings of acquaintances, and mere strangers, professing to be very obsequious to each other—meaning of course nothing of what is said— In the argument for the advancement of Science, I thought the objections, with which he began against it, were so frivolous, and trivial that they scarcely deserved the trouble of answering them. There is however something more forcible in the catalogue of the diseases of learning.— Hume speaks contemptuously of the style of Bacon— Its most remarkable character to my mind is the copious and original turn of his thoughts, with the incessant quotations from the bibles and from the Greek and Latin Classics.— I was not entirely satisfied with the life of Bacon by Mallet; and took up that of the Biographia Britannica, which is somewhat longer.— But the mode of writing with a load of Commentary always interrupting the narrative is intolerably tedious and incompatible with that unity which should be the first Law of written composition.

21. III— IV:15 Sunday.  My wife was very sick all night, and I rose at 3. to light a lamp— She was confined this day till the Evening to her bed— I thought my wound was healed, till on walking to Meeting, I found it far otherwise— Mr Lunt preached from Romans 12.21. “Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good.” This text naturally introduced some disquisition upon the nature of good and evil, and the old perplexing enquiry why a Supreme Almighty creator, wise and good permits the existence of evil— A question which can never be solved— The Book of Genesis in its account of the Creation says, that in the process of the six days work, God surveyed it in successive parcels, and saw that it was good.— But good for what? good for whom? Good and evil are relative terms, but their relation is not to action but to sufferance— Creation is an act of power— Neither good nor evil to the Creator. Neither good nor evil to the created inanimate—good and evil have reference only to sensation— Sensation is individual, and what is good to one may be evil to another— Life, is enjoyment, and therefore is good; but unless we were commanded to love God, I see no reason by the Law of Nature why it should be required. But the meaning of St. Paul in this passage is to advise the forgiveness of injuries— It is the concluding verse of the 12th. Chapter of the Epistle to the Romans, the summary of the whole doctrine of Christianity for this world— If there existed of the whole body of the holy scriptures nothing but this 12th. Chapter to the Romans, it would form the text of the most perfect religion that was ever devised upon Earth— Mr Lunt gave notice that immediately after the service of the afternoon, there would be an meeting of the members of the Church for the election of a Deacon, in the place of the late Deacon Samuel Savil. This was the first indication that I received of the death of Deacon Savil; of that of Deacon William Spear I had received advice some months since— I rode home, and to and from meeting this afternoon. Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with us. Mr Lunt’s text for his afternoon Sermon was from John 18.38. “Pilate saith unto him, What is truth?” He observed that perhaps Pilate put this question in a jeering Spirit; but he would suppose that of those who now heard him discourse some would with deep anxiety and sincere piety put to themselves often the same question, what is truth? And the conclusion to which after varied arguments he urged them to come was that Truth consisted in the firm conviction of the existence and omnipotence of God, of the immortality of our own Souls, and our responsibility beyond the grave— He closed with a very pathetic appeal to the hearts of his hearers upon this subject— The meeting of the members of the church for the choice of a deacon was held immediately after the service— The election was by ballot. The number of votes 28. of which 26 were for George Baxter. He was present and upon a call from Mr Lunt enquiring if he accepted the appointment; answered yes— Mrs T. B. Adams, Mrs John Angier, Elizabeth C. Adams and Elizabeth Harrod were here after meeting.

22. IV. Monday.  A day wholly uninterrupted by visitors; and much though not entirely confined to the house— The contusion upon my thigh bone is yet sore, and the flesh over it swollen; and it is angered by the exercise of walking— The extravasation of blood has discoloured the whole length of the thigh, and descended by the knee pit quite to the calf of the leg, creeping round at the same time upon the groin— All round the injured spot the surface of the skin is recovering its natural colour. But directly over the spot there is swelling, induration, heat, and slight pain to the touch. I have had some apprehension of internal suppuration; and Dr Woodward who examined the part on Sunday advised the application of leeches. Without examination, he repeated the advice this morning, but a diminution of the menacing symptoms, encouraging a hope of recovery by the vis medicatrix Naturae, I postponed receiving the visit of the leeches till tomorrow. I rode after dinner with Mrs John Adams, and Charles’s youngest boy Arthur round through Milton; and occupied the rest of the day, with the second book of Bacon’s advancement of learning, and with the life of Bacon, in the Biographia Britannica— The second book on the advancement of learning opens with a brief stimulant of flattery to king James, reminding him of the peculiar inducement to him to illustrate his name and reign by the advancement of knowledge for the benefit of after ages, inasmuch as he has progeny of his own, and a prospect of more, while his immediate predecessor Elizabeth, was a sojourner in the world, in respect of her unmarried life— He then proceeds to consider what had been undertaken and performed by kings and others for the increase and advancement of learning. Genius invents—talent combines, skill marshals, and judgment separates ideas— In embracing the whole compass of human knowledge, Bacon begins by dividing it into parts, and presents in a table the General Distribution of human knowledge— “The parts of human learning have reference to the three parts of Man’s Understanding which is the seat of learning; History to his Memory, Poesy to his Imagination, and Philosophy to his Reason—[”] The subdivisions of this classification are desperately numerous and complicated and after enumerating them he specifies upon each separate part of the system those which had, and those which had not before that time been sufficiently explored by human labour. It is not a little extraordinary that with such a range of intellectual power, he should have rejected the Copernican system of Astronomy, though he acknowledges that it accounts for all the apparent movements of the Heavenly orbs.— My progress in the reading of the life is slow, and painfully laborious by remarking the gigantic intellect and the moral obliquity combined in the character of this man.— The union of Power and of Virtue is so delightful in contemplation, that I shrink from the demonstration how far it was from being realized in the person of this great bad man— The present age is prolific of the depravity if not of the greatness.

23. IV. Tuesday.  Mr Curtis came this morning with his grandson just as we were setting down to breakfast. He came to consult with me respecting the disposal of a part of the Estate of the late Ward Nicholas Boylston— I had forgotten to endorse the order from the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington upon the Merchants Bank at Boston for 80 dollarscents received as unclaimed dividends at the Treasury and which I sent by my Son last week to Mr Curtis— I now endorsed it payable to him— He wishes now to sell the Estate in School Street and has an offer for it of 30000 dollars from MrSargent. But Mr Bowditch the Lawyer is of opinion that the clause in the will directing that the old hereditary Estates should be reserved by the Executors as the last to be sold, prohibits the sale of the School Street Estate—while the Milk Street land purchased by Mr Boylston himself remains unsold— Mr Curtis wished me to examine that provision in the Will, and then go to Boston and advise with Mr Bowditch concerning it; which I promised and if sufficiently recovered from my lameness, to go in to Boston and meet him at my Son’s Office between 9 and 10. O’Clock next Thursday morning. I rode out this afternoon with Louisa C. Smith, Mrs John Adams, and Charles’s youngest boy, Arthur, this day three years old— Miss Smith alighted at Mr John Greenleaf’s and there we met Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham— We rode round by Dr Storrs’s meeting house at Braintree, and on our return stop’d at Mr Greenleaf’s— He and his wife, my cousin Lucy are barely alive— He is 80 years old, blind deaf paralytic; and crippled by a dislocated shoulder by a fall down stairs two or three years ago. She is three years younger than me, and for the last seven years has been half a dozen times supposed to be dying, yet they live— Mr and Mrs Loring and Miss Beach were still there. Mrs Lucy Dawes, and Mrs. Mary Dawes, with her husband George Dawes live with them— I asked Mrs. Greenleaf if she knew any thing of the French Sermon about which I received a Letter from the Revd. Mr Miles of Lowell, but she did not— I proceed in my reading of the second Book of Bacon on the advancement of Learning, and of his life in the Biographia Britannica— The multiplicity of his subdivisions of the Sciences has already crowded my Memory into confusion— I should need a close study of a week to embrace them all, with discrimination— He advises the study of the Mathematics for a bird-witted child—that is who has not the faculty of attention— I feel dismally the want of this faculty, and believe that I ought to enter upon a course of Mathematics. The Life in the Biographia is more detailed and circumstantial than that of Mallet, and gives the succession of his works of his honours and of his disgrace. His Life embraces no inconsiderable part of the Reigns of Elizabeth, and of James the first— I drag along heavily one page a day, in writing upon the special subject which I had determined to discuss during the present recess of Congress. Mr Loring wishes me to go to Hingham, on the 1st. of August.

24 IV. Wednesday  Mr Spear is an itinerant lecturer for an Anti-Slavery Abolition Society, and he came with a copy of my Letter to Thomas Loring of 8. August 1842. in which it is stated that the Slaves of this Union were then represented in the National House of Representatives by 25 members, and enquired whether this was the fact now. I told him that the statement made upon the apportionment, by the census of 1830. when the house of Representatives consisted of 242 members. But that the present apportionment is fixed by the census of 1840— The house consisting of 223 members— The standard of apportionment 70680.— The numbers of Slaves 2,487,213— The standard gives one representative for 117800 Slaves, or 21 members and a decimal fraction of 113. for the whole number— But as an element of power, the whole delegations from the Slave holding States, and each member represents the whole Slave-holding interest, and the whole mass of Slave owners— The number of their members therefore is not 21 but 88. knit together by one interest and that interest the ascendancy of Slavery. Mr Spear said this was a view of the subject new to him, and I referred him to my report at the recent Session of Congress, on the Massachusetts Resolutions for a further exposition of it— I gave him a copy of the printed Document of the proceedings of the Senate on the Texian Annexation Treaty— This afternoon I received a visit from Mr William Lawrence with his youngest daughter, and an inmate of his family, Miss Hale, and with them came Miss Harriet Welsh; who remained to pass some time with us— I rode with Louisa C. Smith, Miss Welsh, and Mary to Dorchester over Milton Bridge, recrossing the Neponset above, and returning by the new village of the granite quarries, and the Roman Catholic Church surmounted by its Cross— My double reading of Bacon, on the advancement of learning, and of his life, suffers interruption, by numberless casual and trivial avocations, of which when the day is gone I can give no account— I see frequent reference to Dr Rawley’s life of Lord Bacon, but the name of Rawley is not in the Catalogue of Harvard University Library. Dr Tenison, Dr Shaw, Stephens and Arthur Wilson, in a History of Great-Britain are also quoted as authorities for sundry statements of facts— Only the last of these works is in the college library.— My own work of the Season labours along more than any thing else. In the National Intelligencer of the 19th. there is the translation of a Letter from General Santa Anna the Mexican President about the propositions sent by the special messenger G. L. Thompson to be remembered— Matter for discourse on this subject multiplies under my hand and becomes daily more difficult to discuss.

25. IV. Thursday.  I had promised Mr Nathaniel Curtis, to go into Boston this morning, to consult with him and Mr Bowditch about the sale of the Boylston Estate in School Street, and I have examined Mr Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Will to ascertain the extent of the limitation of the powers of the Executors to dispose of the real Estate— I find the words of the will are—the Estates which belonged to my Ancestors shall be the last sold. Now the Estate in School Street belonged to Thomas Boylston the third of the name in lineal descent including the first emigrant from England in 1636— He was not an ancestor of Ward Nicholas, but his uncle—brother to his mother Mary Hallowell, and Son of Thomas Boylston and Sarah Morecock.— This Thomas was the 4th. Son of the first emigrant Thomas. I find these particulars in a genealogical table compiled by Coll. A. S. Brooks 28 Septr. 1827. and copied by me 13. Septr. 1839. A question remains whether the Estate in School Street was purchased by the 3d. Thomas Boylston, or descended to him from his father. In the latter case, it comes within the limitation of the authority to sell— This question can be settled only by the title deeds.— I wished also to go in to Boston to attend the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society But about Sunrise it began to sprinkle and I waited till near 9. O’Clock hoping that it would hold up—instead of which it came to a steady rain— I countermanded the order for the carriage, and passed the day without going beyond the yard— My reading was so desultory, and my attention so distracted that I retain nothing that I read— I had well nigh forgotten my Letters to Edward Everett and T. Aspinwall for Mr G. W. Burnet— I finally enclosed them in a short Letter to him addressed them as he had directed to New-York.— I received this morning a New-York Daily Tribune of last Monday, containing a translation through the New Orleans Bulletin, from the Diario del Gobierno of Mexico, of a Correspondence between Ben E. Green, son of Duff Green chargé d’Affaires of the United States in Mexico, and Jose Maria de Bocanegra, the Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs: from the 25th. to the 31st of last May, whereby the Mexican Government was notified of the Treaty for the annexation of Texas which President Tyler had negotiated and sent to the Senate on theof April— I have also received two Sermons, one preached at the consecration of Bishop Eastburn, by Bishop De Lancey 29. December 1842 at Boston, and called the faithful Bishop; and the other by Edwards A. Park Professor at the Andover theological seminary, delivered on the 28th of May last at Boston, on the duties of the New-England Clergy— These Sermons, are the bane and antidote to each other. The New-York Evangelist of 11. July contains a narrative of a new expulsion of the Jesuits from Persia— This various and desultory reading absorbs my attention so that when I turn to the second Book of Bacon on the advancement of learning, my Memory becomes a cullender, and the stream of thought runs through as fast as I pour it in— Mary read this evening two Chapters of Coningsby— I suffered last Night with the rhumatism.

26. IV:15 Friday.  The confinement to which I still subject myself owing to the disability of my left thigh, affects my spirits and health, that seems to change my nature. The privation of that exercise which for so many years I have made a necessary of life, is sinking me into a state of Apathy and stagnation of the blood. I have every evening on going to bed an application of Opodeldoc, and my thigh is slowly and gradually recovering its colour.— This morning I began to work with the hoe, upon my seedling trees in the seminary—very few of which remain alive— Josiah Adams came to speak of a pew in the Meeting house which for some years pass he has rented of me— The year expires in October, and he wishes to continue the lease for another year I promised him an answer next week, to consult in the mean time my Son, whose return home to-morrow we expect.— We had morning visits from Rufus Dawes and his wife, judge Cranch’s daughter Elizabeth—Mrs Mary Dawes, and a Miss Fisher— Lewis Bass Collector of the Parish tax, brought me my bill for the present year 171 dollars 5 Cents—which I took ad referendum. A man named Brazee came from Brattleborough in the State of Vermont— Left an orphan in childhood, for the last 8 years he has made shoes for subsistence, but he aspires to loftier destinies, and is desirous of acquiring the Science of music—to qualify himself for teaching it— This of course requires expence, and he comes to me as a benevolent person to supply his wants— I declined without incivility— Evening visit from Mr George W. Beale— I rode this afternoon with Miss Welsh, Mrs John Adams and the child Arthur.— My wife has a Letter from his father at Lebanon springs, written that day.— I finished reading the second book of Bacon on the advancement of learning; and now I ought to compass the whole extent of the work, but cannot, without reading it over again and again— These two books however on the advancement of learning form a very small part of the Treatise de Augmentis scientiarum, which is in nine Books in the fourth Volume of this Edition, in Latin without any translation, and is itself only the first part of the Instauratio magna, the second part of which is the Novum Organum, like wise in Latin without translation— In the distribution of the Sciences and especially of those which concern the mind there are in this book a multitude of observations upon men and manners which would have been equally if not more appropriate in the Essays. There is in them a depth and compass of intellect admirable, and surprizing; but always some thing louche in the moral aspect.— The plan of the work is original; but the thoughts in detail are all borrowed; and the quotations from the Bible and from Greek and Latin Classics are numberless.

27. IV:15. Saturday.  Yesterday was the 47th. anniversary of my marriage. A day which I always welcome with gratitude to Heaven; but which at every return gives warning of nearer approach if not advent of the last. It passed away this time with out notice except in my memory It was a nearly idle day for reading or writing; and this day was still more so— I answered a Letter from Mr Henry Bowers of Scituate, and sent his two Portraits to my Son’s Office N. 23. Court Street Boston— Benjamin went in with the Carriage, and Harriet Welsh returned to Boston alone. In the Evening, my Son and the party with him came back from their excursion to Lebanon, Albany, and the Catskill Mountain All well. Dr Woodward was here, and examined again my contusion— There is yet a hard swelling at the spot on which I fell, and some discolouration of the skin by extravasated blood, down below the ham to the calf of the leg but the discolouration is fading, and the hard swelling abates. Alexander S. Johnson, eldest son of Mr Johnson of Utica, and of my brother Charles’s second daughter, came out with Mr George Thom from Boston; Mr Thom had an engagement in Boston and could not stay to dine— Mr Johnson dined with us, and after dinner I walked with him, first to my Son’s house, whence he surveyed the prospect of Boston harbour, the Boston State house, the Cap of the Boston Light-house, the upper part of the shaft of the Bunker hill Column—the background of the blue hills, and the side view of the Adams Temple, the rising granite town-house, the Hancock lot with the old lime tree in the centre, and the old cellar to the house where John Hancock was born, and the surrounding beautiful village—we then went to the temple, the door of which was open, and sexton in the porch under the belfry, and over the vaults. He had not the key of the vault where my father and mother repose, but Mr Johnson viewed the marble tablet, at the right hand of the pulpit as you go up the central aisle, erected in 1829. with the inscription upon it written by me, and surmounted by the marble bust of my father: the work of Greenough. Thence we proceed to the opposite grave yard, where my name carved on the granite front of my tomb, marks in advance the spot of my last home; and there we visited the four granite Monuments erected by my father to his ancestors Henry, Joseph Senior, Joseph and John who preceded him from the settlement of Mount Wollaston down to his own time— Mr Johnson then returned to Boston—while we were out Mr Robert G. Shaw and his daughter were here as visitors but were gone before we returned— My Son and Mary-Louisa came in at dusk of eve, and President Quincy, and the Revd. Mr Waterston paid us evening visits.

28. IV:30. Sunday.  Dr Pierce of Brookline preached, this morning from a clause in Colossians 3.4. “Christ, who is our life.”— This figure of speech unintelligible in its literal sense was first used by Jesus Christ himself— “I am the resurrection and the life.” the life—not saying whose life— Paul, speaking to the Christians of Colosse says Christ is our life—and in the verse preceding that of the text he says— [“]For ye are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God”—and the whole verse from which the text was taken reads [“]When Christ, our life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with him in glory.”— This Epistle to the Colossians is one of the shortest books of the new Testament, consisting only of 4. short chapters, in which the peculiar Christian doctrine of the atonement is blended with a summary of moral precepts for the regulation of private and domestic life. Dr Pierce considered the assertion in the text that Christ is our life, under five several aspects 1. As Christ is the source 2. the manifestation 3. the hope, 4 the comfort and 5 the resurrection to eternal life. Upon each of these points he made remarks apposite to the text, but from which I could draw no very clear practical conclusion.— It was a dissertation of the old school of which Dr Pierce is one of the oldest patriarchs. A graduate of Harvard of 1793.— He gave notice at the request of Mr Lunt that the communion would be administered next Sunday.— He came home with me, and dined with us.— His afternoon text was from John 19.25. [“]Now there stood by the cross of Jesus, his mother, and his mother’s sister, Mary the wife of Cleophas, and Mary Magdalene.” (Question of construction, was the sister of Jesus’s mother, and Mary the wife of Cleophas the same person, or two persons, and if the same how came the two sisters to be both named Mary?) The motive for the selection of this text seems to have been, to pronounce a magnificent panegyric upon the female sex— I believe the superiority of the female sex in all the social and benevolent virtues, and am not sure that the tribute of the Doctor’s gallantry was out of place. I had scarcely returned from the afternoon service when Mr Degrand came in from Boston, with Mr W. W. Clapp Editor of the Boston Evening Gazette who took tea and spent the evening with us. They visited with me, my garden Nursery and seminary; and witnessed the ruin of my trees.— We had also evening visits from Mr and Mrs G. T. Bigelow, Elizabeth C. Adams, Georgiana Harrod, John and Fanny Foster and Charles Miller. Of course no reading. My Son also spent the Evening here

29. IV:30. Monday  I was visiting my Seminary this morning, and for some bodily exercise was hoeing round the roots of my fruit trees dead and alive, when Mr E. Price Greenleaf came in, and walked with me round my grounds. I have lost at least forty peach trees of all ages whether by the frosts of last winter, or the drought of the present summer I cannot tell— Every one of the seedling Oaks of last Summer has perished— One budded Pear stock, and several Apples have thrown out vigorous shoots, but the borer at the root of the stock and the aphis at the top of the shoot prey upon their vitals in concert Mr Alexander S. Johnson came out from Boston in the Noon Stage to spend a week with us. After dinner Mr Beale called on me with Mr Gardiner, the chief surveyor for the projected Old Colony Railroad— They were staking it out, to pass within ten feet east of my eastern most barn—then to cross in oblique line the County-road—traverse centrally my lot in front of my house and the Hancock lot given by my father to the town, and pass close westward of the burying ground.— It would scarcely be possible to carry through a line more injurious to my property, both by the danger of firing my barns and by cutting up into fragments the most valuable lot of land that I possess. But it is useless to complain and idle to remonstrate. While standing out at the corner where they were to pass, a phaeton came along with a gentleman and Lady in it— The man got out, and came up to me, announced himself by the name of Cutler, and said he had been requested by Mr Henry Bowers of Scituate, to make enquiry concerning two Portraits of my father, and President Washington, which he had left with me last year, and he wished to know my opinion of them. I told him that I had received a Letter from Mr Bowers to the same effect which I had answered last Saturday, and according to his request had sent the portraits to my son’s office 23. Court Street Boston— And that I had been so much pleased with the Portraits that I had exact copies of them taken by an eminent Portrait Painter, Mr Marchant for myself— I met there also Harvey Field and John J. Carr, my tenant who lost a Cow last night, he thought by her eating whole apples.— A person by the name of Samuel L. Fiske of Southbridge in the County of Worcester, came and introduced himself as he said solely for the purpose of seeing me, and having to say that he had seen me— Mercy Tufts paid us an afternoon visit— And Mr Stockton the purser in the Navy, with his wife came out from Boston, where he is stationed and took tea with us. I walked up the hill to see Mrs Charles, who has come back from her tour very much fatigued and Charles came home with me and spent the Evening with us— Of the day thus occupied what can I say more—and what became of Bacon?

30. IV:30. Tuesday.  The preconcerted current of my daily occupations continues under great perturbation. My Son went to Boston this day, and brought me out a volume of critical and miscellaneous Essays of T. Babington Macaulay, consisting of reprinted articles from the Edinburgh Review— I wanted it for an article upon Lord Bacon, of which I had heard, and which I expect will be satisfactory— It is a review of a new Edition of Bacon’s works in 16 octavo volumes, published 1825–1834. by Basil Montagu— And in the last volume of which there is the desideratum, a new Life of Bacon— I sent an answer to Mr Daniel P. Parker’s invitation to me, to visit the ship which he has called by my name, and promised to go next Saturday, if a fair day. And I wrote an answer to Miss Thaxter’s invitation to me, to attend the anniversary celebration of the 1st. of August, at Hingham— We had a visit this afternoon from Mr Hülsemann the Austrian chargé d’Affaires at Washington; and afterwards one from Mr Loring, who was very urgent in soliciting my attendance at the Hingham celebration of the 1st. of August. I persisted in declining, assigned my lameness from which I have not yet sufficiently recovered, as my principal reason, but hinting at some others, not less monitory to detain me at home.— I told him I had answered with some prolixity Miss Thaxter’s Letter of invitation, and explained my unwillingness to take part in the celebration of this anniversary.— He said he should go to Boston again to-morrow, and on his return in the Evening would stop, and take the letter to Miss Thaxter and deliver it to her.— I began to read the Sylva Sylvarum, or Natural History in ten Centuries: each consisting of 100 experiments— There is a preface to this work by William Rawley, Lord Bacon’s Secretary written for publication before his death, but not published till after that event— He says it was intended as a third part of the Instauration. As a middle link between the De Augmentis Scientiarum, an the Novum Organum— But Bacon hesitated whether to publish it or not during his life time, and it does not appear at all essential to the great work. It is divided into experiments in consort, and experiments solitary; and it has more the appearance of a Cookery book, or collection of Confectioner’s receipts than a philosophical system of Natural history— It begins with experiments of percolation—or the straining and passing of bodies one through another— And the remarkable fact is that he falsifies the result of the experiment. He says dig a pit on the sea shore above high water mark, and sink it below low-water Mark— As the tide flows in, it will fill with fresh and potable water— This is a mistake—the water will not be potable, nor even potable though it will lose many of its saline particles, by evaporation. Charles spent the evening here, but his wife did not come.

31. IV. Wednesday.  Sun rose 4 51. set 7.18.  For the first time since my return home I was able to go up the hill and see the Sun rise from the South-east corner of my Son’s house— My Chronometer is 51 minutes in advance of the Sun. It qualifies not a little the pleasure which I experience in witnessing the phenomenon of Sunrise to observe what progress of Southing he has already made from the solstitial point of declination. From this day forward the nights lengthen and the days shorten till the winter solstice, and I must soon rely upon lamplight for the morning hours— I received a note from Mr Loring, that he could not call here this afternoon, as he had promised yesterday— I took therefore the Letter to Miss Thaxter to the Post-Office— It began to sprinkle as I was on my way, and before I got home became a shower followed by others all the remainder of the day, which confined me to the house— Mr A. S. Johnson dined at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. I received a Letter from William Wallace Whitney at New-Orleans, enclosing the Morning Herald of that city of 17. July current— In that paper, there is printed a Letter from the same Whitney to William Cullen Bryant Editor of the New-York Evening Post. It is an elaborate and formal defence and attempted vindication of the character of General Edmund Pendleton Gaines from the charge of rashness in an editorial article of the Evening Post.— In his Letter to me enclosing this paper Mr Whitney refers to my address to my constituents at Braintree of 17. September 1842. in which he says I took occasion to allude to the measures of General Gaines on the Sabine during the Mexican and Sabine War, and as he, Whitney conceives, did him injustice— He therefore calls my attention to the printed Letter and requests a reconsideration of my opinion— The printed Letter is in so small a type that I was obliged to Mr A. S. Johnson for reading it to me; and it will require from me a calm, considerate and spirited answer.— But for this I must take time Charles and his wife and daughter spent the Evening with us.— But all my reading of Bacon is suspended, by Macaulay’s review of Basil Montagu’s edition of his work and Life. The review charges Montagu with a laborious and absurd effort to defend the moral character of Bacon; and the attempt to pass him off as a Spirit as pure as it was bright—but this was a desperate task. Macaulay darts into both extremes—extols the intellect and denigrates the moral qualities in Hyperboles. Bacon was at once an unscrupulous man of the world and sycophant of a royal court, and a profound philosopher— The important events of his life—his slow and gradual ascent to fame, power and honours— His horrible treachery to the Earl of Essex, his base subserviency to the favourite Buckingham; his lamentable downfall and self-sacrifice, and the resignation and perseverance with which he redeemed himself to the veneration of posterity are a theme for continuous meditation and unabating interest.

1. IV.15. Thursday.  Mr Hale came as an agent to solicit a contribution for a private establishment for the support and disposal of poor orphan children— It was devised and is maintained by Misses A. and E. C. Fellows in Boston, who publish a quarto periodical journal, styled the Social Monitor and Orphan’s Advocate in Monthly numbers, one of which Mr Hale left with me. He says he was himself an orphan, supported and educated by these persons. Their plan is to withdraw from the poor houses of the country towns such orphan poor as they can find opportunity to provide for by placing them in families where care is taken to educate and maintain them— This is the day of the Anniversary celebration at Hingham— This day the Steam ship Caledonia Captain Lott, arrived at Boston from Liverpool and Halifax in 12 1/2 days with 92 passengers. And the Steamship Hibernia Captain Ryrie, sailed from Boston for Halifax and Liverpool— One calendar month now suffices for writing to London and receiving an answer— I finished reading Macaulay’s Article on Bacon, which I have read with pleasure, but which has kindled my thirst to see and compare Montagu’s edition of his works with that of Mallet which I possess.— and particularly to read Montagu’s life of the compound of Angel and Fiend Francis Bacon— Macaulay judges him with a mixture of excessive rigour and of extreme admiration and kindness. There is a natural alliance between admiration and love—and a natural affinity between contempt and hatred— But between admiration and hatred there is none; and between Love and contempt there may be an easy transition but no union. Macaulay’s estimate of Bacon’s philosophical system and discoveries appear to me to be greatly exaggerated, and his condemnation of the Grecian Philosophy much too broad and universal.— The Stoic, Epicurean, and Platonic philosophies were as full of practical good as the novum organum. When Pythagoras sacrificed a hecatomb, for having discovered the relative measure of the right angle and the hypothenuse, it was not the mathematical abstraction that caused his joy.— When Archimedes said to Hiero give me a stand I will move the earth, it was not a barren problem of mechanics of which he boasted. The sayings of the wise men—the golden verses—the inductive reasoning of Socrates were all eminently practical and useful— Bacon proposed a new method of study, and disparaged too much that which preceded him. While I have been reading Macaulay Bacon himself slumbers. I have fallen into idle habits— I rise about 4. Wash, scrub and curry one hour—read first permanent matter—then Newspapers and pamphlets which come by Mail— Journalize 3 hours—searching for papers at intervals till 2. dine. Afternoon Siesta two hours— Yawn, and range about the house and garden till Sunset— Tea— Evening with my family.

2. III:30. Friday.  My Son with Alexander S. Johnson, and Charles’s sons John and Charles went this morning on a fishing party to Cohasset— They returned before dinner and I dined with Mr Johnson at Charles’s— I wrote to Mrs Harriet Boyd at Green Bay, Wiskonsin Territory, authorising her with her husband to draw upon me for 80. dollars payable at one day’s sight at the Merchant’s Bank Boston—being for her portion of the balance of the proceeds of sale of Mr T. B. Johnson’s effects directed by the judge of the orphan’s Court at Washington to be distributed between his sisters.— I answered also the invitation of Mr B. R. Curtis to attend at the Meeting of the Alumni of Harvard University the day before Commencement, and to preside at their dinner— I declined though with a very strong inclination to accept— And I wrote to Mr George Fuller, Administrator of the Estate of Moses Gill; requesting him to transfer to the Executors of the Will and Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston, seven shares of the stock of the Pennsylvania Bank of the United States, of the 25 which I transferred to him last April. A great part of this day was absorbed in looking up loose pamphlet documents of which I have immense multitudes in such disorder and confusion that whenever I want any one of them it is like seeking one grain of wheat in a bushel of chaff—a desolating search three times out of four terminating in disappointments, and loss of the time.— With the design of answering Mr William Wallace Whitney’s Letter, I recurred to my Address to my Constituents at Braintree on the 17th of September 1842— I soon found the passage containing the statements and opinions which Mr Whitney requests me to reconsider— It was the charge that in 1836. President Jackson expressly authorised General Gaines to invade the Mexican territory—and take post at Nacogdoches which he did.— I find throughout the whole passage no charge against General Gaines, but I did not state in my address, the equivocating disavowal by Jackson in Secretary Forsyth’s Letter to the Mexican Minister Gorostiza of 10. May 1836. of Gaines’s actual occupation of Nacogdoches. Of that disavowal Mr Whitney takes no notice in his Letter to Bryant Editor of the New-York Evening Post—a disingenuous omission which must not be suffered to pass without exposure— But for that purpose I must review the whole series of transactions of that period, and especially the whole controversy respecting the Gorostiza pamphlet— In this pursuit I passed from my Address at Braintree, to my fragment speech of June and July 1838. where I charged upon Jackson’s administration these escroceries of his conduct towards Mexico, and once engaged in the reperusal of that Speech the leisure of the day was consumed— Mr Lunt was here this afternoon— And Walter Hellen arrived from Washington.

3. IV. Saturday.  I went to Boston this morning, with Mrs Charles Adams Alexander S. Johnson and my Grand-daughter Mary-Louisa— Charles went with his son John in his own Curricle. Mrs Charles and Mary-Louisa alighted at Miss Wainwright’s door— I went first to the Emancipator and Morning Chronicle Office, where I found the Revd. Joshua Leavitt. I delivered to him the manuscript copies of the proceedings in the District and Circuit Courts of the United States in Georgia upon the case of the Antelope.— I had received a Letter from Mr Charles T. Torrey in jail at Baltimore, requesting the loan of these papers for the use of his counsel. Mr Leavitt promised to have them forwarded. I then went to Charles’s Office and thence to the bottom of commercial wharf on board of the new ship John Quincy Adams, just built for Mr. Daniel P. Parker who has given to it this name— Built at Medford—of 650 tons burden already nearly loden with a cargo of cotton fabrics and bound to Canton in China. She has a sculptured figure head likeness of me, larger than life of about 8 feet in stature, and considered as a strong resemblance, with the name and the family arms carved upon the stern— Mr Parker had assembled a few of his friends and mine to meet me there; and after taking me all over the ship and introducing to me the master workmen, ship carpenters, block-makers riggers and caulkers, and especially the carver of the head and stern Mr Mason, had a temperance collation of cakes, grapes apricots and limonade served up in the cabin, where Coll. Josiah Quincy, introduced by a short sentiment complimentary a toast so flattering that I could not fix it in my Memory. I was so overwhelmed with humiliation that I had not the power of articulation left and only muttered a few incoherent words, and hid my head for shame! Coll. Quincy relieved the dulness of the Scene by his usual smartness of wit, and he called on the Sailor’s preacher the Revd Mr Taylor, who made a short and amusing Speech— Mr Abbot Lawrence and Mr Gould joined in the conversation, and a number of Ladies cheered the company with their smiles.— About half past 12. I took my leave and the company dispersed I gave a parting blessing of silent prayer for the destiny of the ship and returned through Faneuil Hall Market to Charles’s Office.— Saw there Dr. George Parkman and Mr Andrews the broker— Thence we rendez vous’d with Mrs Charles and Mary-Louisa at Dr Frothingham’s, and returned home to Quincy to dine After dinner I was disqualified for writing— Elizabeth De Windt, now Mr Christopher Pierce Cranch came this afternoon to spend some days with us. She was married last winter and has since resided in the City of New-York— She is in feeble and infirm health.

4. IV. Sunday.  Communion day. Mr Lunt’s morning text was from 1. Peter 3. [“]For Christ also hath once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit: 19 by which also he went and preached unto the spirits in prison.” It was a discourse preparatory to the administration of the communion— The verse immediately preceding the text says “For, it is better, if the will of God be so, that ye suffer for well-doing than for evil-doing.” an admirable principle of morals, and well deserving to be itself the text of a whole sermon— Mr Lunt said that the Apostle Peter must have had an acute sense of the difference between these two modes of suffering— He had suffered for evil-doing, when he forsook his lord and Master in the last scene of his life; and he was to suffer for well-doing, when he died a martyr to the Christian cause— There is something obscure, and which seems to require explanation in the assertion that Christ after his crucifixion went and preached unto the Spirits in prison— The main argument of the epistle is an earnest exhortation to all the disciples of Christ to follow his example by suffering, not only without swerving from the path of righteousness, but by persevering in that of active beneficence. In the administration of the Communion an affecting incident occurred by the appearances of the two new Deacons to distribute the bread and wine in the place of the two who for several years past had performed that service—Savil and William Spear— After the Meeting I began to walk home, but was overtaken by a sudden shower of which the water fell in a flood, and I was driven to take refuge in the carriage which was taking home Louisa Smith and Mrs Charles. Even that barely saved me from a drenching.— Mr Bigelow handed me as we were coming out of the Temple a very urgent invitation from Jonathan Chapman Chairman of the Whig State central Committee, to attend and preside at a Mass Convention of the Whigs of Massachusetts upon Boston Common, on Thursday the 19th. of September next, and said he would call on me for an answer this evening— I attended meeting this afternoon alone— Mr Lunts text was from 2. Corinthians 7.1. the last line of the verse—“perfecting holiness in the fear of God.” The doctrine of the discourse was that the fear of God, that is Religion is the exclusive and only foundation of perfect virtue; a principle which I hold to be certain though perfect virtue does not always follow from religious faith. This Sermon was well written, well reasoned, and well delivered. I preferred it to the one of the morning. The fear of God is the sum total of the Old Testament— The immortality of the Soul is the vital essence of the New— From these two articles of faith necessarily follows the responsibility of Man, the only guarantee of human virtue. Mr and Mrs G. T. Bigelow and Mrs John Angier visited us this Evening. Mr Bigelow undertook to deliver my verbal answer to Mr Chapman’s invitation declining to preside at the Mass Meeting of whigs on Boston Common— Age and infirmity admit of no composition— Mrs Elizabeth Cranch was so unwell that she could not come down to dinner— But she revived in the Evening.

5. III.30. Monday.  Alexander Smith Johnson eldest surviving son, of my deceased niece, youngest daughter of my brother Charles, after spending a week with us, left us this morning, to return to the city of New-York, where he resides, and is a practising lawyer— He was born 30 July 1817. at Utica, and was educated at Yale College (See my diary of 1. June 1830. Vol. 10. p. 466.) The Revd Dr Storrs of Braintree paid us a morning visit with his wife and sister— I called at the Quincy stone bank, and deposited there 20 Eagles and 20 half Eagles which I had received at the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington—reflecting that a deposit there of gold coin, is far safer than in my own house. After dinner, Mr George Warren, a member of the Boston Mercantile Library Association came and urgently invited me, to deliver the introductory Lecture to the course which they propose to commence next October— I had hoped to be spared the annoyance of these applications by my card in the National Intelligencer ofJuly last, but they are more numerous than ever. I told Mr Warren that I could make no engagement, but would deliver a Lecture if I should find it in my power— Mr Loring of Hingham and his wife were also here—and I promised to go with him to a fishing party at Cohasset, on Thursday of next week— Three times this afternoon I sat down to continue writing my proposed address to my Constituents—and wrote not more than five lines— Read not a single concerted or solitary experiment of Bacon’s Natural History, nor one page of Macaulay’s Miscellaneous articles from the Edinburgh Review— Great part of the day was consumed in overhauling my pamplets putting them into confusion worse confounded, and hunting up 25 of my own composition of which I made a parcel and gave it to Alexander S. Johnson— I made out last summer a list of 72 Miscellanies in print by me, which on looking over now I find very deficient.— In American State Papers collected by Lowrie and Clark and published by Gales and Seaton in 21 volumes folio, the first four contain the Documents relating to foreign Affairs, and of these there are in the fourth volume many written by me— My hand is in almost every collection of the Session of Congress documents from year to year for the last 30 years, and not unfrequently before— I rise so early that in reading or writing I find myself oppressed by drowsiness, and compelled to quit my table for more stirring occupation— I then begin to ransack my old papers, which wakes me up, but consumes my time, and dissipates my thoughts. I have also resorted to the practice of taking a Siesta after dinner which makes up for the shortness of my sleeping hours at Night. But it is a subtle thief of Life.

6. IV. Tuesday.  Sun rose 4.58. Set beclouded  I am so far relieved from my lameness that I can walk without spraining my leg— I went up the hill and saw the Sun rise from the East corner of Charles’s house—not quite clear, but so that I could mark the first beam of his appearance above the horizon.— I filled earthen pot N. 3. with earth and planted in it 3. Washington red plumstones; as I had done in each of the other two— I took other morning exercise of an hour, my health recreation and apology for wasted time— There are four stocks, budded last Summer by E Price Greenleaf, 3 apple and one Pear, which have put forth shoots, the pear 3 feet 9 inches—the apple in front of my study window 2. feet—that in Fanny’s plat 28 inches—that in Mary Louisa’s plat 21 inches— The stalks of all the apples stunted by the congregaiton of green aphides and black ants. There are seven shag-bark walnuts up in the bed behind the tool box up, from my last fall’s plantation— I would gladly save them from the frosts of next winter, but know not how. Mr Lunt called, having already returned the 2d. volum of my miscellanies which I have given to my grand daughter Mary Louisa— He told me he had been pleased with my essay on the character of Desdemona, but did not concur with my opinion of her— I asked him on what point he differed.— He said on the point that the colour of Othello constitutes the Tragedy, and on my rigorous estimate of the character of Desdemona— But he was not disposed to discuss, and I did not press for it— He said there was a man at work in the graveyard engraving on the ministerial monument the name of Mrs. Anna Fiske second wife of the Revd. Moses Fiske, and before that, widow of Daniel Quincy, and mother of John Quincy whose name I bear— She was my great-great-grand-mother—my trisayenle, and I revere her memory as if she were mother. That she was buried in this Tomb, is ascertained by an extract from Fairfields Journal quoted in Mr Lunt’s two centennial Discourses— Mr Lunt had a list of my published miscellanies, which he gave me, requesting me to revise and correct it— This has stimulated me to re-examine the immense mass of my pamphlets and old Congressional documents which appals me as I proceed. Walter Hellen offers to assist me and this day we made some progress, but a whole month will not suffice for the task. I this day found at last the collections which I had made last Summer, and preceding Seasons, of my own miscellanies, to give to my son, and others of my relatives and friends— That for my Son contains a number sufficient to make four large volumes for binding—and there are scattered about in newspapers and other public journals an ample number to make up four volumes more; besides manuscripts numberless. I received this day Letters from William H. Seward and Christopher Morgan of Auburn, New-York, inviting me to write for publication a Letter on the subject of the annexation of Texas to the Union; and an invitation from George Bliss, George Dwight and Henryinviting me to a whig mass Convention at Springfield on the 9th.

7. III.30 Wednesday.  Sun rose 4.58. Set 7:13  I saw the Sun this day, rise, and set, from my Son’s house; neither entirely clear; but both enough so to mark the moment of his emerging and disappearance. Mr Enos White of Weymouth came this morning to solicit a contribution for surrounding with a fence, and putting into some order the grave yard of the parish of which my grandfather William Smith was many years the Pastor— There he, and his wife Elizabeth Quincy, my Grandmother and Dr Cotton Tufts, and his wife Lucy Quincy, my Grandmother’s sister, and their son Cotton, all lie buried— In that spot in October 1775. I attended the funeral of my Grandmother.— And there on the 6th. of May 1833 I attended the funeral of Cotton Tufts the son. I told Mr White that in the Summers of 1774 and 1775. I had lived several months in the house of my Grandfather at Weymouth, and he and his wife seemed to me, as a second father and mother. When last there I had seen the Stones over the graves of my grand parents, and would cheerfully contribute to a fencing round the enclosure, and other reparations for the protection of the place from insult— Mr Daniel Greenleaf paid a morning visit to me, and to Mrs Elizabeth Cranch now the wife of his nephew Christopher Pierce Cranch. Mr Greenleaf is 83 years of age, and so deaf, that it is difficult to hold a conversation with him—and Mrs Cranch is so infirm in health, that it is doubtful whether she will out live him.— She and Mary-Louisa dined this day at Mrs Adams’s my brother Thomas’s widow.— My wife received a Letter from Mrs Treadway at Richmond— Her daughter Mrs Crane has lost the fine boy whom she had with her when they visited us in August 1842. I received this day a Letter from Rufus King and 4 others of the State, Clay Central Committee at Albany, New-York, inviting and urging me to write for publication a Letter upon Texas— The Letter received yesterday from W. H. Seward and Morgan, was in aid of this request. Also a Letter from M. M. Fisher of Medway, requesting in behalf of the District and County Committee of the Liberty party of the Eighth Congregational Distric of Massachusetts, a conference with me next Monday, in relation to the nomination of a Candidate to represent the District in the 29th. Congress— And a Letter from George Fuller, administrator de bonis non, with the will annexed of Lieutt. Governor Moses Gill, respecting the 7 Bank shares which I transferred to him by mistake. I wrote on the back of the Deed of the Congregational Society of the Town of Quincy by their Treasurer George W. Beale, to me, of Pew N. 6 in the Stone Temple, an assignment of all my right, title and Estate therein to Benjamin R. Curtis, his heirs and Assigns— Much of the day wasted in ransacking the farm house for old documents and pamphlets.

8. IV: Thursday.  Sun rose 4:59. Set beclouded.  My Son, went to Boston, with his youngest Son, Arthur to consult Dr. Bigelow. His wife and my granddaughter Mary Louisa went with him. They returned home to dine, and Charles brought out the 61st. volume of Niles’s Register, containing page 219. Clement C. Clay’s Letter to the Legislature of the State of Alabama of 12. Novr. 1841. resigning his seat in the Senate of the United States—in which he recommends emphatically the political doctrine of Thomas Jefferson, that the Northern Democracy are the natural allies of the Slaveholders of the South— I have long been desirous of referring to the Letter of Mr Jefferson in which this principle was avowed; an also to an Article in the North-American Review, by Edward Everett commenting upon it— Charles brought out the 4th. Volume of Jefferson’s writings, and the 22d volume of the North American Review where I expected to find these Articles. In my searches this day with Walter Hellen for old documents and pamphlets at the farm-house I found the anonymous pamphlet published by John Forsyth Secretary of State in 1837. entitled “Examination and Review of a pamphlet, printed and secretly circulated by M. E. Gorostiza, late Envoy Extraordinary from Mexico; previous to his departure from the United States; and by him entitled ‘Correspondence between the Legation Extraordinary of Mexico, and the Department of State of the United States, respecting the passage of the Sabine, by the Troops under the command of General Gaines[’”]— I had alread found, a loose copy of the Message of President Van Buren to H.R.U.S. of 26. Feby 1838; containing a copy and translation of Gorostiza’s pamphlet; in answer to a Resolution offered by me, and adopted by the House on the 20th. of February 1838— These two pamphets are indispensably necessary to me, for the preparation of my answer to Mr Whitney. Also the Session Message of 24. Congress 2d. Session 6. December 1836. wherein President Jackson disavows the entry by General Gaines upon the Mexican Territory. Also Messages of 27. April and 4 July 1838. N. 351. 25 Congress 2. Session—especially from p. 765 of the latter.— At page 766. there is a Letter from Genl. Macomb to Gaines of 26. January 1836.—enclosing a Letter of Instructions from the Secretary of War dated 23. January 1836— These were the precise orders upon which Gaines crossed the Sabine and took Post at Nacogdoches—but the Instructions themselves are not there They were communicated to the House in the Message of 14 May 1836. 24. Congress 1. Session. N. 256. in answer to a Resolution of the House of 10. May 1836 on a motion of Edward Everett the day before. The instructions are obscurely worded, and do not give explicit authority to cross the line— That however is given by Letter from the Secretary of War of 25. April 1836. five days after the conference between Forsyth and Gorostiza, when the Mexican Minister was apprized of the intention of Jackson to authorize the invasion of Mexico by Gaines.

9. III.45 Friday.  Sun rose 5. Set 7.10 beclouded  I awake now habitually before the Clock in our entry strikes 3. and cannot sleep again— I lay an hour more or less and rise with the first glimpse of twilight. At this when the sky is clear, I see every night just before going to bed between 10. and 11. the planet Jupiter rise in the North east, about the extremest Northern declination of the Sun; and at half past 3. in the morning. Venus rises nearly at the same point— It seems as if it were the same star night and morning; fixed in the heavens, with unceasing and unfading splendor. I suppose that not one person in a thousand would understand me should I say that this incident has given and continues to give me a transient sensation of pleasure. I resumed the practice of allowing two hours of morning exercise, devoted to my seedling trees. I planted two Washington plum stones in a plat in the Seminary, next the Barn fence, and covered them with an inverted earthen flower pot, bottom broken off. The summer house cellar was choked up with weeds, from 3. to 5. feet high. I plucked and hoed them up; and disclosed 2 seedling shagbark trees, up from last years nuts of the old adjoining tree— Mr G. W. Beale called here, and I acknowledged before him as a Justice of Peace, the Assignment to Benjamin R. Curtis of pew N. 6, in the Stone Temple— Mrs John Adams, and Mrs Cranch, dined at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— Mr and Mrs Erastus Brooks, (Margaret Cranch) and Mrs Lucy Dawes were here this afternoon— Charles and his wife and daughter, this Evening.— This day the Railway from New-York to Boston, by the way of Long Island was first opened, and I note from the Atlas Newspaper the time within which the journey was performed.  Time from Brooklyn South Ferry to Boston, per Passenger Train over the Long-Island Rail-road. Friday 9. August 1844.  Time from South Ferry Brooklyn to Boston 10. hours 9. minutes.  X The train waited 16 minutes for the 4 1/2 Clock Train from Boston for New-York.  Note. The arrival at Boston is noted by New-York time.

10. III.30. Saturday.  Sun rose beclouded.  My morning exercise encroaches already upon my hours for labour, and the search for old documents and pamphlets absorbs time beyond all computation— I worked this morning upon an old Apple tree in the alley between my own and Charles’s house, and which bears Russetton Apples I propose to strip off its parasite ulcers, and loosen the ground about its roots— Mrs Elizabeth (De Windt) Cranch who has been spending a week with us, left us, to go and pass another with Mrs John Angier at Medford, and then return to her father’s house at Cedar grove, Fishkill Landing, on Hudson river— Mary and her daughter Mary Louisa went with her to Boston and returned home to dine— Charles A. Cummings, heretofore a School-teacher, and in 1840 Selectman of Quincy, a fierce democrat called on me this morning with a Revd Mr Goodrich a Minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church to solicit a subscription for building a new church of that denomination in this town— There is already a church of the same denomination near Quincy point— Mr Goodrich belongs to the Providence Conference, and the town of Quincy falls within that jurisdiction. Mr Goodrich was appointed by the Conference to preach here, but the proprietor, of the church or of the pews refused to receive him, and will not permit him to occupy the Church.
