I met there Sophia Quincy who was as much displeased with the picture as I was, and regretted that Mr Alston’s friends had allowed it to be exhibited— From this Hall I went into State Street and walked to the head of long wharf, where I saw the unfinished Custom-house with its multitude of granite pillars— Returning slowly up the Street, I met P. P. F. Degrand, the person of whom I was in search, and requested him to procure for me 30 shares of the stock of the great western rail-road, and to bring them to my Son’s office, which he did in the course of half an hour— I gave him a check for 2692.50 upon the Quincy Stone Bank; which in consideration of my name they consented to take at the Suffolk Bank, and I received the certificate for 30 shares of the Stock— Mr Palfrey the Secretary of the Commonwealth came in to enquire of my son to enquire if he could recommend as an agent for the protection of coloured free citizens of Massachusetts—in the Southern States— I called at the houses of Robert C. Winthrop, judge John and Isaac P. Davis; neither of them at home. Dined at Dr. Frothingham’s. At Mr James H. Foster at 5. Waited an hour for James. Home with Louisa C. Smith at 7. and found my wife confined to her chamber unwell

6. IV:20. Friday.  Sun rose 5:30. Set 6:28.  Continuation of cloudless sky the whole of last Night and of this day. Morning exercise renewed. But Fahrenheit was at 40. and the morning before breakfast too cold for writing; the consequence of which was that I merely retrieved the loss of nearly a day in this diary, and that my task slumbers. I answered a Letter from Mr Frye, enclosing one from Joseph Pilling offering me 5000 dollars for my house in Pennsylvania avenue at Washington— I am not willing to sell it for less than 6000, and so express to Mr Frye— My wife was yet confined the whole of this day to her chamber and Mary rode out yesterday the first time since her illness. I barely looked into the volume of the Library of useful knowledge containing an account of Lord Bacon’s Novum organum scientiarum or new method of studying the Sciences in two parts—said to have been written by Lord Brougham—but I made progress in the history of the reign of Henry the 7th.— I find this reading very agreeable, and am quite delighted with the Style; which must be considerably modified, at least for the spelling.— In the very first page he says of Richard the 3d that he was “a Prince in military virtue approved, jealous of the honour of the English Nation, and likewise a good lawmaker for the ease and solace of the common people.”— There are numerous examples of pregnant antithesis and synonimous nest eggs, and curious similitudes— The people made heartier demonstrations of joy on the day of his marriage with the white rose, Elizabeth of York, than on the day of his entry, or of his coronation “which the king rather noted than liked.”— “that it was not the first blow that made the war invasive, for that no wise Prince would stay for, but the first provocation, or at least the first preparation.”— “Pretext is never wanting to power.”— “Arguments are ever with multitudes too weak for suspicions.” “This Court (Star chamber) is one of the sagest, and noblest institutions of this kingdom.” In Yorkshire [“]the memory of King Richard was so strong that it lay like lees in the bottom of men’s hearts; and if the vessel was but stirred, it would come up.”— [“]In my judgment it is some defect even in the best writers of history, that they do not often enough summarily deliver and set down the most memorable laws that passed in the times whereof they writ, being indeed the principal acts of peace.—” The book is full of such striking passages, but I have no time or space to record them.— This afternoon I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s and delivered to her a Letter from her Son, Isaac Hull, engaged on the survey of the North-eastern boundary.— She spoke of the Pic-Nic yesterday as having been very numerous. The universalist minister, Mr Davis, speechified. Returning home I stop’d and spent an hour with Mr Charles— He himself and Walter Hellen returned this evening from their excursion to Woods’s hole and Nantucket

7. IV:15. Saturday.  Sun rose 5:31. Set 6:26.  Sowed a row of Button pear seeds from the tree next the dwarf apple, immediately behind the tool shed in the garden—grass mowed in the front yard and seminary.— Mrs Treadway returned before dinner from her visit to Medford and Boston— In the Stage with her came a young man named Noble Butler, of Louisville Kentucky, a student of divinity at the theological school at Cambridge; who came merely to see me, and to ask of me an autograph to send to his wife. I invited him to dine with us; but he was engaged to take the return Stage to Boston at half past two, and declined. After dinner, Mr James M. Shute, a Stereotype plate maker came from Boston with Letters from Jonathan Elliot, and B. B. French, the chief Sub-clerk in the office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States. Elliot proposes to purchase the plates for a Stereotype Edition of his Debates in the State conventions, on the Constitution of the United States, in five volumes. And orders 200 copies to be struck off, to be delivered to members of Congress on or before the first of March next at 15 dollars a set—a third edition; the preceding editions having been in four volumes. On receiving these proposals Mr Shute applied to Robert C. Winthrop, to enquire of Elliot’s credit and Mr Winthrop referred him to B. B. French whose answer Mr Shute read to me. French refers to a Resolution of H.R.U.S. adopted on the 14th. of June last, involving, he says, an expense of one hundred thousand dollars; directing the Clerk of the House to furnish the members of the 28th. Congress, each a set of the documents already furnished to the members of the 26th. and 27th. Congresses, which French says includes Elliot’s debates—but no appropriation was made to pay for the books, and a proviso is contained in the Resolution that it shall not authorise a reprint of the books— I recurred to the Journal of the House which I have in sheets, and found the Resolution which was offered by R. C. Winthrop, and carried through by the previous question twice over against the opposition of Cave Johnson, by yeas and nays, first to lay on the table 64 to 111. and last to reconsider the vote for the Resolution 67 to 105— French says the Clerk (M’Nulty) refuses to execute the Resolution, and I advised Mr Shute that as the reprint and the order for 200 copies for the members are directly in the face of the Resolution, he should have nothing to do with it— And as the Resolution was offered and carried by Mr Winthrop, I recommended a second visit to him: that he should tell him my opinions on the subject, and conclude for his conduct, upon Winthrop’s final advice— I received from President Quincy the work of Joutel in French and English from the University library—from George Bancroft a flattering Letter, and from W. J. Taylor and John H. Pleasants—Richmond a strange one.

8. IV.15. Sunday.  Sun rose 5.32. Set. 6:25  Mr Stetson the Minister of the old congregational church at Medford preached for Mr Lunt this morning from Galatians 6.5. “For every man shall bear his own burden” This epistle to the Galatians is a controversial argument against the practice of circumcision, and generally to set aside the ritual obligations of the Law—meaning the Levitical Law— Jesus had not explicitly abrogated that Law— But he had commanded his apostles to preach his gospel to all Nations, baptising them in the name of the father and of the son, and of the holy ghost, and had promised to be with them till the end of the world— Baptism was thus tacitly but not explicitly substituted for circumcision. The converted Jews however still adhered to that bloody rite— From the narrative in the Acts it appears that at first both Peter and Paul preached the gospel indiscriminately to the Jews and Gentiles— Peter was by a miraculous vision was absolved from the Law as to lawful and unlawful meats; but he still adhered to circumcision. It was at Corinth that Paul after his return and that of Silas and Timothy from Macedonia, reasoning in the synagogue to Jews and Greeks, when the Jews opposed themselves and blasphemed—shook his raiment and said unto them, Your blood be upon your own heads: I am clean: from henceforth I will go unto the Gentiles—and the same night in a vision he was recommissioned, with a promise from the Lord that he would be with him, and no man should set on him to hurt him (Acts 18.5–10) In this Epistle to the Galatians 2.7. he says “the gospel of the uncircumcision was committed unto me, as the gospel of the circumcision was unto Peter”—and they quarreled—and Paul says he withstood Peter to the face, because he was to be blamed— And this axiom that every man shall bear his own burden is part of Paul’s argument. Mr Stetson and his son dined with us, and his afternoon text was from Matthew 16.24 “Let him deny himself.” The whole verse being “Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.” The discourse was upon self denial, which he defined somewhat metaphysically, observing that self-denial implied a double nature in man one craving and the other refusing the same thing. He descanted also largely upon the soul—its immortality, its solitude, its condition in futurity— I read also a Sermon of Orville Dewey upon Retribution, recommended to me by Mrs Charles— After the service this afternoon I went with Louisa C. Smith, Mrs Treadway, and Mrs Charles, and visited Mrs Josiah Quincy, her daughter Abigail, and the two Misses Ruthven. Mrs Waterston was confined by illness to her chamber and could not see us. Mrs Quincy had given me a note from her husband this morning inviting me to pass two or three days with them at Cambridge this week or the next, and I promised to go, a week from next Wednesday.

9. III 40. Monday.  Sun rose 5.33— Set 6:23.  Charles’s youngest Son, Arthur has been for some weeks in drooping health, but I met him Saturday towards evening, on the hill, with his nurse Rebecca—yesterday afternoon the scarlet fever struck out upon him, to our great alarm, though with favourable symptoms.— This morning early, Charles took his eldest son, John Quincy to Boston, to place him at the town Latin School. Mr Crane, and Walter Hellen, went also to Boston intending to visit Medford and mount Auburn, but found time only for a pilgrimage to the Bunker hill Monument at Charlestown. To the top of this they ascended with the help of a steam engine. Walter Hellen returned alone about 8 O’Clock this evening; but Charles and Mr Crane stayed to attend a Meeting of the young men’s whig club, and got back shortly before midnight— Mr Daniel Baxter came with his Deed ready drawn of the 15 Acre woodlot on Pine hill, interlocked between two lots of mine but he was not fully provided with his title— In 1829. it was purchased by Lemuel Bracket, and in November of that year was surveyed by Lemuel Humphrey for him. in 1832. it was after cutting off all the wood upon it, sold by Bracket to Caleb and Livingston White and in 1837. Caleb conveyed his part to Livingston White—who now conveys to Daniel Baxter. But he had with him only the deed from Bracket to the Whites and the bounds in his deed to me were not properly described. So I told him he must produce all the evidences of his title, and amend the description of the bounds, which he undertook to do— After dinner a person whom I took to be a clergyman came with a friend of his, named Elisha Hale settled in one of the North-western States—his own named is Cozzens—but I find not this name in the list of Clergymen of Boston in the Massachusetts Register— They came merely on a visit of curiosity, and stayed but a few minutes— I finished reading Lord Bacon’s History of the Reign of Henry the 7th. which has been a delicious treat. There is an imitation of the style of Tacitus in the narrative, and an interweaving of moral reflection with the series of events, extremely pleasant.— The story of Peter Osbeck son of a converted Jew of Tournay, historically known by the name of Perkin Warbeck is marvellous. “Nay, himself, with long and continual counterfeiting, and with often telling a lye, was turned by habit almost into the thing he seemed to be; and from a liar to a believer.”— The notice of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus, and the expedition of Sebastian Cabot, or as Bacon calls him Gaboto, are among the remarkable passages in this work— Another is the melancholy fortunes and fate of Edward Earl of Warwick, son of Edward the 4th. brother Clarence— The character of Henry himself at the close of the book is drawn with a master’s hand, but with a Courtier’s spirit, smoothing over the truth with flattery.

properties.dateline: Quincy Tuesday 10. September 1844. Cohasset. Hingham. Quincy
properties.text: 10. IV. Tuesday.  Sun rose 5:34. Set 6.21.  After breakfasting about Sunrise; with my son, Adoniram Judson Crane, and Walter Hellen, I went in the Barouche, first to Mr Loring’s house at Hingham, whence without alighting we proceeded to Cohasset on a fishing party— Not to our usual place of departure the Cold Spring, but to a new building, erected since our last Summer’s party; and called the Atlantic House—close upon the end of Nantasket Beach. A larger and more convenient lodge for dining a party than the one at the Spring. Before we left home, Mr Nathaniel Curtis came in from Roxbury and kept company with us. Between the Atlantic house and the beach we met Mr Allen the young clergyman whose ordination to the pastoral charge of the Church at Jamaica Plains I attended last October— He was here in company with several Ladies of his parish. There were besides our company several gentlemen from Hingham and Cohasset, with Mr Loring and the Revd. Charles Brooks— There was a small sloop at anchor near the beach which with Mr Crane, Mr Brooks, the Revd. Dr John Brazer of Salem, Mr Curtis, a young man named Nathan Lincoln, and two or three others, we reached by a small leaky boat from the beach, and in which we sailed in quest of fishing grounds from 10. A.M to nearly 2. P.M. The Captain and owner of the Sloop took us successively to all the favourite fishing grounds, but without success at any one of them— The sky had been occasionally covered with thin transitory clouds. Soon after we sailed the Sun came out with intense heat and a dead calm for about an hour, when an eastern breeze came up and thenceforth we were comfortably cool— We had a very pleasant sail; but upon four several removes found not fish enough to make sport. We caught less than a dozen chiefly small rock cod— Mr Brazer very soon tired, and when the breeze came up qualmish, and impatient and quite importunate to return to the shore— To please him we returned before 2. and found a the Atlantic house several other gentlemen, accessions to the party— A temperance dinner of chowder and fried perch was soon over, with coffee for claret and lemonade for Madeira— After dinner Mr Nathan Lincoln sung two Sea Songs Soon after, Mr Curtis took leave and returned home— At 4. we left the Atlantic house and came to Mr Loring’s house at Hingham. Charles, anxious for his Son Arthur, and Mr Crane afflicted with a fit of asthma, returned immediately to Quincy and sent back Benjamin with the barouche for Walter Hellen and me. We had an evening party of Ladies and Gentlemen at Mr Loring’s in conversation chiefly with me, till the sound of the 9 O’Clock bell started us, and we took leave of the company and came back to our home at Quincy—where we landed just before ten O’Clock, rejoiced to learn that the symptoms of the child Arthur’s disease are favourable.

11. IV. Wednesday.  My morning exercise is now confined to sowing seeds of Apples, Button pears, and horse plums. I sowed this morning a row of Pear seeds, plum stones and seeds of Apples from the young summer house apple tree, in the summer house cellar. Daniel Baxter came with his Deed of the Pine hill lot, and Lemuel Humphrey’s plan of it, making it 15 Acres 1. Rood and 25 Rods, for all which he had charged— There was also yet missing the deed from Caleb to Livingston White, and I told him as all those Lots were originally sold by the town for 15 acres each— I could not take the lot for more. And I thought it probable that, Mr Humphrey’s plan encroached upon my two adjoining lots. I said also that Harvey Field had told me the price of the lot was 495 dollars. he went and soon returned with Caleb White’s deed to Livingston, dated in 1837 and recorded— His own deed to me was made conformable to that from Bracket to the Whites and the consideration for 15 acres only—495 dollars.— I took his deed and the plan, and gave him a check on the stone bank for that sum— This lot, with the three others adjoining it, and the lawyer’s common form are aggregate of 108 acres of woodland all contiguous.— Mr Lunt paid me a morning visit, and said there was to be an ordination, next Wednesday at Chelsea of a young man by the name of Rice, to which our church is invited, and he inquired if I should be willing to accompany him as a delegate— I told him that I was engaged to go to Cambridge on that day to pass the Night at President Quincy’s; but I should not be obliged to go till late in the day, and supposed I could attend the ordination and go afterwards to Cambridge— But there was one suggestion for his consideration rather than mine which had perhaps not occurred to him— I had twice within the last two years attended him as a delegate at Ordinations— Might there not be other members of the church, who would incline to have their turn to partake of these offices, and might think I was engrossing more than my share? He said the idea had never occurred to him— I said he might take time to think of it and I would go with him or give place to another according as he should conclude— I was engaged at least two hours of this morning in examining my Diary, commencing with October 1818, to make extracts of all the notices of the Negotiation of the Florida Treaty with the Spanish Minister Onis. I marked a number of passages which I requested Walter Hellen to copy for me; which he readily promised to do— I proceed in the reading of Bacon’s Works— The Reign of Henry the 7th. is followed by two fragments. One a single page, commencing the History of the reign of King Henry the 8th. The other three pages of the beginning of the History of Great-Britain. Then come Theological works— Then a confession of Faith— Then a confession of Faith by Lord Verulam, and four Prayers by Lord Chancellor Bacon &c.

12. IV. Thursday.  Two hours of labour exercise in the garden and seminary— This morning our family visitors from Richmond Virginia, Mrs Susan B Treadway eldest daughter of my long since deceased brother Charles—her daughter Mrs Susan Crane with her husband Adoniram Judson Crane, and their infant Son Joseph Mayo Crane, and his mulatto nurse Julia, left us to return home. They have been with us since theof last Month They have within the last year lost two children, a girl and a boy—the latter being the child with whom the two ladies visited us at Washington in August 1842. The boy now with them has since that time been born and is now about seven months old— Mr Crane is sorely afflicted with the asthma; fits of which he has been suffering almost the whole time that he has been here.— I gave Mr Crane at parting, my three Eulogies, upon Monroe, La Fayette and Madison— The Oration at Newbury-Port— The address of 17. Septr. 1842 to my Constituents at Braintree—the Lecture ofNovember 1842 at Providence, and the Speech of 15 April 1843. at Washington in reply to Wise and C. J. Ingersoll— I asked him also to procure for me if he can a file of the Richmond Enquirer for the year 1818. and a copy of the pamphlet review by professor Dew of the debate in the Legislature of Virginia in 1832. upon a motion for the abolition of Slavery in that State— Mr Carruth and Mr Gilmore are the agents for the company who have obtained a charter for opening a railway from Boston to Plymouth. They have concluded to make the road pass within 20 feet East of my easternmost barn; there to cross the county road and cut diagonally through my lot in front of my house; utterly ruining the finest lot for dwelling houses in the whole town—exposing my barns and houses to the most imminent danger of fire; and sinking to a dead loss my interest in the Neponset Bridge— They talked about an estimate valuation of D. Greenleaf’s land adjoining mine at 100 dollars an acre— I thought it best to have no altercation with them, and referred them entirely to my Son— I took Letters to the Post Office, and called twice at Charles’s—once before dinner, and again at Sunset. Took tea there with my wife who has been most of these last four days there with the child Arthur who has the scarlet fever severely but with favourable symptoms. We came home in the Carryall, and I found at home a young man named Hutchinson from Milton, with a pompous personage from Vermont named Arunah Spear, who came to make enquiry, if I had in my possession certain papers documentary, being a declaration of a man by the name of Allen in Braintree in 1818 said to have been made before Thomas Adams. Allen died within a week of making the declaration; and it is believed that the papers never were sent to Washington but remained in the hands of Mr Thomas Adams and passed into mine. I told him I had none of my brothers official papers— Mr Gourgas or Mrs T. B. Adams might have them.

13. IV. Friday.  Morning hours absorbed in digging round the seedling tree patches in the seminary— Sowing button pear seeds dwarf apple seeds and horse plum stones in a row behind the tool shed—staked with twigs sawed off from a wild cherry tree— There are nine shagbark seedlings, two peach trees, and two pears now there, sown last October, some of which I may hope will survive the approaching winter. five shagbarks in the pumice patch over the fence and one peach— I dug a hole in one corner of it; and emptied into it a basket of rotten button pears and woodhouse apples— In the summer house cellar there are also two shagbark seedlings of last year, and one in the alley next the road— I examined my Diary for November and December 1818. and marked large extracts to be copied— General H. A. S. Dearborn came from Roxbury and delivered to me a Letter from himself, Samuel H. Walley junr. Joseph W. Tucker, and Francis Hilliard—Committee of invitation of the whigs of Roxbury, requesting me to attend at a great meeting of the whigs of Norfolk County, and to address them next Wednesday the 18th. the day before the great mass meeting of the 19th on the Boston Common. I desired the General to return my thanks to the Committee for the honour of the invitation; and to express my regret that the necessity of refraining from attendance at any public meeting having reference to the Presidential election would deprive me of the opportunity of complying with their request. I explained to him my reasons for this forbearance, which he said were perfectly satisfactory, and he agreed with me that this verbal answer, would render a written one unnecessary. Mr Ibrahim Bartlet brought me a manuscript volume of 228 folio pages carefully sowed up in a cotton covering, for me to read and give my opinion upon it. Mr Bartlet reminded me that he had brought me last year the same manuscript for the same purpose; but I had not then time to examine it— I do not remember, nor does Mr Bartlet know who the author of the manuscript is.— After dinner, doctor Edward Jarvis, brought me a Letter of introduction, from Mr Samuel P. Loud of Dorchester where he resides— His wife was with him, and is quite a handsome, well educated and personally accomplished woman— The Doctor was one of the signers of a memorial to H.RU.S. from the American statistical association detecting and exposing the blunders of the Census of 1840.—the Treatment of which by the house and the Committee on Statistics I told him. He said the Society would address another memorial to Congress at their next Session, on the errors of the Census respecting Education, and the returns of schools— I advised him to send the memorial early in the Session within the first 30 days and promised to present it— I was not able to make an addition of more than half a page to my daily task—which needs the spur.

14. V. Saturday.  Mr Thomas H. Perry, a professor in the navy of the United States called on me this morning from South Abington, his native place and where he is now upon furlough. He has visited me before— Last fall here, and after the close of the late Session of Congress at Washington— He has a taste for astronomical studies and is desirous of being stationed at the new Washington Observatory— He says he made known this desire to the Secretary of War, who promised him that he should be provided for, but said that no appointments for the observatory would be made, till the bills shall be finished.— Mr Perry said there had been some recommendation to put the Observatory in charge of a Post-Captain in the Navy; which would just be an extinguisher over the whole concern—for there was not a Post-Captain in the Navy who knew how to take an Astronomical Observation, the art of which was only to be acquired by practice; as he himself had ascertained by being admitted to observe by the astronomer at the British observatory at the Cape of Good Hope— I went to Roxbury, and dined at Mr Henry Codman’s with the Trustees of the Massachusetts agricultural Society— My Father was once President of that Society, but I have never been a member of it.— There are 12 Trustees, and they hold a meeting once a month and dine together alternately at each other’s houses— I met there John Welles now in his 80th. year, and President of the Society—Peter C. Brooks my Compere—3 or 4 months my senior, and of younger men Abbott Lawrence, Benjamin Guild, two Lowell’s, John C. Gray, a son of my old Classmate Samuel Putnam, Doctor John C. Warren, Doctor Vinton, an Episcopal Clergyman, and Theophilus Parsons.— Almost all these are sons of old deceased cotemporaries and friends of mine— Henry Codman is a son of Stephen Codman yet living. Mrs Codman is the only daughter of John Amory, the eldest brother of the two families of Amory with whom I was intimate in my youth. Mr Welles has recently lost his wife and in apologizing to me for not having visited me since my return from Washington; as the thought of his bereavement came to mind was overcome even to tears.— He cheered up however immediately, and was afterwards pleasant and social as I have ever known him. These dinner parties of the Trustees of the agricultural Society to which I am occasionally invited bring up a mingled memorial of three several stages of my life, all studded with affecting reminisces— My early youth from 1790 to 1794— My return from Europe and residence at Boston from 1801 to 1809. And my last return from England in 1817. while both my venerated parents were yet on earth— I left Mr Codman’s table before 6. and reached home before 7. My wife had passed the day at Charles’s house and come home unwell. Charles spent the Evening here. His son Arthur still suffers with the scarlet fever.

15. IV:15. Sunday.  Sun rose beclouded— Set clear  The weather continues excessively dry, with this day a return of Summer heat— My Son’s children Louisa Catherine and John Quincy, who came in yesterday from Boston are with us to keep them away, from Arthur who is yet going through the scarlet fever; still with favourable symptoms— The eruption passing off and the sore throat abated— My wife came home yesterday afternoon from Charles’s house, sick; had a bad night and has been all this day confined to her bed.— The effect of the heat upon my nervous system to disable me for writing is appaling, and irremediable. Mr Lunt preached at home—this morning from Joel. 2.13. “Rend your heart and not your Garments.” The discourse commenced, with an historical account of the different usages among the antient Jews of manifesting their afflictions, by personal acts of violence—by clothing themselves in sackloth, rolling their bodies in ashes, prostrations—scarifying their faces, and among other things rending their garments— He then adduced numerous citations from both the old and new Testament to shew that these practices were disapproved by God, and repeatedly and severely censured by Jesus Christ— He quoted especially the passage in Micah 6.7. and the frequent warnings of Jesus against the hypocritical fasts and ostentatious slovenly manners of the Pharisees— The emphatic precepts in all parts of the Bible against observances merely of form cannot escape the notice of every enquirer after truth. And from the earnest exhortation to despise and discard all such delusive pretensions to sanctity the argument naturally slided into a glowing commendation of pure Christian humility— This book of Joel consisting only of three short chapters, is at the first aspect an outburst of lamentation at the calamity of a land devoured by worms and caterpillars— The canker worm the palmer-worm and the Caterpillar.— These I suppose were metaphorical figures denoting the Babylonian conquerors. All these pictures by the prophets of the dreadful judgment of God in the captivity, are of what Benjamin West used to call the terribly sublime— Mr Lunt’s afternoon text was from Psalm 67.4. [“]O let the nations be glad and sing for joy: for thou shalt judge the people righteously, and govern the Nations upon Earth.” I read also two of the Sermons of Orville Dewey. The 13th. in the volume, being the second upon future retribution—and the first in the volume—upon human nature— My Sons wife has been frightened by the Sermons on retribution— They are of the rigid and gloomy school of theology. Such doctrines, if they cannot breed a hell in the next world, at least make one in this— I have no faith in them—and very little in their author— The Sermon upon humann nature is better, and yet does not entirely satisfactory to my mind.

16. IV:30. Monday.  Sun rose, beclouded  By way of variety I took up the public Documents respecting the negotiation of the Florida Treaty, and especially the correspondence of George W. Erving in 1817 and 18— The supplementary Documents, called for by the Resolution of H.R.U.S. moved by Dixon H. Lewis, are the most perfect extinguishers of Andrew Jackson’s lies, and Erving’s own base misrepresentations that could be produced.— Jackson’s lies are gross and glaring— Erving’s misrepresentations, are artful and cunning— Jackson’s type is Richard the third— Erving is an honest Iago— There is no baser conspiracy recorded in history than theirs against me which it is my duty to expose to the world. Mr Billings came to enquire about the pension claim of his grandmother Lydia Faxon—married a few days after the limitation of 1. Jany 1794. I told him that a great effort had been made at the recent session of Congress to repeal the limitation altogether—but it had failed.— The attempt may be renewed next winter— Mr Cheseborough is a minister of the gospel, settled at Chester in the state of Connecticut; and came with his brother in Law, George H. Chapman, a merchant of Boston, and his brother Robert Chapman, a boy of 15. to enquire if in the old Book of Records of the town of Braintree there is found the name of his lineal ancestor William Cheseborough— He found the name—but there is one paper among the title deeds to the Mount Wollaston Estate, in which Cheseborough was a party, for which I searched, but could not find it.— Upon the earliest list of births Mr Cheseborough found several instances of the name of Sheffield which he said was the name of his mother, and he concluded she was also a descendant from the patriarchal Braintree family. Mr and Mrs Stockton, Mary M’Knight and Miss Ann Twiggs came out and visited us from Boston this afternoon— My wife continues much indisposed and was confined almost the whole of this day to her bed— My Grandson John Quincy went into Boston early to attend the Latin School— My Son was here before dinner, in search of John C. Calhoun’s address to his party friends last January, withdrawing his name as a competitor for nomination at the Democratic convention then to be held at Baltimore the last week in May for the candidate of the party for the Presidency of the United States— I found it for him in the Globe of 5. February last— He went this evening to a whig Meeting at North Bridgewater— This evening I traced in Middleton’s Celestial Atlas, and by inspection of the sky, all the principal stars in the constellation of Draco, which I had never before ascertained.

17. III.45. Tuesday.  Mr Loring called here this morning with Mr Hudson a portrait painter residing at Hingham and desirous of painting a picture of me— I gave him accordingly a sitting of an hour and a half, and he dined with us. I could not keep my eyes open half the time while I was sitting— Mr Loring brought us a basket of Seek no further apples—and proceeded to Boston. I had received a note from Robert C. Winthrop inviting me to dine with him, with Mr and Mrs Grinnell who are coming from New-Bedford to spend some days with him— Mr Loring took my answer to his note declining the invitation to dine, being engaged to go to Chelsea, but promising to call on him to-morrow morning. Mr George Newcomb came to enquire about the case of the Schooner Rosanna, a claim in Congress. I told him I believed there had been a report from a Committee of the House favourable to the claim and perhaps a bill reported; but which had not passed, or had failed in the Senate— I said I would call it up again at the next Session. Mr Newcomb asked me if I could furnish him with copies of my speeches, and addresses relating to the right of petition and to Texas, to which I had referred in my recent Letter to Miss Thaxter, at the Hingham celebration of 2. August last— He said he had usually voted with the democratic party here; but there were two things upon which he could not go with them. One was their suppression of the right of petition—and the other was their setting up James K. Polk as President of the United States— I gave him copies of my speech of 25. May 1836. on the rations—of that of May 1840. on the smuggling the Address at Braintree of 17. September 1842. Of my Speech of April 1843. upon War with Mexico and England, and of my Lecture at Providence on the right of suffrage— Messrs. Robbins, Brigham, Guild and Maguire, came as a Committee from the whig convention of the 8th. Congressional District, held at Dedham last Tuesday to fix on a Candidate for election as Representative of the District in the 29th. Congress, to announce to me that I had been unanimously nominated by the Convention for that Office, and that the Convention had thought proper not only to nominate me but to appoint them a special Committee to inform me of it in person.— I thanked them, and the Convention for the honour they had done me; and although my age and infirmities had led me to hesitate whether I should prove sufficient to discharge all the duties of the office, I must hope for improved health and in the crisis impending over the country, accepted the nomination. Henry Wilson of Natick was also one of the Committee to notify me of my nomination, but did not come with the rest. The Convention passed sundry resolutions honorary to me, a Resolution approving the whig nomination for President, and a resolution condemnatory of Polk and Dallas.

properties.dateline: Quincy. Boston Wednesday 18. September 1844. Chelsea— Quincy—
properties.text: 18. IV. Wednesday.  I went first into Boston this morning with Mr Lunt and alighted at Mr Robert C. Winthrop’s house. I sent Benjamin with the Barouche to land Mr Lunt at judge Warren’s house in Beacon Street to take him up there again at one O’Clock, and then call for me at my Son’s and A. C. Spooners Office N. 23. Court Street. I told Mr Winthrop that I had called on him to speak of George W. Erving and Andrew Jackson, and Charles J. Ingersoll’s concerted attack upon me during the last Session of Congress, and particularly upon Erving’s written communications to Jackson against me. Erving had spoken to me about it during the Session— He then read to me part of a Letter which Erving had written to him on the subject— And he now read me part of another received by the last Steamer, and written after Erving had received Charles J. Ingersoll’s counterfeit report published as the report of the Committee of foreign affairs dated 1. May 1844— Erving’s Letter now is apologetic towards me; but tenfold bitter and rancorous to the memory of Mr Monroe; and mean and sneaking in his excuses for his wanton attack upon me— I asked Winthrop if Charles J. Ingersoll’s view contains Erving’s paper or a garbled and summary statement of it made up by Ingersoll himself.— Winthrop said he thought it was Erving’s own paper— But I read from it several passages evidently shewing that it is not. While we were in conversation John C. Gray came in and having apparently business with Winthrop, I left them— Called at the Office of the morning Chronicle and Emancipator and enquired of Mr Leavitt if they had any pamphlet copies of my Letter of 4. July 1843 to the Bangor Committee. Mr Alden said he believed he had some at his house, and if he had he would send them to me. I enquired also if M. M. Fisher had received my answer to his Letter. He said he had— At one O’Clock I found A. C. Spooner at his office, just returned from a four months excursion to Europe— Mr Lunt came in the Barouche— We went over Winnisimmet ferry to Chelsea, and thence to the town Hall two miles distant from the landing— It was half past two when the Council met. Dr Flint of Salem Moderator. Mr Waterston Scribe. After the usual preliminaries we walked to the Meeting house and the Revd. George M. Rice was ordained Pastor of the Church— The Sun went down upon the ceremonies. We partook of a Collation at the town Hall, and then with Mr Lunt I recrossed the Winisimmet ferry, and after taking Mr Lunt home I returned to my own at Quincy.

19. IV. Thursday.  At the ordination, or rather installation yesterday of the Revd. George M Rice, as Pastor of the first Congregational Church and Society in Chelsea, the ceremonies were as follows. 1. Anthem. 2. Introductory prayer by Revd John T. Sargent of Boston. 3. Selections from the Scriptures by Revd John Pierpont junr of Lynn 4. Hymn 5. Sermon by Revd. William P. Lunt of Quincy. 6. Hymn. 7. Prayer of Installation, by Revd. Samuel Barrett of Boston. 8. Charge by Revd. Dr James Flint of Salem 9. Right Hand of fellowship, by Revd. Samuel D. Robbins of Chelsea 10. Address to the People by Revd Robert C. Waterston of Boston 11. Concluding prayer by Revd Frederick T. Gray of Boston 12. Doxology. 13. Benediction by the Pastor George M. Rice— Mr Lunt’s Sermon was from Philippians 3.9.—“the righteousness which is of God by Faith.” All the services were appropriate and creditable— This form of ordaining a minister of the gospel to the charge of a single church is pre-eminently popular and republican— And contrasts most advantageously with the forms of episcopal ordination In these there are two things insupportable, and blasphemous. 1. The pretension of the bishop to confer the holy ghost and 2. the power of pardoning a retaining sin at his discretion. These are the most servile and obsequious vicious practices retained from the church of Rome— Our churches are independent of each other. Associated as brethren— Their pastors are all equal—elected by their people without hierarchy of Bishop Priest and Deacon; without the ridiculous pretension of receiving from the afflatus of the Bishop either the holy ghost or the discretionary power to forgive or to retain sins.— The introductory, ordination, and concluding prayers each by a separate brother pastor— The Anthem, Hymns and Doxology— The Sermon— Charge, Right hand of fellowship and Address to the People, are all congenial parts of one ceremony—all solemnizing incidents of reciprocal duties contracted by the incipient relations between the Pastor and his flock— These services were all well performed on this occasion.— This day was the great Mass Meeting of the whigs at Boston, at which I was invited to preside but declined— Daniel Webster presided and delivered a Speech of an hour and a half— My Son, who is President of the young Men’s whig club went into Boston with Walter Hellen, and my two Granddaughters to see the show.— Mr Hudson the Portrait Painter came and took a sitting of an hour.— The next is to be next Monday— I went up the hill, and saw the sun set from the North-western chamber of Charles’s house— I saw his wife, and her boy Arthur, the glands of whose neck are badly swollen after they had flattered themselves that the scarlet fever had entirely passed off.— Walter and the two girls returned home about 7 this Evening. Charles stays in Boston over night— My wife still keeps her chamber.

20. IV:20. Friday. Sun rose 5:  I planted a row of the largest woodhouse apples, six, as many button pears, 6 horse plum stones and one peach stone between two rows of seedling shagbarks behind the tool shed in the garden, placing them all in a bed of dry manure, and staking out the row with two twigs from a wild cherry tree. I had morning visits from Mr Hubbard Hancock of Stow, Vermont, I take it for granted a whig, though he did not say so— Then the Revd. George Allen of Worceter, and his son George Allen junr. of Boston. This Gentleman (the father is one of the finest political writers in this Commonweal), and on the Masonic controversy, the right of petition, and the projected robbery of Mexico, has written and published papers for comprehension of the subjects, soundness of principle, and elegance of composition unsurpassed if not unequalled. I have had some occasional correspondence with him since 1833. but have never seen him till this day— One of the objects of his visit was to enquire if in the old Record Book of Births, Marriages and Deaths in Braintree the name of Allen appeared, about a century and a half back. I got the book, and we found four or five of the name, between 1680. and 1720.— I lent him the book on his promise to return it. Soon after 4 this afternoon I went with my Son into Boston and at his office, executed and acknowledged for my part as one of the Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston, before A. C Spooner, the deed in fee of the old house in School Street of Boylston Estate, to Lucius Manlius Sargent of Roxbury for 29500 dollars. I then left my son there and came out to Cambridge on a visit to President Quincy at his invitation, and that of his family; with them I passed a pleasant evening enlivened by the company of several of the professors and other officers of the University— Among them Messrs. Beck, Felton and Bond. The conversation was various, literary, not very scientific, occasionally political, but not controversial and throughout cheerful and good humoured— The only drawback to me, was the continual call upon me for talk, leading me to engross a very disproportionate part of the conversation to myself; an impulse to vanity and self conceit— Towards 11. O’Clock, the company retired— I asked for a lamp and a friction match for the morning, and was shewn by Mr Quincy to my bed chamber.

20. IV:20. Friday. Sun rose 5:  I planted a row of the largest woodhouse apples, six, as many button pears, 6 horse plum stones and one peach stone between two rows of seedling shagbarks behind the tool shed in the garden, placing them all in a bed of dry manure, and staking out the row with two twigs from a wild cherry tree. I had morning visits from Mr Hubbard Hancock of Stow, Vermont, I take it for granted a whig, though he did not say so— Then the Revd. George Allen of Worceter, and his son George Allen junr. of Boston. This Gentleman (the father is one of the finest political writers in this Commonweal), and on the Masonic controversy, the right of petition, and the projected robbery of Mexico, has written and published papers for comprehension of the subjects, soundness of principle, and elegance of composition unsurpassed if not unequalled. I have had some occasional correspondence with him since 1833. but have never seen him till this day— One of the objects of his visit was to enquire if in the old Record Book of Births, Marriages and Deaths in Braintree the name of Allen appeared, about a century and a half back. I got the book, and we found four or five of the name, between 1680. and 1720.— I lent him the book on his promise to return it. Soon after 4 this afternoon I went with my Son into Boston and at his office, executed and acknowledged for my part as one of the Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston, before A. C Spooner, the deed in fee of the old house in School Street of Boylston Estate, to Lucius Manlius Sargent of Roxbury for 29500 dollars. I then left my son there and came out to Cambridge on a visit to President Quincy at his invitation, and that of his family; with them I passed a pleasant evening enlivened by the company of several of the professors and other officers of the University— Among them Messrs. Beck, Felton and Bond. The conversation was various, literary, not very scientific, occasionally political, but not controversial and throughout cheerful and good humoured— The only drawback to me, was the continual call upon me for talk, leading me to engross a very disproportionate part of the conversation to myself; an impulse to vanity and self conceit— Towards 11. O’Clock, the company retired— I asked for a lamp and a friction match for the morning, and was shewn by Mr Quincy to my bed chamber.

21. IV. Saturday.— Equinox  After a sound nights sleep I awoke just in time to hear the town clock and a clock in the house strike 4— I soon rose, lighted the lamp with a friction match, and after an hour for dressing sat down and wrote the journal of yesterday; which just brought me to the breakfast hour of the family— The hour of morning prayer at the University is as when I was there 6. preceded by two bells— Immediately after breakfast, I visited with President Quincy the University Library, in the new building of gothic Architecture, solid granite and fire proof, erected upon the princely bequest of Christopher Gore. The librarian is Thaddaeus William Harris, a son of my lately deceased friend and Classmate, who had at one period of his life from 1791. to 1793. also held that office— The library is well assorted and arranged in this building in suitable alcoves; with the names of the donors over the respective alcoves containing the books given by them— The name of Adams is over one of the Alcoves, which contains the books given by my father and by me whether all of them or not they do not know; for they have no catalogue of either set. Mr Harris asked me if I could furnish lists. Mr Quincy has asked me more than once the same question— He has noticed the donations in his History of Harvard University 2.569. Mr Harris shewed us a considerable collection of new French Books recently added to the Library and a German collection of Etruscan and Grecian sculptured vases— They have not the works of the Count de Caylus— I borrowed the second volume of Blacks Translation of Humboldt’s New Spain— We then visited the cabinet of Minerals where Professor Webster was at work in reducing and cleaning some crystals which he has lately collected on an excursion into the western part of New-York— After viewing the collection of portraits in the dining hall we returned to the President’s house, and then rode out to the new Observatory, on the spot where stood Cragie’s Summer house— When I was there the day after commencement last year they were digging the foundation— There is now a dwelling house for the observator, piers for placing on them as stands the great Frauenhofer Refractor. The transit instrument, and the transit-circle— The tower of solid granit is raised about 20 feet above the surface of the earth and is not yet finished— We found Mr Peirce and Mr Bond there and went all over the buildings with them.— The prospects are beautiful, and extensive all round— None of the instruments have yet been received. Mr Peirce and Mr Bond returned with us to the President’s house— The Professors Beck, Peirce, and Salisbury a stranger from Yale College; and Professor Webster were at the dinner. Mr Cleveland a Sailor author came in while we were at table, and Mr Greene came in from Boston at the dessert. Miss Webster the professor’s daughter came after dinner— At 5 I took my leave, and came through Boston and came home to Quincy satiated with sweets. I found my wife better, but yet confined to her chamber— The poor child Arthur yet with a swollen throat— My Son part of the Evening here.
