22. IV:15. Sunday.  Sun rose 6. Set  Sudden change from midsummer heat and a parching drought— The sear and yellow leaf on many trees, and showers of them fallen and falling from the willows.— The Sun set clear last evening but a Southwest gale had been blowing all day. This morning was cloudy and from 2 to 4 pm this afternoon the was a copious shower of rain— The first fordays— Mr Lunt preached this morning from Philippians 3.9.— “The righteousness which is of God, by Faith.” The same sermon which he preached last Wednesday at the Installation of Mr Rice— It gave me occasion to remark upon the great imperfection of my Memory.— As Mr Lunt read over his sermon I recollected every sentence as I had heard it before. Yet I could not remember one sentence, but as it was repeated to me. Dr Pierce of Brookline has told me of a young woman in his parish who after hearing a sermon once delivered, can go home, and write it out word for word—what a power! and how vainly I have struggled full three score years to retain so much as the substance of discourses that I hear.— Even after twice hearing this sermon of Mr Lunt I could give but a scanty and meagre account of it— The kernel of it is that Faith is the Christian system of morals. He began by observing that it had been cast as a reproach upon Christianity that it had no system of Morals connected with it— Meaning thereby a code of positive precepts, such for example as the decalogue— Mr Lunt presents Faith as in itself a system of morals; and a priesthood and the institution of the Sabbath as schools of moral philosophy.— There is much in this view But in truth the New Testament is itself the most excellent code of ethics in the world, and Jesus was the most perfect of moral teachers— He summed up the whole duty of man in two precepts, the love of God, and the love of his neighbour— He taught his doctrines to the poor— He exemplified them by his life— He sanctioned them by the performance of miracles.— He died and rose from the dead to prove their immortality. Love is to the moral universe, what gravitation is to the physical— One principle, the vital element of all human action, pervading the life of man from the cradle to the grave—all founded upon duty— The basis of Greek and Roman Moral Philosophy was self love. Happiness— There was no word in their languages to express duty— Justice was their moral law— Mercy is the moral law of Christianity— Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from 1. Corinthians 7.31. “And they that use this world as not abusing it.” From which he inferred that there are lawful uses which may be made of the world—and by the world he said might be understood either the people of the world, our fellow tenants of the globe—or the globe itself the tenement of man— Besides these discourses I read two of the volume published by the Revd Orville Dewey, the second upon human nature; and the third upon the wrong which sin does to human Nature— The two sermons on human nature contain an ingenious, benevolent and I believe sound argument against the doctrine of its total depravity— I saw the Sun set from Charles’s house—clear— Mr G. W. Beale here this Evening.

23. IV:15. Monday.  Sun rose 5:47. Set 5:58. Fahrenheit 40.— Fire.  There was a border cloud over the Sun, at his rising this morning, and the average temperature of the morning atmosphere the last week in September with fair weather disables me for writing— At ten O’Clock Mr Hudson came and engaged me for a sitting until noon— I was much occupied in looking over the file of the last Winter’s Globe to find the letter from Andrew Jackson to Aaron Vail Brown with the mystification of George W. Erving’s treachery, but without success. The Revd. G. D. Garland of Roxbury, a preacher of the Freewill Baptist Society came with a contribution paper for building a church of that denomination to which I put down my name for 5. dollars.— I barely made out my record of yesterday and took a short tour in the garden and nursery when I was called to dinner— Soon after which Dr Dana of Brandon, Vermont came with a Letter recommendatory from William Hayden, Senior editor of the Boston Atlas— He was accompanied by his brother a merchant of Boston. They are fervent whigs, and the only object of their visit was to see and converse with me— While they were here, Mr and Mrs. Birney came in— He is the son of James G. Birney now of Michigan, and the candidate of the Liberty party for election as President of the United States— The Son resides at New-Haven, Connecticut; I met him last week at the office of the Morning Chronicle, in Boston last which, and Mr Leavitt introduced him to me. Why he visits me now I do not know— His father owes me a grudge, and as the head of the abolition Liberty party made a violent and furious assault upon my character and reputation in a Letter to his party— He had perhaps some provocation— When he was going to the first world’s convention at London in 1840. he wrote to me requesting Letters of introduction to my friends in England—a piece of sheer impertinence, for I had no personal acquaintance with him which could warrant me in recommending him to my friends, nor any reason to believe him a man of merit so transcendent that I could venture to recommend him, though a stranger. But as an answer of refusal would have required an assignment of reasons which I knew would be more offensive to him even than neglect, I left his Letter unanswered, and he now assails me in revenge.— He has emancipated some Slaves which he inherited from his father— Has suffered persecution, obloquy and loss for the cause of Liberty for which he is entitled to respect and gratitude. But he is the sport of envious, bitter, ambitious and malignant passions, and his head is turned by the greatness thrust upon him of a party candidate for the presidency.— Charles took his Son John Quincy to Boston to school this morning, and brought him back this Evening.

24. V. Tuesday.  Sun rose 5.48. SetFahrenheit 36. Frost.  Sharp frost, and the morning so cold that I was unable to write— We had a fire in the middle room, and the cold shatters my nerves so that I have scarcely the use of my hands— Yet my son has promised the young men’s whig club of Boston that I will deliver to them a political Lecture on the evening of Monday the 7th. of October— Charles is President of that association, and I wish to give him aid as far as may be practicable in the fulfilment of his duties in that capacity— I wished also to take the opportunity to expose the foul conspiracy of Andrew Jackson, George W. Erving, Aaron Vail Brown, Charles Jared Ingersoll, Major Lewis—Dixon H. Lewis and others charging me with a treacherous surrender of Texas to Spain by the Florida Treaty in 1819.— I have written 40 pages, which it would take me two hours and a half to deliver, and I have not yet got half through my defence— I cannot finish before the 7th. of next month, and must deliver it in fragments.— I shudder at the work before me, and despair of making it effective. Mr Hudson came and took a sitting for my portrait— It is so irksome, and so time-consuming, that he has agreed to reduce the sittings to one hour a day, and I have agreed to give him as many sittings as he shall desire. He improved the likeness very much this day. This afternoon Mr Cassius M. Clay came out from Boston, with Mrs George T Bigelow, and Miss Porter daughter of the late General Peter B. Porter, to visit us. Mr C. M. Clay is a native of Kentucky, and within the last two years has acquired great celebrity by declaring the highest toned sentiments against Slavery— He has in numerous public speeches advocated the abolition of Slavery in that State; has raised against himself hosts of deadly enemies, and has been more than once hunted for assassination.— He has emancipated a number of his own slaves. Last winter he attended a meeting called by Colonel Johnson to pass Resolutions for the annexation of Texas to the United States and he prevented the passage of the Resolutions He is now travelling about the Northern States, discoursing wherever he goes against Slavery, the Slave trade and the annexation of Texas. His wife is with him, said to be a very fine woman; but has been taken ill in Boston, and could not come out with him this afternoon— He has made several speeches at Boston, and is said to be transcendently eloquent He told me that his speech to the Boston young men’s whig club, was reported in the Atlas of this morning; and requested me to read it and write to him at New-York my opinion of it. He also said that he had derived his principles in part from me— Charles here this evening.

25. V. Wednesday.  Sleepless Night— Its causes— Breakfast yesterday on Coffee; and a large cup of tea last evening. I must beware of evening tea. The third cause, anxiety for my task I cannot shake off— Mr Loring called this morning on his way from Hingham to Boston, and gave me a letter from Francis Hilliard, Chairman of the whig Committee of the 8th. Congressional District, inviting me to address my Constituents and the public, at such time and place as may be most convenient and agreeable to myself— This is a new burden which I must assume, and I desired Mr Loring to say to Mr Hilliard that having promised to address the young men’s whig club at Boston next Monday week, I must ask for time to prepare for another address to my Constituents, probably till towards the close of the next month; and will answer his Letter in time to give ample notice to the people of the whole district of the time and place when and where I may address them— Mr Loring inclined to Dorchester or Roxbury, and to the Evening rather than the day-time— He called again this afternoon on his return from Boston to Hingham. I had agreed with him to go upon a fishing excursion to Cohasset to morrow. But the weather was lowering, and we both expected foul weather to-morrow. We determined therefore to postpone indefinitely the party to Cohasset—especially as he says the Cod have forsaken the fishing grounds on the coast for the Season, and that there has been but one Cod in Boston market for the last ten days. Mr Hudson came and took an hour sitting for my portrait— He is to come again on Friday— He inclines to take the hands, and we had a long consultation how to dispose of them— Charles took his son John Quincy again to Boston to attend school— He came out yesterday because it was holiday for a muster— And Charles remains in Boston over this Night— I wrote with great difficulty and a trembling hand—excessively hurried— In reviewing the Negotiations with Spain which terminated by the conclusion of the Florida Treaty, the subject spreads and widens under my hand— It goes back not only to the negotiation of the Louisiana Treaty in 1803. but to the suspension of the deposit at New-Orleans in 1802— To Thomas Pinckney’s Treaty of 1795— To the Negotiations of John Jay and Gardoqui about the Navigation of the Mississippi in 1786.— And to the cobwebs spun by France and Spain during the war of our Revolution, to exclude us from the right of navigating the Mississippi, and from the country bordering on that river and its tributaries.— But I must stop far short of all this— I begin with G. W. Erving’s Commission, full power and intructions as Minister to Spain in 1816.—but must look back to the Negotiation of James Monroe and Charles Pinckney with Don Pedro Cevallos in 1805 and not wholly overlook the Louisiana Treaty purchase in 1803. I was most laboriously occupied upon this work till 10 O’Clock this evening and then went to bed, labouring with it in my head.

26. V. Thursday.  There was some rain in the course of the last Night but it began in earnest about the hour of my rising, and continued without abatement till near Noon— It was well that we had agreed to postpone indefinitely our fishing party to Cohasset, and as I have promised to address two public meetings before the first of November, my anxiety to prepare for both of them becomes from day to day more and more intense. After all the trouble and pains I have taken to draw up an Address to my Constituents I find that it wants unity of subject, point, for impression, good humour to hit the fancy and secure the sympathy of the auditory, and pleasantly to amuse them— All these are essential to popular eloquence— There is nothing so fatal to the success of stump speaking as dulness— Tous les genres sont bons, hormis le genre ennuyeux— I have analysed the correspondence furnished in answer to the call moved by Dixon H. Lewis in the House of Representatives on the 29th. of April last, and every page of it furnishes pregnant evidence to refute the lies of Andrew Jackson, Aaron Vail Brown, George W. Erving, and Charles Jared Ingersoll, every one of whom lies without remorse, but with variety of falsehood, which makes each of them an effective witness against all the others. But it will require extreme caution to compare and collate with one another all the documents heretofore published; the new ones recently produced and the false statements of each of the four false witnesses— And I never can be too much on my guard to avoid contesting any well attested statement, and to make none on my part susceptible of being disproved— We had visits this afternoon from Mr and Mrs R. C. Waterston, and my Son who had passed last Night in Boston to attend a supper party of the young men’s whig club, returned home this day, and spent the evening with us— He brought out the Boston Post of 25. March 1844. containing Andrew Jackson’s Letter to Aaron V. Brown of 12. Feby 1843. which he has borrowed from the files of the Boston Atlas. I have been for weeks wanting this paper without being able to find it; and I still want the Letter of Aaron V. Brown to the Editors of the Globe communicating Jackson’s Letter for publication— My Son brought me a declaration of Mary Jennison, widow of William Jennison, an Officer of the Revolutionary War, and of the Boston Frigate in 1778. to obtain an increase of pension— He brought also a Letter from Jonathan Amory of Roxbury, soliciting in case of a vacancy at West Point a warrant for his son Thomas C. Amory now at school under the charge of Mr Daniel Leach— Mr Amory encloses a certificate of Mr Leach to the moral character, intelligence and proficiency in study of the youth for whom the warrant is desired. These two subjects will require my attention at Washington next December.

27. V. Friday—  Fahrenheit 36. Sun rose 5.51. Set 5:50  I have been desirous of staving off the making a fire in my writing chamber till the first of October; but have not succeeded— After losing one night’s sleep with cold feet, and losing hours of insomnolency before getting to sleep last Night, I gave up the struggle, and this morning lighted a fire in my chamber.— Mr Hudson came and took another sitting for my portrait, which he has so much improved, that the family are all pleased with the likeness. The spy-glass in the hand will distinguish it from all other portraits of me. The Boston morning Post of 25. March last, which my Son brought out for me last evening enabled me to find this morning the Globe of 21. March 1844. upon the files which I had brought from Washington, and which I had not hitherto been able to find— It is better for my purpose than the Boston Post, because it contains the original publication by Aaron Vail Brown, of Jackson’s Letter, and further, the Letter from Brown, to the Editors of the Globe, Blair and Rives, enclosing Jackson’s Letter for publication. I have determined to make this the immediate and single subject of my Address to the young men’s whig club at Boston, next Monday week— First, for the vindication of my own character, from the vile Slanders, of Jackson, Erving, Brown, and Charles J. Ingersoll—and secondly, to expose to the world, and to after times the infamous means used to accomplish this annexation of Texas to the United States— How far this selection of my subject will be satisfactory to those whom I am to address; how far to the free people of this Union—how far I shall be able to enliven it with interest is a problem from which I would shrink if I could.— I have fearful odds to encounter; and little to encourage me—  My Polar star must be my guide— The Florida Treaty was the most important incidents in my life; and the most successful Negotiation ever consummated by the Government of this Union— And this is precisely selected above all others as an engine for the total destruction of my good name and to charge me with treachery to my country and to my trust— I have long hesitated, not whether I should notice this conspiracy against me; but how, and when— I have taken time to look over the documents, and can wind the whole body of the conspirators round my fingers— My only danger, is of losing my vantage ground. I went up the hill at Sunset and was forthwith called back to see Mr John Foster and a Mr Adams from Kentucky— Charles and his wife, first time for these three weeks, spent the Evening here.

28. V. Saturday  Fahrenheit 32.  A gathering storm the whole day. My wife after ten days confinement in her chamber is again able to be out, and Charles’s youngest boy Arthur is convalescent from the scarlet fever— Morning visit from Mr Lunt who sat with us about an hour, but has no conversation— Mr Benjamin Greenleaf, principal of a teacher’s seminary at Bradford in the County of Essex, and Mr Tack, preceptor of an Academy at Cohasset called to see me, and Mr Greenleaf gave me a work published by himself called the National Arithmetic on the inductive system, combining the analytic and synthetic methods, in which the principles of Arithmetic are explained in a perspicuous and familiar manner: containing also practical systems of mensuration—gauging, geometry and book-keeping—forming a complete mercantile Arithmetic—designed for the use of common schools and academies. An improved Stereotype Edition— A small duodecimo volume, and therefore the more acceptable to me—for the less there is of matter in books to teach science the better; because there is less of taxation upon the memory. I answered the Letter from M. M. Fisher of Medway and agreed to receive the deputation from the Liberty party of the 8th. Congressional district, next Tuesday.— I received a Letter from Mrs Harriet V. W. Freeman of Philadelphia, inviting me in the name of the whig Ladies of that city to attend and address a few words to them on the occasion of their presenting a banner to the National Clay Club on the evening of the 30th. of September in the Saloon of the Chinese Museum.— My Son went this morning to Boston, taking with him his daughter Louisa Catherine to take a lesson of music, and brought her out and his son John Quincy from the Latin School, to dinner.— Charles informed me that four members of the old anti-masonic party had desired him to say to me that they intended to come out and see me next Tuesday afternoon and that their object was to invite me to republish a collection of all my Letters on the anti-masonic controversy— Charles and his wife were here this evening, and our two Granddaughters played jointly on the Piano, and Mary Louisa sung.— I am heavily burdened in preparation for my address to the young men’s whig club at Boston on the evening of next Monday week.— I am under peine forte et dure till that day shall be passed.

29. IV:15 Sunday  Equinoxial  The roaring of Nantasket beach was heard last Evening from our house, and this day we had a South-east storm of wind and rain which I found in full blast and shower when I rose, and continued till 3 in the afternoon, when it cleared off and the Sun flamed out for an hour or two, but went again into clouds.— Dr Francis, Parkman Professor of Pulpit eloquence and the Pastoral Care at the Harvard University preached for Mr Lunt this morning from Ephesians 4.13 “Till we all come in the unity of the faith, and of the knowledge of the Son of God, unto a perfect man, unto the measure of the stature of the fulness of Christ.” The text and the discourse had an aspect of affinity with the Professor’s chair It was liberal and anti-sectarian, holding up the Christian Religion as a system of great and all comprehensive purpose bearing upon the condition and happiness of all men; and that it could not possibly contracted into the narrow compass of such questions as whether a little more or a little less water should be used in administering the rite of baptism—whether the operation of the spirit was instantaneous or gradual; whether fashions of dress or modes of conversation should be reduced to articles of faith; all seeming to belong to the childhood than to the mature age of human existence, all more suited to the imperfect growth, than to the measure of the stature of the fulness of Christ— Dr Francis dined with us. his afternoon Sermon was from Acts 15.9. “purifying their hearts by faith”— There was something of a disquisition upon the nature of Faith, upon which I some years since delivered at several places a Lecture, but he did not mark the distinction between the faith which is confidence in others and that which is fidelity to a trust— Dr Francis was several years minister of a congregational church at Watertown, and bears the reputation of standing high in the class of our clergymen of the middle age— He has none of the graces of delivery, nor brilliancy of composition which are the appendages of Pulpit eloquence— His genius is solid rather than sparkling— I could not give this day that attention to his discourses which their intrinsic merit should have commanded. I was too much absorbed in preparations for my self defence, before the Boston young men’s whig club, of Monday 7. October— A dubious experiment [symbols]

30. IV:15. Monday  Sun rose 5.55 Set 5.45. Fahrenheit 36.  The pressure upon my brain grows more and more intense as I approach the day of my first trial, and my time is now taxed night and day—till I can scarcely obtain sleep from my pillow, or breath to ascend the hill, and witness the glorious rising and setting of the Sun; or the nightly fading of the beams of Jupiter waning under the light of the moon, or the extinction of the rays of Venus in the Splendor of the rising Sun. Rachel Samson was here this morning but went up the hill to work for Mrs Charles.— We had morning visits from Mrs George Sullivan and her sonBowdoin, and her sister now the wife of Dr John C. Warren— And after dinner came the Anti-Masons Henry Gassett, John D. Williams,Odiorne, and a Mr Weld— They are desirous of republishing an edition of all my writings upon the anti-masonic controversy, copies of which they intend to have sent as presents to all the literary and scientific institutions of the United States— Mr. Gassett brought with him and left with me a list of my writings on the subject which he possessed 1. Letters to W. L. Stone, on the Apprentices Oath. 2. Letters to Edward Livingston. 3. Letter to James Moorhead. 4. To a Committee of the Vermont State Anti-Masonic Convention at Montpelier. 5. To James Moorhead, Secretary of Meadville Convention. 6. To Benjamin Cowell of Rhode Island. 7. Address to the People of Massachusetts— There are two or three others, which I must look up. They propose to make the publication at their own expense; to obtain from me all the Articles missing from their list; and that I would write a preface to this new compilation giving a summary history of the Antimasonic controversy— I said I would cheerfully do it if I could find the time for it which I feared would be impossible before the meeting of Congress, or indeed during the next winter.— They desired me to take my own time for it— They seemed concerned for fear that the Masons have revived under the name of odd fellows— While they were here, Jeremiah Hackett of Vermont came in, upon a mere visit of curiosity to see me— Charles, Walter Hellen, and my two Granddaughters went this afternoon to Boston, to see Mr Macready play Hamlet, but were disappointed— My wife who is convalescent had a faint ill turn this evening.

1. V:30. Tuesday.  Sun rose 5:56. Set 5.43. Fahrenheit 32.  The temple clock struck six, when the disk of the Sun was about half risen. Till then I saw Venus, but then she vanished from my sight— The sky was crystal clear, and the Mercury in my Dresden thermometer at 32.  The names in the margin are of the members of the Committee of the Liberty party of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, who visited me this morning. They have appointed this day week for a convention to nominate a candidate for election to the house of Representatives of the United States in the 29th. Congress.— They have heretofore not nominated a candidate against me—but they will at this time, and it is highly probable will defeat the election— They were however to me this day peculiarly courteous and civil— Mr Fisher said they had no disposition to dictate opinions to me, nor to ask any pledge of me, which it might be disagreeable to me to give, but they had come to the conclusion that they were under obligations of duty to vote exclusively for persons who entertained certain opinions on the subject of Slavery, and all they were fully aware of the great and frequent services that they were indebted to me for, in support of the cause which they had so much at heart, they wished for this friendly interview to ascertain my opinions on certain points upon which there was considerable adversity among those generally opposed to Slavery.— I told them that I would cheerfully give to them my opinions as they were sincerely entertained, upon any and every point interesting to them— That I had no motive to conceal or disguise any of my opinions upon subjects of public concernment— That I had lived 77 years and served in various offices, and never asked or solicited directly or indirectly the vote of any man, and thought it not worth while to commence the practise now— I answered all their questions; discussed with them the points upon which we did not concur— The vote for President upon which I should not be the partizan of any man.— We considered the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia and the territories and the prohibition of the interstate Slave-trade. They declared themselves perfectly satisfied with the interview— One of them said he should vote for me with pleasure—another said he did not know but what he should— The rest were silent. I asked them for their names; which one of them brought me on cards, from French’s tavern where they dined Mr Fisher said they expected at this election to cast from 1400 to 1600 votes. Charles and his wife were here this Evening.

2. IV. Wednesday.  Sun rose 5:57. Set 5:42. Fahrenheit 32.  The temple clock, struck six as about 4 digits of the Sun’s disk had appeared above the horizon, and as he rose Venus vanished from sight on the firmament— My visitors yesterday from the Committee of the Liberty party were apparently not of one mind when they came nor yet when they left me. My opposition to the immediate abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, and in the Territories, they all disapprove, and Mr Howe the late Senator from Norfolk County in the State Legislature pressed me specially with the question whether Congress have not the power to repeal the Laws of the District which allow and sanction Slavery— With regard to the inter-state Slave trade I told them I had no doubt of the power of Congress to prohibit that, and would vote for a bill to that effect to-morrow, though it would not be possible to prevail upon the house to receive such a bill— I told them I regretted that I could not concur with them in all their opinions, and still more the dissensions prevailing among themselves— The Colonization Society— The Anti-Slavery and abolition Societies—the no-government non resisting and women membered Societies— I grieved also at their classing in the same level of exclusion the whig and democrat parties.— I thought there was a great difference between them; and that placing them on the same level was to secure the triumph of the worst party— This tendency of all private associations to settle into factious cabals is the besetting sin of all elective governments— I had no visitors this day— This Evening my Son, with Walter Hellen, Mary Louisa, and Louisa Catherine and John Quincy whom they took up in Boston, went to the Melodeon, and saw the Tragedy of Hamlet performed, the part of Hamlet by Macready— It was close upon 1. of to-morrow morning when they got home excepting John Quincy 3. who remained in Boston to attend the Latin school— I received this morning from Mr N. Frye at Washington the daily Globe of 20 March 1844. containing the Letters of Aaron Vail Brown and Andrew Jackson upon the annexation of Texas to the United States— I employed so industriously this day that besides the daily record I wrote 4 pages of my task, only to prove what with diligence can do in one day.— The danger now is that I shall do too much—slide into dulness, wander into impertinence, fret into ribaldry and worry into tediousness— The conspiracy against my good name is so complicated, so combined so crafty and so base that I can scarcely keep my self-command to meet it—

3. IV:15. Thursday  Sun rose 5.58. Set 5.40 with sprinkle of rain.  Th temple Clock struck 6 with the first beam of the Sun emerging from the eastern hill over the corner of Captain Underwood’s house— I had no interruption of visitors except from a Mr Tirrell who came to dispose of tickets for a convivial party of the members of the Quincy fire companies at 1. O’Clock p.m to-morrow— I took ten tickets and promised to attend the meeting in person, if I should find it convenient— My Son went this morning with his son Charles Francis to the granite quarries, where Mr Lemuel Humphrey of Weymouth had engaged to meet him to make a survey and take a plan of a lot of mine there— He intended to have returned home to dinner; but the work took the day, and was still left unfinished— At the setting of the Sun I went up the hill where his wife told me that he had not returned and she knew not where he was— I came back to enquire of Benjamin F Andrews where he had left him this morning; but James Davenport their servant followed close after me and told me that Mr Charles with his Son had returned. Though I had the whole day for my labour I was able to write only three pages of my task, and find I shall be obliged to curtail and concentrate much of what I have yet to say on Monday next— In the Evening Charles came down—without his wife, and I read to the family what I have already written for the address of next Monday.— It occupied an hour and a half, and I suppressed the reading of several documents, which I must not pass over next Monday.— I must bespeak the patience of my hearers a full hour longer and then abridge and leave out— But what is worse my language is too violent, and must be smoothed down, I know not how nor to what extent—further I have now only four days more to finish, and must leave space for a final recapitulation— I read myself this evening quite hoarse, and took warning to pitch my voice quite low when I begin— All my correspondence lags behind and I leave unanswered numerous invitations, and complimentary Letters. Walter Hellen has completed for me a large collection of extracts from my Diary of 1818 and 1819. which I much wanted at Washington last Winter; and of which I want that more than one copy should be in existence to guard against the casualty of fire, and the possibility of theft or mutilation— The Steamer Caledonia arrived from Liverpool at Boston this morning at ten O’Clock, in the average Summer passage of 14 days, and with the average number of 101. passengers.

4. IV:15. Friday.  Rain storm from early morning till late this afternoon— I thought I should have a long uninterrupted day, but was sadly disappointed. As the evening twilight came on I took my hat to go up to Charles’s house, when two strangers came in and introduced themselves as Mr Wilson of Missouri and Mr Haven of New-York city— They are whig politicians and came to see me from mere curiosity to see and talk with me— Mr Wilson said he had been settled in Missouri nearly 25. years, and most of that time in opposition to Coll. Thomas H Benton, whose recent movements against the annexation of Texas were caused by his knowledge that nothing else could have saved him politically in Missouri— The people there were all of them perfectly willing to take Texas, and to fight the Mexicans, or the British—but they have an abhorrence to being burdened to pay the debt of Texas which they know will amount to nearer twenty five than ten millions of dollars, and they know that if Texas should be annexed to the United States there will not come to them one acre of ungranted land— Mr Wilson discoursed thus for at least an hour with little interruption from me— Mr Haven said little— I invited them to take tea with us, but they said it was growing late and they must return to Boston— They were scarcely gone, and our tea table cleared when Mr Edward M. Clymer a Student at the Law school at Cambridge, came with a Letter of recommendation from his uncle William Hiester of New Holland Pennsylvania— Mr Clymer’s object was only to spend an evening with us which he did— He is a pleasant very well bred and sociable young man, whom I regretted not to have convenient means to pass the Night with us. Charles and his wife also spent the evening here— The news by the Caledonia and other newspaper intelligence absorbed hours, and a private Letter from George W. Erving to me in the pamphlet, of 1. March 1818 referred me to one that I had received from in London after my appointment as Secretary of State, and before I embarked to return home. Walter Hellen searched and found it for me and with it a file of Letters from him received by me in England from 1815 to 1817. The one of which I was in search contained a quotation from a Latin poet, not of the hacknied class, and I lost some time in searching for it, in vain— And more time in reading over the file.

5. IV:15. Saturday.—  Sun rose 6:1. Set 5:38.  Mr John J. Carr the tenant of my homested farm came to me this morning from a whig committee with a subscription paper promising to pay blank sums, for the circulating papers among the people; and other expenses of the Committee, which I declined to subscribe, observing to Mr Carr that I thought there would be an impropriety in my contributing money for such a purpose, and by the indefinite terms in which the paper was drawn up it would be the incipient entrance upon a practise making all elections venal, and setting up all public offices at auction to the highest bidder. Mr Dudley Williams of Roxbury with his wife was here with a Document certified by John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth, being the declaration of Hannah Allen now widow of Richard Allen, but heretofore widow of Zebulon Thayer, and a claimant for a pension— Her maiden name was White, and she says she went to school with me to Nathan Rice— Besides her declaration there are affidavits of Bryant Newcomb, and Dudley Williams—and Certificates from Judson Stoddard town Clark of Braintree—Samuel F. M’Cleary City Clerk, William T. Andrews Justice of the Peace and Sherman Leland judge of Probate for the County— Mr Williams requested me to transmit these papers to the commissioners of pensions which I promised to do. Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks came out from Boston, and dined with My Son up the hill— They went to Europe in 1842 for the recovery of his health, in which he has been partially successeul.— They returned in the last Steamer, and are to resume in a few weeks their residence at New-York— There he has been many years in partnership of trade with Charles Augustus Davis— They returned to Boston immediately after dinner, and they were scarcely gone, when Charles’s wife was taken suddenly ill and took to her bed— Dr Woodward was sent for, and I came home in grief and alarm from the house to which I had gone for festivity and joy.— How pungent is the feeling of such vicissitudes! I laboured hard at my task— Walter Hellen found for me the file of Letters from George W. Erving, which I received in England from 1815 to 1817. and among them was the one I wanted, an exquisite curiosity at this day— A Letter from Madrid of 3. May 1817. containing a classical quotation of Latin poetry, which after diligent search, consuming no small time I found was from Propertius 2.20.32— Three lines and two words— They are the key to Mr George W. Erving’s Revelation’s to President Jackson in 1829 and 1832— They were a supplication to me from Erving to raise him from the Hell of Madrid to the Heaven of Paris.

6. IV:15. Sunday. Communion day  I attend meeting at the Temple in the hope of composing my shattered nerves and abstracting my agitated bosom from the cares of the world and the interests of Time— This is peculiarly my desire on the days when I partake of the communion— This day, with sorrow I says was too much absorbed by this world, and too little to that at the verge of which I stand— Heaven forgive me for it! Mr Lunt preached this morning from John 12.27. [“]Now is my soul troubled; and what shall I say? Father, save me from this hour; but for this cause came I unto this hour.” This is part of a discourse of Jesus only six days before his last Passover at Bethany where he had performed the miracle of raising Lazarus from the dead— Here it was that between the worship of those who had witnessed the miracle and believed him to be the Messiah; and the compassing of his death by those who disbelieved, which was within one week of being consummated, his soul was troubled— He revealed himself and the destiny that awaited him, in figurative and, somewhat misterious, discourse, not understood even by his disciples, until explained by his subsequent death and resurrection; and foretold at once his suffering and his glorification— Mr Lunt’s view of his text appeared to me ingenious and impressive as he delivered his sermon; but other thoughts were forcing themselves upon my memory while he spoke, and my soul was like one of those sheets of antient parchments, upon which a poem in monkish rhyme is written over an Oration of Cicero. Mr Lunt administered the communion and the usual annual collection was taken up to defray the expenses of this ordinance— He also reminded the members of the church of a resolution within the last year adopted, that two blank books should be purchased, one for a copy to be made in it of the antient records of the church, and the other in which the future records may be kept— The change in the time of meeting from ten, to half past ten in the morning, and from a quarter past to a quarter before 2. in the afternoon commenced this day.— On returning from the morning service I found Mr Degrand who dined and spent the day with us.— After dinner Mr Joseph Angier of Milton preached in exchange with Mr Lunt, from James 2.8. “If ye fulfil the royal law, according to the scripture, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, as thyself, ye do well”— Mr Degrand left us to return to Boston about 7. in the evening, and from that time till midnight I was writing at my task without coming to a close— Charles had gone to Boston this morning, was at meeting this afternoon, and here this Evening.

7. V. Monday.  This was one of the epochal days of my life— On the 26th of last month my son brought me the Boston Post of 25. March containing Andrew Jackson’s Letter to Aaron Vail Brown of 12. Feby 1843. The next morning I found on my file, the semi-weekly Globe of 21. March 1844 containing Brown’s Letter to the Editors of the Globe, with Jackson’s Letter for publication— I determined to make them the text of the address which I had promised to deliver to the young men’s whig club of Boston this Evening.— I thought this a suitable occasion for opening my defence before the country and the world, against the conspiracy of Andrew Jackson, Aaron Vail Brown, George W. Erving and Charles J. Ingersoll, with their coadjutors and tools, to ruin my good name, and fabricate a fable to justify the robbery of Texas from Mexico, by the pretence that Texas had been by me treacherously surrendered to Spain— I began the address that day, and finished it this day just in time for dinner— The composition therefore is excessively hurried and unskilfully put together, with sundry repetitions, which needed a pruning hand; but I had no time to give— At 6 O’Clock this afternoon I rode into Boston with my Son and Walter Hellen, and precisely at 7. alighted at the Tremont Temple— I was there received with the utmost simplicity by the Committee of the young men’s whig club, in a private room adjoining the hall which was already crowded as full as it could hold— Several of my elderly friends were assembled in this private room and I was specially greeted by Samuel T. Armstrong, Jeremiah Mason, Abbott Lawrence, Stephen C. Phillips, Robert C. Winthrop, Josiah Quincy junr. Samuel H. Walley junr. and several others. Mr Hayden Editor of the Boston Atlas, Erastus Brooks of the New-York Evening Express, and the younger Buckingham, applied for the use of my manuscript for immediate publication in their respective papers— I gave it with a pledge that I should have a proof sheet to revise before publication, to Mr Hayden the first applicant— At precisely half past 7. I entered the Hall with my Son, who is President of the club, and with the chairman of the Committee of the Club. The reception was complimentary and enthusiastic, and my Son said that after such a reception, it would be superfluous for him to do more than announce to them the name of his father John Quincy Adams—whereupon another shout of welcome shook the house— A young Mr Coffin at my request read the Letters of Aaron Vail Brown and of Andrew Jackson, and I discoursed upon them two hours and ten minutes much to the amusement of the Auditory— The closing Apostrophe to the young men of Boston was specially well received. As soon as the crowd was cleared away we re-entered the Carriage; left my son at the United States Hotel, and with Walter Hellen I returned to Quincy—reaching home at eleven.

8. Tuesday. V.  Sun rose 6:4. Set 5:33.  In the hurry of preparation for the last evening my diary has run three days in arrear, and the high excitement of yesterday with more than two hours of loud speaking, preceded and followed by the rides have left upon me a feverish lassitude, and longing for a vacation ill-suited to my condition— I am to address my constituents the people of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts before the last of this month— I ought to have been at work upon it this day but could not bring myself to it. I allowed myself about three hours to transport three seedling stocks of pear trees, and one shag-bark walnut tree from the Nursery to the Seminary: a very hazardous operation, and of the success of which I despair even while undertaking it. The trees are of six or seven years growth and would flourish in their native soil; but they stand too near other yet more valuable trees, and must be removed from their proximity—the walnut had a double tap root which John Kirk could not extract from the rock-bound soil, and of which he cut off with the spade a large portion— My Son remained last Night in Boston, and took lodging at the United States Hotel to start early this morning on the Western Railroad for Springfield, where he is to address a whig Meeting this Evening— To morrow and Thursday he is to perform the same service at other places; and to return home next Friday. The Atlas and the Boston Courier of this morning have notices of the meeting of the Young men’s whig club last Evening at the Tremont Temple, and very commendatory accounts of my Address which the Atlas promises to give from my Manuscript Notes to-morrow— But I received no proof sheet. I had engaged to pass the Night at Mr James H Foster’s if I had remained in the City. Mr Josiah Quincy junr. also offered me a bed, and judge John Davis engaged me to dine with him on the next day of Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society— My time was so wholly absorbed yesterday that I could not even read the Boston Morning Newspapers— The State-elections keep up the political agitation— The accounts from Delaware are very equivocal—from Maryland encouraging, but with a dark spot from the City of Baltimore. From Pennsylvania and New-York they are desperate, and the general result is equally so. Maine has gone by a majority of more than ten thousand for free trade and Texas.— It is hard to steer and row against wind and tide; but even in the agony of death we must say like Lawrence don’t give up the ship.

9. III.50 Wednesday  Sun rose 6.5— Set 5:31.  The moon had just risen when I rose, and having been yesterday in conjunction with Venus, I hoped to see them both at the rising of the Sun; but as the morning dawn advanced a hazy vapour arose and covered the atmosphere—the Sun rose with a crimson colour, and a smoky outline, and the day was the entrance to the Indian Summer.— I redeemed the arrears of my Diary, and began an address to my constituents, which I propose to have in readiness for the 30th. of this month— But it will absorb all my time so that I can do nothing else— I set out upon a new plan, and consider all that I have written from the 13th. of July when I got home till the 26th. of September as waste paper. My Address to the young whigs of Boston was published entire in the Boston Atlas of this day; but the paper did not come to me— The Morning Chronicle, the Liberty party paper of yesterday had not even a notice of the Meeting of the whig club of the night before— This day it has a very favourable account of the Address, specially remarking that there was not a word in it about the Presidential election or the Presidential candidates— Yesterday was the day of the Meeting of the Liberty party Convention to nominate candidates for Senators for the County of Norfolk; and for a member of the House of Representatives of the United States for the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts in the 29th. Congress. I received on Monday two Letters from John Gulliver, of Roxbury, one of the Liberty party Committee, who conferred with me on the 1st. of this month—extremely anxious between the fear that the Meeting would, and the hope that they would not nominate a Candidate against me— There is in the Morning Chronicle of this day no notice of the Meeting at Dedham yesterday— The Democratic party have nominated Isaac G. Wright who was last year one of the Senators for the County of Norfolk in the Legislature of the State. Mr Josiah Savil came this afternoon to enquire concerning certain papers, which he says were put into my brother Thomas’s hands shortly before his death, relating to the claim of Charles Newcomb, a revolutionary Soldier for bounty Lands— Newcomb was a pensioner under the act of Congress of 1818. The pension was revoked by the act of 1820.— He died soon after the papers were put into my brothers hands—and his widow Jerusha Newcomb who was a daughter of Micajah Adams is now entitled to a pension by the 5 years laws.— I referred Mr Savil to Mr Gourgas for the papers, and asked him for a written statement, to which I would attend.

10 IV. Thursday.  Sun rose 6.6. Set 5.29 Indian Summer.  I went up the hill to see both the rising and setting of the Sun, but before he rose the haze gathering over the Eastern horizon thickened so that I could discern only the outline of his disk, and at his setting although distinctly visible till he drew within a disk’s distance of the western, he had totally disappeared behind the haze before reaching its border. It was a genuine Indian Summer day, occupied as I would that all my days should be, with no unnecessary intermission, and writing the record of yesterday, and three pages of task— I cannot do more— Mr Beman is a coloured man about 3 4ths. white who came with a subscription paper for the Methodist-Episcopal Zion Church at Boston.— He is the Pastor of that Church, and one of the Clerks in the morning Chronicle Office.— A young man by the name of Ebenezer Wiley from South Reading in the County of Middlesex came to see me, from motives of mere curiosity— I was somewhat inquisitive about himself, but he was not much disposed to talk about himself, and I did not press enquiry.— Henry Hardwick came again to propose the purchase of that corner of land behind his house, which he has so long coveted. I promised to go and see the place or to ask my son to see it, for Mr Hardwick assured me repeatedly assured me that he would give for it double what it was worth— I paid to my wife the bequest of her brother Thomas B. Johnson and she went into Boston this afternoon, with her two Grand daughters Mary Louisa and Louisa Catherine and Walter Hellen— He brought me out the Boston Atlas of yesterday containing my address to the young men’s whig Club of Monday Evening published entire but with sundry considerable errors of the press.— About half of my address copied from the Atlas is published in the Boston Courier and in the Daily Advertiser of this day. The latter with a very favourable editorial notice— The first accounts came in this day of State Government elections in New-Jersey and Pennsylvania— The first favourable to the whigs— The second far otherwise— Both parties have Committees remaining at Washington during the recess, to superintend the issuing of documents and the circulation of intelligence— Willis Green of Kentucky is the Chairman of the whig-Committee— Robert J. Walker the Senator from Mississippi chairman of the democracy.— Walker printed a pamphlet—an Address of the Democratic Association at Washington D.C— Headed the South in Danger— Read before you vote.— Green undertook to circulate the same pamphlet in the North and the Democrats charged him with forgery.

11. III.50. Friday  Sun rose beclouded. Set 5:28.  My time is so thoroughly consumed in reading and writing on days occupied as this has been, that when it has passed I have nothing to tell— I had two Pear trees and two plum trees transplanted into the Nursery, and devoted an hour to the thinning of my seedlings in the Nursery. The two persons by the name of Coe were strangers from Connecticut the first, Minister of an episcopal church at Bethlehem, Litchfield County and the other from Winchester in the same County. They came to see me, merely for curiosity and the younger brother said that if he had returned home without seeing me, his father would not have forgiven him. My Son came back from his excursion to Springfield, Westfield and Cabotville where he has been making speeches the last three evenings— He comes with a severe cold, and weary of the office he had undertaken— Ruth Turner was here at work; Walter Hellen went to Boston to see Macready perform in a new Tragedy called the Bridal— I examined at last the publication in the Atlas of my Address to the young men’s whig club. The remainder of it is published in the Boston Courier, and I suppose in the Daily Advertiser of this day.— There are a few mistakes of the press in the Atlas—none of much importance except the word vaccination for buccination, which is ridiculous, and the more so because buccination is not a legitimate word, but one which I sported for the benefit of Aaron Vail Brown— Buccino is the Latin word for swelling the cheek to blow the trumpet or the horn, and there is a picture in the word— I made a noun substantive of it by the common analogy of Latin verbs turned into english nouns.— The compositor of the Atlas was not scholar enough to perceive it and substituted for it a word, which turned the whole sentence into nonsense— The returns of the elections continue to come in most unpropitious— The whigs have indeed carried the election in New Jersey and Stratton will be the Governor of the State— But Pennsylvania is irretrievably sunk in Democracy, and her most popular statesmen are trickish and unsafe— My projected address expands as I proceed— I am still wandering among first principles and generalities— I wish to call the attention of my countrymen to the pernicious feature of the slave-representation in the Government of the United States; but the people are so broken to it, that it is of no avail to expose it— I have yet much to unfold of the Tennessean conspiracy of Jackson, Erving, Aaron Vail Brown and Charles Jared Ingersoll against me, but I am yet uncertain whether now is the most favourable time for completing the exposure, or whether to wait.

13. IV. Sunday.  Sun rose 6.10. Set 5:24. Fahrenheit 28.  The sharpest morning of the Season yet— A more splendid exhibition of the starry firmament I never witnessed than that of this morning immediately after I arose— And among the numberless multitudes of assembled worlds, the planet Mercury shot his seldom visible but brilliant solitary beam into my window, about a quarter of an hour risen precisely in the track in which he was to be followed by the Sun— I ought to have seen the rising of Arcturus, just now rising long enough before the Son to be visible in the morning. Within a week of Starlight mornings I shall see him. My fingers and feet were pinched to see the rising of the Sun from the corner of Charles’s house; but it was a glorious sight— The surface of the ground wherever the eye could range was covered with hoar frost; but the temperature of the atmosphere softened much in the course of the day.— The Revd. Augustus R. Pope, of Kingston, near Plymouth officiated at the Temple by exchange with Mr Lunt. His morning text was from Luke 22.32. “But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not: and when thou art converted strengthen thy brethren.” It is the saying of the Saviour to Peter, forewarning him of his approaching desertion at the last Supper.— Mr Pope remarked upon the strangeness of the fact, that Jesus, the Messiah, at the moment when he was about to suffer an ignominious death, should have prayed that the faith of his disciple Peter might not fail, when he knew and foretold to Peter himself that it would— But he foretold also that Peter would recover from the fall of his frailty, and exhorts him when he is converted to strengthen his brethren— The Sermon was chiefly a discourse upon Faith— Simon (Peter’s) faith was to fail notwithstanding the prayer of Jesus—he was yet to be converted, and then was to strengthen the faith of his brethren. Since my own Dissertation upon Faith, which palls a little upon my Memory I have heard several Sermons from Clergymen on the same Subject, all of which have given me further ideas regarding it, but none has presented an exact analysis of it as an intellectual and sensitive property of men. Mr Pope enumerated the various senses in which the word Faith is used in the Scriptures without remarking upon the analogy between them— He dined with us, and I made several enquiries of him concerning the family of old judge Sever, at whose house I once slept in April 1787. and of his son, John Sever my Classmates— They are both long since dead but many descendants of John and his brother James remain. Mr Pope’s afternoon Sermon was from James 1.22. [“]But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.” After the service I called to see Mrs Charles who still keeps her bed— He was here this evening.

14. IV. Monday.  Sun rose 6.11. Set 5:22. Fahrenheit 44.  Lewis Bass, Collector of the parish tax, called on me this morning for payment of mine for which I referred him to my Son— He said he wanted a supply to pay to Mr Lunt— He is chairman of the whig Committee of this town and asked me if my Address to the young Men’s Boston whig club, was printed in a pamphlet. I said it was not yet, but I expected it would be— He said the whig Committee had voted last Saturday Evening to purchase 200 copies of it for circulation— This explains the application of J. J. Carr to me for a contribution. Bass said he took the half weekly Daily Advertiser and had seen only the first half of my address; but he referred to so many passages in it, that he shewed he had read it attentively— My Son went to Boston this morning and took his boy John Quincy into the Latin School. He returned and dined with us, and was here again in the Evening. He brought out a note of invitation to him and to me, from William Sawyer, to dine with him to-morrow— I received from President Quincy last week an invitation to attend the exhibition at Cambridge to-morrow— Before we had finished our dinner William Jackson of Newtown and his brother Francis Jackson came in; returning from a tour to Plymouth to examine the course of the Old Colony Rail-road.— William Jackson is the Candidate of the Liberty party for the Office of Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth. Francis Jackson is of the party who take no part in the Government because it requires an Oath to support the Constitution of the United States— William Jackson told me that he went to the Liberty party Convention last week at Dedham to prevent if possible the nomination of a Candidate for Congress against me— But he found it impossible— They were exceedingly zealous. He said he hoped I should be re-elected, but considered it doubtful— Mr William H. Story came from Brooklyn, New-York, with an invitation to me to preside over a whig mass-meeting there, on the 24th. of this month, which I declined, and I wrote also to Mr Halsey declining the invitation to read my address to the young men of Boston, on the Evening of the 23d at the Tabernacle in New-York. I regret much that I could not accept that invitation— Ruth Turner was again here this day— In the evening came on rain and the prospect of foul weather to morrow— My task is the daily page of the journal and three pages of preparation for the address to my Constituents. This is the ne plus ultra.

properties.dateline: Quincy, Tuesday 15. October 1844. Cambridge. Boston. Quincy.
properties.text: 15. IV. Tuesday.  How often Self-examination, is followed by self-reproach! and how often self reproach by self absolution and the neglect or forgetfulness of reform! I had determined to attend the exhibition at Cambridge this morning and to be there in Season at the Meeting of the Committee of Overseers at 10 O’Clock, to leave home at the latest by half past 8. The morning Newspapers came by the Mail, and among them, the National Intelligencer of last Saturday the 12th. instt. containing the whole of my Address of the 7th. to the young Men’s Whig club at Boston, and an idle curiosity to ascertain if it was correctly printed enticed me to read till I found the watch within five minutes of ten and that the Carriage had been an hour and a half in waiting— I hurried through Boston to Cambridge, and found the performances of the exhibitions just commenced, by a Latin Oration— There was a Prospectus of 14 performances, three of which were omitted— Three in Latin, two in Greek, & the rest in English— There was an English version of Chateaubriand’s Description of Jerusalem by Charles Eliot Norton of Cambridge A Latin Dialogue—translated from Sheridan’s Rivals. A Greek Dialogue from Moliere’s Fourberies de Scapin— A disquisition on the Offence and doom of André—by Frank Boott Goodrich of Roxbury A Dissertation upon American Eloquence—by Paul Willard of Charlestown— His antient American Orators were Patrick Henry and James Otis— The man of the Middle age Fisher Ames. The moderns Henry Clay and Daniel Webster— An English version of a Speech of Mirabeau to the National Assembly of 19. April 1790— A disquisition upon Philosophical and Religious Didactic Poetry—bottomless— A Greek version from Livy. A Dissertation upon the Satire in Gulliver’s Travels, by Charles Henry Glover of Nantucket—the most amusing part of the day.— He spoke of the Pilgrim’s Progress and Robinson Crusoe in parallel with Gulliver, as pre eminently pictures of English Life and manners.— The English Oration—the Reformer by Thomas Russell of Plymouth was not sparkling— After the performances I called at the President’s house, saw Mrs Quincy and her daughter Abby took her son Josiah junr to his house in Boston, passed an hour of heavy rain at Charles’s Office—took up again Josiah Quincy at his house, and went with him to N. 87. Mount Vernon Street where we dined, with my very old friend William Sawyer whom I had not seen for many years— The company were almost all old friends— I returned after dinner home.
