16. IV. Wednesday  Excessively hurried and delayed— My Son removed this day with his family to Boston— The further I proceed in my task, the more the field widens before me. I had received a Letter of the 24th of last Month from Francis Hilliard of Roxbury, Chairman of the whig Committee of the 8th Congressional District, inviting me to address my Constituents and the public, at such time and place as might be convenient and agreeable to myself— I had then just agreed to address the young men’s whig club at Boston, and had not even commenced that address.— I sent word by Mr Loring to Mr Hilliard, that I would comply with that invitation and fix the time and place for it after getting through with the young men of Boston— Ever since the 7th. I have been intending to write to Mr Hilliard, but he called on me this morning for my answer— I proposed to him this day fortnight the 30th. of this month at 10. O’Clock in the morning.— The place I left entirely at the discretion of the Committee to select; wishing only to suit the persons who will be likely to attend, that they may be put to as little inconvenience as possible— I had suggested to Mr Loring the expediency of notifying the towns of the District and proposing to them to send delegations to attend the meeting, which Mr Hilliard said he thought they would do.— With regard to the place Mr Hilliard went and consulted with Mr Brigham, and returned and said they proposed to apply for the use of the church at the Weymouth landing to which I readily agreed. He asked if I thought of adding any religious solemnity to the meeting. I said I should be glad that the meeting should be opened with prayer, by the Minister of the Church, or if he should be reluctant by Dr Richard Storrs the Minister of the next Orthodox Church at Braintree— And so the arrangement was concluded— Mr George S. Foster is a young man, a member of the Young Men’s Henry Clay Association of New York.— He came for the purpose of persuading me to attend at their mass meeting next Wednesday, and to deliver over again that evening in the Tabernacle, my address to the young Men of Boston— I told him how much I regretted that I could not perform and that I had answered the invitation from Mr Halsey to that effect. He then said that they would have a printing press in the procession, and want an address to be struck off and circulated while the procession is moving. He urged me very warmly to write such an address but I declined. I wasted too much time and a little anger upon a Letter of Langdon Cheves about the Tariff, Texas, Nullification and disunion— Evening not idle.

17. IV. Thursday.  Sun rose 6.14. behazed Set 5.17. beclouded  I received my manuscript of the Address, from the Atlas Office, but its publication in pamphlet form is yet problematical.— I have revised the errors of the publication in the Atlas, and have made up 20 copies and distributed them among several individuals my friends in several quarters of the Union— I shall soon be called to reply—to furious assaults from the worthies, whose characters and exploits I have brought in relief before the civilized world.— My main object now is the address to my Constituents to be delivered on the 30th. of this month—but in the review of the proceedings at the last Session of Congress I must make a selection of the topics which I am to discuss.— They are, 1. The choice of a Speaker whose election was contested. 2. The prostration of the Law prescribing elections by single districts. 3. The exclusion from the Journals of the protest against the subversion of the Law. 4. The abortive effort to discard the gag rule which I am yet discussing. Then come the Massachusetts Resolutions and the proceedings of the House upon them— The bill to refund Jackson’s fine— The threatened repeal of the Tariff of 1842.— The Oregon fever.— The Texas fever and Treaty— The Treaty with the German Customs Union, and the complicated intrigues and cabaling for the annexation of Texas; with the three Baltimore Conventions— The whig nomination of Henry Clay, and Theodore Frelinghuysen— The mock democratic nomination of John Tyler without a Vice President— The smuggled nomination of James K. Polk, and George M. Dallas— The political contortions of John C. Calhoun, and the disunion schemes of R. Barnwell Rhett and Langdon Cheves, all form a compound subject for discoursing to my Constituents. Of all these I must make a selection of which the Slave representation may be the common bond— A large portion of my time this day was consumed in a revolutionary Letter of Langdon Cheves. There is an almost insuperable difficulty in my way, that I cannot discuss these matters without bearing upon the Presidential canvas— Mr Beale and his two daughters spent the Evening here— It was my only interruption, yet I was up till 11. at Night.— I received the first and second number of a new weekly Newspaper, published at Boston called the Plain Dealer—professing Democracy, but striking at the prominent Men of all parties—except Thomas H. Benton.

18. V. Friday.  The pressure upon my brain increases and my time becomes so totally absorbed in writing that I have now Memory for scarcely any thing that passes from day to day. This day, besides the journal of yesterday I wrote four pages of my task, an atchievement which I shall probably never again perform. Mr G. W. Bryant came from North Bridgewater, and invited me to go and address a meeting of the people there— He said the Liberty party were making very great exertions there, and were speciall working for a concert with the Democracy; and they were detaching so many from the whigs, that they were apprehensive of losing the election of their candidate to represent the town in the State Legislature— I told him that I had promised to address the people of the 8th. Congressional District on the 30th. of this Month— I had left it to the whig Committee of the District to fix upon the place where the Address should be delivered, and I understood they had agreed upon Weymouth landing.— But I could divide my address in two, and deliver part of it at one place and part at another, and if he would see Mr Francis Hilliard of Roxbury, Mr Brigham of this town, Minott Thayer of Braintree or Thomas Loring of Hingham, and could make an arrangement with them, I would go to North-Bridgwater at any one or two days before or after the meeting at Weymouth landing. Doctor Nathaniel Miller of Franklin, came also to enquire if I could not visit that town or that part of the County, where he said the Liberty party were extremely busy and courting favour with the Democracy— He made some enquiries about the deputation from that party which visited me, and particularly about M. M. Fisher of Medway. At their convention at Dedham there were 55 votes taken of which there were 36. for Appleton Howe 14 for me, and 5 for this Mr Fisher. Their Presidential Candidate James G. Birney has come to Boston to electioneer for himself— He has been nominated by a Convention of Democrats at Saginaw in the State of Michigan, as a member of the State Legislature, and is throwing off his mask, and still trying to hide his face behind it— This coalition secretly concerted and just now coming out in its true colours will certainly break down the election in this 8th. District for the next Congress. I hope I may not take it too much at heart, but that it will prepare me for retirement for the rest of my days.

19. IV. Saturday.  Warm rain with a furious storm of wind all last night and continued all the morning of this day.— I still drudge without seeing when I can come to a close— I received this morning a Letter from John P. Kennedy of Baltimore, thanking me for my exposure of that infamous fraud concocted by Andrew Jackson, George W. Erving, Aaron Vail Brown, and Charles J. Ingersoll, with the two Lewises and other understrappers, for the destruction of my character; and to accomplish the annexation of Texas and a fourth part of Mexico to the United States. But he gives me warning that I shall have the whole swarm of hornets upon me; and I must make up my mind to meet them— In the progress of my address to my Constituents I am now coming to the encounter with the deepest, the cunningest and the foulest rascal of them all— With the bold dashing utterly base and baseless lies of Andrew Jackson, I shall have not much trouble, and no danger but of assassination not by him, but by one or another of his blood-hounds. With George W. Erving, I shall have easy work if I can get hold of him; for his revelations have not yet been made public, and I only know that the Statements drawn from them by Jackson, Brown and Ingersoll are all equally false— Brown’s Note, upon Jackson’s Letter is of itself enough to demolish him—he can never get over it.— Ingersoll’s falsehoods, are more cautiously covered and more dexterously combined— There is cunning as well as impudence in his publishing his report as the report of the Committee of foreign Affairs, although they rejected it— The mountebank mock solemnity with which he announces the revelations of George W. Erving to Jackson, may not perhaps be so easy to turn into ridicule, nor will it be so light a task to unravel his web of sophistry and chicanery, woven from Ervings sleezy threads, as to unty the coarse and clumsy knots of Jackson and Brown— To an impartial jury I should have but a plain tale to tell and the whole fabrick of knavery would fall to pieces—but with prejudice, faction, false popularity and unbridled profligacy, what will be the event?— The odds are fearful— May God defend the right— This afternoon Walter Hellen went into Boston with My Granddaughter Mary Louisa— She remained there at my Son’s house. He returned early in the Evening— Mrs De Windt came in this Evening from her residence at Fishkill landing. She comes alone to visit her unfortunate Son, John who is at Dr Bell’s at Charlestown— Her daughter Anna Maria is at Brattleborough—Vermont.— Sore afflictions.

20. IV.30. Sunday.  Sun rose 6.18. Set 5.13. Fahrenheit 30.  Mr Lunt preached this morning from Matthew 21.28. [“]But what think ye? A certain man had two sons; and he came to the first and said, Son, go work to-day in my vineyard. 29. He answered and said, I will not: but afterward he repented, and went. 30. And he came to the second and said likewise. And he answered and said, I go, sir, and went not. 31. Whether of them twain did the will of his father— They say unto him the first”— The discourse was a comme̅n̅y upon the whole parable, and one of the most pleasing Sermons I ever heard from Mr Lunt— He dissected the whole story—filled up the outline of the contrasted character of the two Sons—delineated the characters of two others, who might be of the same family— The one who upon being commanded by his father to go, work upon his vineyard, should answer at once I go, and should actually go—the best of the family—and the worst who should on receiving the command, should refuse obedience and act accordingly— He remarked upon almost every separate word of the narrative. Go Work—expatiated on the Nature of the command to work—active and useful industry—to day not waiting till to-morrow—and he closed with an Arabian Apologue about Bén Hassan to whom a Genius came and called him up to do some act of diligence, but who pleaded for indulgence from day to day, till Death came in the place of the Genius and would listen to no delay.— Mr Lunt occasionally digressed from the parable to the context and remarked upon the manner in which he avoided answering the question by what authority he performed his miracles—retorting upon them by a question whether they think the baptism of John from Heaven or of men? and when they answer they cannot tell he rejoins neither tell I you by what authority I act, not saying as they did that he cannot tell, but predicating his refusal upon their pretence of inability— Mrs De Windt left us this afternoon, and went to Mr John Angiers at Medford. She had come from Albany last Thursday, to Mr George T. Bigelow’s at Boston, and came out last evening with Mr and Mrs Bigelow from Boston.— Mr Lunts afternoon Sermon was from 1. John 3.7. [“]Little children, let no man deceive you. He that doeth righteousness is righteous, even as he is righteous”—that is as Christ the Son of God is righteous— The doctrine is that all righteousness consists of deeds and not of words— The Acadia Steamer arrived from Liverpool this afternoon at 4. O’Clock at Boston— At 2 and at half past 3 I had looked for her from the hill, but did not see her.

21. IV 15. Monday  Sun rose 6.19. Set 5.11. Fahrenheit 28.  Bright Northern light when I rose.  Mr Bryant, the chairman of the whig club at North Bridgewater came again, and I agreed with him to go there and address the People at ten O’Clock in the morning, rain, snow or shine on Wednesday the 6th. of next Month— I am to go to Bennet’s Hotel, and must be there by 9 in the morning— While he was here, Mr C. C. P. Waterman of Sandwich on Cape Cod came with an invitation from Zenas R. Hinckley and five others a Committee of the whigs of that Town, to meet and address them, when it will best suit my convenience— I was obliged to decline this, having undertaken already more than I fear I shall be able to perform—that is to address my Constituents twice at two different places before I go to Washington, and before the approaching election— I have also received written invitations from W. D. Ely Corresponding Secretary of the Young Men’s Institute at Hartford Connt. to open a course of Lectures for the Winter for them there; in a Letter of 8 October transmitted to me with one of 17. October, from Boston, from John P. Putnam— From H. S. M’Call, Chairman of the Lecture Committee of the Young Mens Association at Albany to address them on my way to Washington, about the middle of November.— From Charles A. Stetson, and four others, who have resolved upon a public celebration in aid of the funds of the Washington Monument Association in New-York on the 25th. of November next— They say the occasion will be one of peculiar interest and my presence and participation in the ceremonies are earnestly and respectfully solicited— These with multitudes of others, of little comparative interest remain unanswered. An old Clergyman from Providence, by the name of Thomas Williams, who has been here before came with a young man, named Jonas Reynolds Perkins a son of the Minister at the Weymouth Landing, a graduate three years since of Brown University, and now a student at Law, with Mr Coffin of New Bedford, and had a long conversation with me upon speculative politics and religion. I deposited at the stone Bank an order of my Son upon the Merchant’s Bank—Boston, for 500 dollars, and drew 200 which I gave to my wife for her journey to Washington, and 100 for my current expenses here. I called at the Aurora Office and asked Mr Clapp if he proposed to publish my Address to the young Men’s whig club at Boston— He said he would, and I promised him a revised copy, from the Boston Atlas— My Son came out from Boston with Mary-Louisa but returned almost immediately to Boston, himself— My wife had intended to take her departure for Washington this day, but was deterred by the prospect of foul weather and postponed her journey till to-morrow—

22. IV. Tuesday.  Sun rose 6.21. Set 5.10.  In my Address to the young Men’s whig club at Boston, I alluded to an incident in the Roman History merely from Memory, and in my extreme hurry I hazarded it, without verifying it by recurrence to Rollin or Livy— After the delivery of the discourse, I have felt a desire to verify my recollection of the facts and asked Walter Hellen and Mary-Louisa, to look it up in Rollin— I found it myself this morning, first in Rollin, and afterwards in Livy, 3.71— The event occurred in the 309th. year ab urbe condita—at the close of a war with the AEqui and Volsci— The dispute was between the Ardeates and Aricini and the people were wheedled into the judgment by an old soldier 83 years of age named Scaptius who started up in the Assembly of the people and declared that he would not suffer his country to be cheated out of her property— That he himself had fought in the battle when that same territory was taken, and would not without remonstrance see it taken away. The People and their Tribunes took fire— The Consuls and Senators struggled in vain to shame them out of their self-degradation in adjudicating the territory to themselves— Scaptius and the tribunes prevailed and the territory was re-annexed— This consultation of Livy was a temptation to dally with Time, to commune with him further but I broke away from him and wrote four pages of my proposed address, besides the journal of yesterday— I took nevertheless to Mr Clapp the publisher of the Quincy Aurora, the Boston Atlas of the 9th. with the errors of the press in my address to the young men’s whig club at Boston— He said he would publish it in two papers commencing next week, and would send me proof sheets to revise before the publication— My wife postponed again her departure for Washington till to-morrow— But she went this afternoon with Mrs John Adams, Mary-Louisa, and Walter Hellen into Boston, and took tea at my Son’s, with his wife.— He himself was dining at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s, with Mr. Daniel D. Barnard of Albany, who came to Boston to deliver a Lecture before the Boston Lyceum and an Address to the young men’s whig club; which last took place last evening. The party got back this evening about 9. O’Clock. While they were gone Mr and Mrs. Goodrich (he the author of Peter Parley[)] came and took tea with us. He afterwards delivered a political address to the whigs of Quincy at the town Hall, which for want of time I did not attend.

23. V. Wednesday.  Sun rose 6.22. beclouded. Fahrenheit 32  Immediately after rising this morning I saw for the first time this Season my old acquaintance Arcturus about 5 minutes risen— I had been looking for him about a fortnight from the direction of the two Stars in the tail of Calisto, and should no doubt have seen him some days earlier had there been a clear sky. His rise now is from 5 to ten minutes before five— Walter Hellen went into Boston in the Stage at nine O’Clock and precisely at 2 p.m. my wife, with Mrs John Adams, Mary Louisa, and the black boy William Queen went into Boston in our own Carriage. I went with them, and reaching the depot of the Western Rail-road opposite the United States Hotel at 3. found Walter Hellen waiting there, and my Son, to see them off. They took their seats in the car for Springfield, and found Mr Barnard going the same way, on his return to Albany— At a quarter past 3 they started, and I went with Charles to his house— I saw there his wife and daughter—but none of the sons. Mrs Charles was in her chamber, feeble, but not so much indisposed as she was the last ten days at Quincy— At 4. I went with Charles to Mr Josiah Quincy’s where we dined, with a company with whom I should meet no where else—President Quincy; Mrs Greene his daughter with her husband—Mr Brimmer the Mayor of the city—Mr Cary the son in Law of Thomas H. Perkins—Isaac P. Davis—Doctor Howe, Director and Secretary of the Perkins Institution and Massachusetts Asylum for the blind, and Henry W. Longfellow Smith Professor of the French and Spanish Languages and Literature, and Professor of Belles Lettres, at Harvard University— A literary and somewhat Scientific Society— I had ordered Benjamin to be with the Carriage at Mr Quincy’s door at 6. but it was half past 7. before I left the table— I came home by Moonlight and reached my house shortly before the sound of the curfew bell at 9. O’Clock— Our parlor family is now reduced to my Cousin Louisa Catherine Smith and me.  Isaac P. Davis told me that there were in the Globe Newspaper of last Saturday and Monday two long Articles on my address to the young men’s whig club in Boston.— My Son is to go to deliver a political address to-morrow, at Fitchburg in the County of Worcester, and the evening after he is to discourse at Lynn.— While I was at Boston this afternoon Mr Minott Thayer called at my house with an invitation for me, and all my friends to dine with him next Wednesday, after the delivery of my Address, an invitation which annoys me greatly. I endeavoured this evening after retiring to my chamber to redeem the loss of the morning but found it impracticable.— Took to my bed before ten.

24. III.40. Thursday.  Sun rose 6.23. Set 5.7. Hoar frost.  I saw Sirius again, about 5 minutes risen. He rose, as near as I can estimate 10 minutes before 5.— The morning was very chilly. The Sun rose perfectly clear and his Southern strides are now visible from one day to another— The pressure upon my time and nerves is indescribable. Mr S. T. Armstrong has been one of the truest friends that I have met with in this world.— He came out from Boston this morning to invite me to dine with him which I engaged to do, this day fortnight the 7th. of November— He was present and heard my address to the young men’s whig club at Boston. He retains more of any discourse of mine that he hears than any other person. He told me this day that he had never before heard that the value of amber was increased by the preservation of insects in it— I found the fact stated in Rees’s Encyclopaedia— This afternoon Miss Catherine Thaxter called here with a cousin of hers, apparently of a later generation whom she introduced as Miss Susan Thaxter.— Catherine spoke of my father and mother, and said she was here at the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage—which was of course the 25th. of October 1814. and she well remembered hearing my father say then to my mother that he loved her as dearly as he did on the wedding day.— The Revd. Jonas Perkins minister of the Church in Braintree at the Weymouth landing called towards evening— There is the place where on the 17th. of September 1842 I addressed my Constituents of the then 10th. District and there is the place where I am to address next Wednesday my Constituents of the present 8th. District— As the performance is to be introduced by a religious invocation, Mr Perkins asked me, if I should have any objection to that solemnity’s being performed by Mr Thomas Williams of Providence, who was here a few days since. I said none, if it would be agreeable to Mr Perkins himself.— He said Mr Williams had expressed to him his wish to officiate and he was willing to gratify him— I requested Mr Perkins if he should on his way home pass by Mr Minott Thayer’s house, to call on him, and say to him that I was grateful to him for his kind invitation to dinner on that day, but that I shall be obliged to return home to dine—and that I begged him not to be at any expence for entertaining any company on that day— My feelings are very different at the prospect of this meeting, from what they were on that occasion— All is now gloomy and discouraging, with a double opposition before me, and all but a certainty of failing to carry the election.

25. IV:40. Friday  Sun rose 6.24. Set 5.5.— Hoar frost. F. 30.  My only interruption of a visitor this day was Mr Lunt who brought me a Letter from the Revd. C. Briggs, inviting me to deliver a Lecture at the opening of the Lyceum in Roxbury two or three weeks hence— I have not time even to answer the invitation, and have numbers of unanswered invitations before me— But I wrote this day the journal of yesterday, and four pages of the address for next Wednesday at Braintree. This hurried composition however has so pernicious effect upon the style, that my heart sinks within me at the thought of what I am going to deliver, and my only hope is in striking about half of what I have written. About half an hour before dinner I took a walk round the garden, nursery and Orchard, looking into the seminary— The desolation of the Season cast a gloom on my spirits— The fruit has been gathered from all the trees except one bearing Quince tree on the borders of the pond— The ground is strewed with sere red and yellow leaves—the ground is wet and gathered in clods— Kirke has taken up a number of my seedlings and cut down others— Most of the large trees are mere stems, stripd of all their leaves— I hastened in from this prospect to dinner— I afterwards met in the garden Mrs Green the daughter of Mr and Mrs Kirk, wife of John A. Green editor of the Quincy Patriot— I had not seen her since her marriage, and did not at first know her— Again as the Sun went down, I walked up the Hill to Charles’s house to see the Sun set. But although it was not quite 5. O’Clock the Sun was already behind Mount Ararat.— I went further over the hill and surveyed the village, the surrounding country; the harbour and bay of Boston. The State house of Boston itself and the shaft of the Bunker-hill Monument; and Memory returned to the fact that this day 80 years ago, my father and mother were united in marriage— What an ordo seculorum commenced for me from that day. What was then the condition of the People who then constituted the town of Braintree— What is the condition of the People of the three towns of Quincy, Braintree and Randolph now? And what will be the condition of the occupiers of the soil of these three towns in 80 years from this day? The recollection of the past is pleasing and melancholy— The prospect of the future— Oh! how gloomy it is! Not a soul now lives, who was then in the bloom of life— Not a soul now living will be here in 1924.— My own term—how soon it will close! And to whom will all this belong in 80 years from this day? Will prayer to God preserve the branches and shoots from my father’s Stock What a phantasmagoria is human life!

26. IV. Saturday  Sun rose 6.24. Set 5.4. behind Mount Ararat.  Mr Loring was here this morning alarmed at the double opposition of the democracy and the Liberty party, each playing into the other’s hands to defeat my election—each holding up an ex-Senator from the County of Norfolk in the State Legislature against me; neither expecting to elect their own candidate, but purposely combining to exclude me— I have no doubt of their success, and only ask to meet the exigency with a proper spirit. Leavitt in the morning Chronicle, hints that the object of the Liberty party in defeating my election is to force me upon the Legislature as a candidate for the Senate and then to give a chance for Appleton Howe’s election as the member for the District.— The electioneering of the Liberty party from Birney their head down—is more knavish than that of either of the others— Mr John Belcher of Randolph came and said he was deputed by the whigs of that place to invite me to visit and address them; which I told him, would much to my regret be impossible— He said they had no hopes of carrying a majority for me in that town but would do, what they could— Mrs John Angier of Medford, and Mrs Susan Boyd with her infant daughter Anna were here— Mrs Angier spoke to me of her deposit in the Life Insurance Company the annual income from which she had requested three or four years ago might be left to accumulate, she now desires to receive all the interest that has accumulated and whatever may hereafter accrue from year to year— Mrs Angier has an extraordinary taste for painting and I saw on Wednesday last at my Sons house a beautiful head of a child in water colours painted by her— I had received a pretty Letter this morning from Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherine, urging me to go into Boston and spend as much of next week there as I can, as she is going next Saturday to Mrs Sedgwick’s school at Lenox and will probably not see me again for a year or more— She was to come out with her father this morning but was unwell and did not come— He came out with his two sons Charles and Henry; dined with us and returned to Boston— I had visits this afternoon from Edward Brooks and Thomas W. Phillips a son of my old friend John Phillips and a brother of Wendell Phillips. I finished this morning my proposed address to my Constituents and am so exceedingly disgusted with it that I made an attempt to begin anew with an introduction which may touch the interests of my hearers themselves.

27. V. Sunday  I was somewhat disturbed in the Night, and not a little disordered through the course of this day. Mr Lunt had told me that he should preach at home this day but he exchanged with Mr Stearns of Hingham. The morning text was from Matthew 18.14. [“]Even so it is not the will of your Father which is in heaven that one of these little ones should perish”— The Sermon had obviously been composed by way of consolation to some person who has lost a child. Jonathan Bass had a note up for the loss of a grand child; and the father and mother one for the loss of their child. I suppose the discourse was adapted to this occasion and perhaps may administer comfort to some persons.— But Rachel refused to be comforted for her children because they were not.— This eighteenth chapter of Matthew is a fruitful field of meditation. It begins by stating that after the transfiguration, Jesus being at Capernaum, and having performed a miracle to procure money to pay tribute for himself and for Peter, the disciples came and asked him who should be greatest in the kingdom of heaven— Was there not some connection between his paying the tribute and that question—and surely there was a rebuke in his answer.— He told them that they who made themselves like little children would be the greatest in the kingdom of heaven and that no others would be admitted there.— Then he gave them that mysterious charge if any of their own members offended them to cast them off, and proceeds to say that it is not the will of their heavenly father that any one of the little ones should perish— Other injunctions of infinite importance follow, and the parable of the two debtors— Mr Stearns stopped at the promise to little children that none of them shall perish. He argued that they come into the world for a wise and benevolent purpose—that they afford comfort to their parents while they live, and that however prematurely taken away they leave to those whose affections they have engaged here the hope of meeting them in bliss hereafter.— The contemplation is sad and we can come after all to no other conclusion than resignation and submission to the will of heaven. Mr Stearns dined with Louisa C. Smith and me, and preached in the afternoon from John 13.34. “A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another.” Love is the essence of Christianity—but the love enjoined by this precept is not precisely the same with that commanded for the neighbour.— Love is a song of degrees— Parental filial conjugal love, friendship, gratitude, veneration, compassion are all diversified forms of one benevolent impulse of the heart, which the Christian must cherish and regulate.

28. V. Monday.  A stormy Night, and stormy day succeeding it. No rain yesterday—not much last Night or this day but an occasional drizzling mist, and a heavy North-eastern gale through both days. I am still disordered and was up twice last Night. Mr Charles Clapp, editor of the Quincy Aurora brought me this morning a proof page of his next Thursday’s paper, containing about half of my address to the Boston young men’s whig club reprinted from the Atlas Newspaper, with my revisal— I examined it without discovering any error in it— There are several errors in the Atlas copy—among which the substitution of the word vaccination for buccination which is ridiculous; and the more provoking as buccination was a word of my own coinage, which I ventured for its peculiar point in the application—for the sake of the walk a took back to Mr Clapp his proof page— Of the Letters that I received this day there was one from Abbott Lawrence, enclosing two to him from David S. Brown, and Charles W. Churchman, both of Philadelphia— Brown is a Quaker; both dated the 24th. stating that Daniel L. Miller junr. a respectable young Quaker and abolitionist would write me that same day a Letter of enquiries about Polk and Clay and Texas, and intreating Mr Lawrence to urge me to answer Miller’s enquiries, because many Quaker and abolition votes would depend upon my answer.— By the same mail there came to myself a Letter from Joseph R. Chandler, Charles Gibbons President of the National Clay Club, A. J. Lewis, Nathan Sargent, and Charles W. Churchman notifying me of this Letter of enquiries from Daniel L. Miller junr and urging me to answer it— Then two Letters from Miller both of the same date, one giving me notice of the other which contains three questions for my opinion— 1. Whether the Election of H. Clay would defeat the Texas-annexation.— 2. Whether the election of Polk would ensure it? 3. Whether the annexation of Texas would advance or retard the abolition of Slavery? I wrote a joking answer but know not how he will take it— I could not with propriety write any other— It is curious how the Polecat rascals work upon the Quakers, and to what base uses electioneering is turned— All the rest of this day, and until 11. at Night I was writing upon my address for next Wednesday— I want another week to finish it as a new draft— It will now be a thing of shreds and patches of which I am heart-sick.

29. IV:45. Tuesday.  The storm finally terminated by rain falling in torrents which began in the course of the last Night and all the former part of this day. Towards Sunset the storm subsided The Northeastern gale gradually sunk to a calm— A soft, damp, clammy state of the atmosphere succeeded still covered with murky clouds till as the Night darkened the stars of the western horizon first appeared, and before I retired to bed at 11. P.M. the sky was clear and waning moon was bright— What small incidents cheer or depress the Spirits! I was fretting all day with the terror of a similar day to morrow, and to the prospect of having to go tomorrow to Braintree through floods of rain, and then to deliver the address to empty walls— The brightening sky as I closed the writing of my address was delicious— A promise of a fair day to morrow; and I found upon a review, that the new introductory written since I finished the first draught last Saturday, with the last half of the first draught, would make a sufficiently well compacted discourse for a delivery of two full hours and I was at my ease.— But nothing less than the incessant toil of writing from the day after I addressed the young whigs of Boston could have produced this result. Though often called to extemporize I never do it with any satisfaction to myself— This morning as the floods of rain were falling a young man named Seymour, came on horseback from Boston, where he had arrived, by the night passage from New-York— He brought me a Letter from J. R. S. Van Vleet, Chairman of the Committee of arrangements of the whigs of New-York, who are to have another great procession of trades to-morrow among which will be the Printers; and they want me to write a short address to the People which they may print with my name, while they are moving— I told this young man it was impossible, being engaged day and Night in preparing an Address to be delivered to the People of my own district, to-morrow— He asked for a written answer, but I thought a verbal one sufficient.— The poor young man said he was very unwell and had not slept last Night— I pitied him— Mr Thomas Tileston came with his brother James, to ask the Manuscript of my address of tomorrow to print in the Courier with which he is connected— I told him it was engaged to the Atlas— He then spoke for the Address to be delivered at North Bridgwater next week, which I promised.

30. V. Wednesday.  Sun rose 6.31. Set 4.58.  I rose with gratitude for the clear blue sky and saw the Sun rise from my Son’s house on the hill— The meeting was announced for half past ten— I went with Louisa C. Smith to Mr Minott Thayer’s house, where I was received by him with his accustomed kindness— There were about half a dozen persons there, chiefly those named in the margin— With Mr Putnam was Mr Simmons of Roxbury— Mrs Fogg an old Lady turned of 80, a sister of Mr Thayer, infirm and unable to leave her chamber sent a message requesting me to come up and see her, which I did— Her son and his wife were also there and live with Mr Thayer, who is a bachelor nearly of my age. Mrs Fogg knew my father, mother and all the family in the time of her and my childhood, but I was so early in my days absent from the country that she remembered not having ever seen me. Nor did I. There was a procession formed to meet me at Mr Thayer’s house and escort me to the Meeting house—with a small musical band; and Major Thomas Adams of Quincy was the Marshall. But the procession assembled slowly and it was past 11. before they came— I marched between Mr Thayer and Mr Francis Hilliard— There was a stand on a platform in front of the pulpit with a large folio bible upon it; and upon that bible I read my Address— The choir in the organ loft sung the hymn America— The Revd. Thomas Williams read the Chapter 1. Samuel 12.5 verses and made a short prayer. Mr Francis Hilliard, chairman of the District whig Committee, announced me as about to address the meeting, which I did for about two hours and a quarter; after which Mr Hilliard announced that there would be another meeting at the same place at half past 3. in the afternoon, but that I should not be present— I returned to Mr Minott Thayer’s, where there was a table laid for dinner and several friends there. Mr Thayer urged me to stay; but I had sent him word last week that I should be obliged to come home to dinner as I did with Miss Smith.— My address was well received.— The house was not filled. The democracy, had stretched a Polk and Dallas flag across the way under which the procession was to pass, but the wind blew it down— We got home at half-past two, well satisfied and grateful for the day.

31. IV:30. Thursday.  Mr Thomas Tileston reporter for the Boston Courier was at the meeting at Braintree yesterday, and an abridged report of my address appears in the Courier of this morning. Mr Brewer of the Atlas Office was also there, who had written to me to ask my manuscript for it; and I gave it to him with a request that a proof sheet should be sent to me for revisal— While I was at dinner yesterday Mr Joseph Holmes of Kingston Plymouth County came in to enquire what was the condition of his petition to Congress about the Schooner Industry— I could not recollect, but left my dinner and looked over the Journal of the House of the last Session, and found nothing there concerning it.— Mr Holmes was in a stage, and had promised the driver not to detain him more than five minutes.— I promised him to look over the journals farther and ascertain and inform him— My last evening was not unoccupied, but I could only bring up my diary of the day before— This morning I was shortened for time, and came into Boston with Louisa C. Smith. Left her at Mr James H. Foster’s in Bedford Street, and came to my Son’s house 57. Mount Vernon Street— He went away yesterday to make speeches somewhere— Mrs Charles and her children are here.— At noon I attended a meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society at which 28 members were present— It was rather jocular than dignified and adjourned soon after one. An invitation was received from the New-York historical Society, to attend their anniversary Meeting on the 20th. of November— A Committee of five members was appointed to attend as a delegation from this Society and a Resolution was adopted that any other member of the Society who should be at New-York at that time should also attend as a delegate— Mr Saltonstall came in; just as the meeting was about to adjourn— Walking with me to the Atlas-Office he expressed his utter detestation of the Texas-annexation project. Mr Hayden of the Atlas Office had the manuscript of my yesterday’s address, and promised to send me to-morrow by 6. P.M a proof sheet to revise— I purchased at Libbey’s 159. Washington Street, a signet ring for my wife, and a breast pin for my granddaughter Louisa Catherine— I dined with a small party at my old friend ex-judge John Davis’s, his two widowed daughters being at table. At half past 3. we went to the Mason’s temple, and found Mr. John G Palfrey, commencing a Discourse on the 50th. anniversary of the Massachusetts Historical Society—very well written and handsomely delivered. I returned to my Son’s house, and spent the Evening with his wife and children, after calling at Mr. Abbott Lawrence’s— Not at home—

1. IV:30. Friday.  My Son had left a Letter signed by Mr. Nathaniel Curtis and himself as Executors and Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston, to the Selectmen of Princeton, proposing an amicable chancery suit in the Supreme Court of the State, to ascertain the right of the town, and the duty of the Executors, concerning a bequest, which was to take effect after the decease of Mrs. Alicia Boylston— I signed the Letter and it was sent this morning. Also an answer to my wife’s Letter of last Saturday from Baltimore. This morning before breakfast I brought up my diary, and then gave the day to visitation of my friends— I gave my Granddaughter Louisa-Catherine, the breast pin I had purchased for her yesterday— I called on Mitchell the engraver with the signet ring I purchased for her yesterday, and gave an order to engrave the Lion crest and the initial A. on the Cornelian stone— At Dr. George Parkman’s former residence I found he had removed to N. 1. Joy place, Belknap Street— I visited at the houses of H. G. Otis, Edward Brooks, Robert C. Winthrop and John Davis, and found no one of them at home. I had found Joseph Hall, 83 years old verging upon the very last stage of life, with his Sister not so old but as decayed, a melancholy contemplation of human life; but still he received me with a warm welcome. I was going to Dr. Frothingham’s when I met his wife in the Street who told me he was at New-York, and she expect him to return to-morrow. at Mr James H. Foster’s I saw his wife and daughter Elizabeth— I had met their daughters Mary and Louisa at Dr Frothingham’s door— I met also President Quincy in the Street, and first mentioned to him the idea of having short Memoirs of the Lives of the persons, whose Portraits are at the historical Society, with an engraving of one of the Portraits published in every future volume of the Society— I was ten minutes at my Son’s office where I saw Mr. A. C. Spooner. Found Mr Abbott Lawrence at home, and spent half an hour with him and Mrs and Miss Lawrence. Dined at Charles’s. Louisa C. Smith also dined there. After dinner I called at Dr. George Parkman’s, and passed an hour with him Mrs Parkman and their Son— About 7 this Evening my Son returned home from his political excursion to Ashburnham, Ashby, and Winchenden. I received in the course of the evening successively five columns from the Atlas office, from 7. to 11. O’Clock after I was in bed, of proof of my address at Braintree— There was still a column left, which I sent them word to publish without waiting for my revisal.

2. V:45. Saturday.  At half past 6 this morning My Son took his daughter Louisa Catherine to the Cars for Springfield.— She goes with Mrs Charles Sedgwick who resides and keeps a boarding school at Lenox, of only 8 girls— Louisa is to remain there one year— Mr Chapman late Mayor of Boston called to see me, and for an answer to an invitation which I had received to visit Medway and address the whigs there next Thursday or Friday. I declined having already taken cold and made myself so hoarse that it is doubtful whether I shall be able to speak next Wednesday at North-Bridgwater— I received also a Letter from Mr Bryant of that place enquiring by which road, I propose to go there, as some of the Citizens, wish to come out and meet me— This too I declined and answered Mr Bryant’s Letter, intimating a doubt whether, the state of my health and particularly of my voice will permit me to go at the appointed time. I visited Mr Robert C. Winthrop, and had a long conversation with him respecting his relative George W. Erving, his base treatment of me, and my public notices of him— I told Mr Winthrop, that when before the close of the session of Congress he gave me Charles J. Ingersoll’s, View of the Texas question and I observed to him my astonishment at the disclosure of Erving’s conduct, never having in the course of forty years acquaintance given him the slightest cause of offence; but having even named him to Mr Monroe as a candidate for the mission to France, and Winthrop said he would communicate to Mr Erving what I said;— I did purposely intend to give Mr Erving time to offer any explanation or apology to me—which the occasion required to repair the wrong he had done me.— He has not done it. By the Letter to Winthrop, from which he read me lately an extract, he expresses his regret at having assailed me; admits that I had given him no cause for it, and says that Jackson had gone far beyond any thing that he had said to him would warrant. But he had offered neither excuse, apology nor explanation to me, and in handling him as I have been compelled to do I have acted with extreme reluctance. I assured Mr Winthrop also that my Son would countenance no design or attempt to place him in competition with him, and that he would have my best wishes for his continuance in his present station as long as it would be agreeable to him and for his promotion to any other office of higher dignity and importance. He expressed much gratification at these assurances; but said he had determined not to serve in Congress after this next election— My next call was at the Atlas Office, where Mr Hayden returned me the manuscript of my Address at Braintree. It is published at full length in the Atlas of this morning, five columns. Small type— By these two Addresses, to the young men’s whig club at Boston and to my Constituents of the 8th. Congressional District I have put myself upon trial by God, and my Country. May God be my judge. With Louisa C. Smith whom I took up at Mr Foster’s I came out this afternoon to Quincy.

2. V:45. Saturday.  At half past 6 this morning My Son took his daughter Louisa Catherine to the Cars for Springfield.— She goes with Mrs Charles Sedgwick who resides and keeps a boarding school at Lenox, of only 8 girls— Louisa is to remain there one year— Mr Chapman late Mayor of Boston called to see me, and for an answer to an invitation which I had received to visit Medway and address the whigs there next Thursday or Friday. 3. IV:30. Sunday.  Sun rose. 6:35. Set 4.53.  The Steamer Hibernia arrived last Night about 11. O’Clock having left Liverpool the 19th. of last Month. I looked in vain for her therefore in crossing the hill going to and returning from meeting— Mr Lunt preached this morning from 2. Timothy 1.7. [“]For God hath not given us the spirit of fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind”— This Epistle was written from Rome it is said when Paul was brought before Nero the second time— It was certainly very shortly before his martyrdom.— It is evidently written under great distress—in prison, abandoned by almost all his associates, some of whom he names, particularly those from Asia, his tone of complaint is not boisterous, nor pusillanimous but moderate, calm, without invective, and firm, specially exhorting Timothy to stand firm in the discharge of his duties, reminding him that the cause for which he suffers, is the purpose and grace of God “given us in Christ Jesus before the world began, but now made manifest by the appearing of our Saviour Jesus Christ, who hath abolished death, and hath brought life and immortality through the gospel:”— This is the cause with regard to which he says God hath not given us the spirit of Fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind. Mr Lunt as is his usual practice analyzed the words of his text and contrasted the Spirit of Fear, with that of the three others named in the text—Power, Love and a sound mind. His description of Fear was almost as graphic as that of Collins in his Ode on the Passions; and he specially noticed the opposition in which it is placed by the Apostle to a sound mind— He observed that a sound mind never admitted Fear— That the passion always disordered the mind, and disabled it for the exercise of its regular functions.— The fear of God itself he said was so qualified by the Spirit of Love, that it lost its evil qualities; but that simple Fear, was of all human qualities that most selfish and base— The closing exhortation to the auditory, to banish the Spirit of Fear, and adhere to those of Power and Love, and a sound mind, was spirited and acceptable.— In the afternoon some what unexpectedly Mr Francis Cunningham a Classmate of my Son appeared in the pulpit and preached from Ecclesiasticus 33.15. [“]So look upon all the works of the most high: and there are two and two, one against another.” There is much wisdom in the Book of Jesus the son of Sirach, but it is not in good taste for a protestant divine to take a text from it for a Sermon; and the Sermon itself was not equal to Mr Lunt’s— Mr Cunningham was a very promising youth— His maturity proves a disappointment.

4. V. Monday.  The weather confined me to the house—dull gloomy with occasional showers. Mr William P. Apthorp, a son of George W. Apthorp formerly of this town but long since deceased came to solicit a contribution for a teacher’s school near Quincy, in the State of Illinois, where he resides and is one of the teachers of the school— The fortunes of that Apthorp family, are impressively melancholy. from Charles Ward Apthorp once a princely merchant of New-York with 20 children, through James Apthorp a Tory, but not a refugee of the revolution with five daughters and two sons, one of whom was George W. the father of this young man.— There is deep tragical romance in the story of almost every member of this family— A brother of this young man, died recently a missionary in the Island of Ceylon— Mr Bennett is the keeper of the Inn at North Bridgwater where I have engaged to go the day after to-morrow to deliver a political address— He came to advise me as to the best road to take in going there, that is, by Braintree, West Randolph and a corner of Stoughton— The distance is 12 miles, and Mr Bennett said there were a number of young men of the town of North Bridgwater and of several adjoining towns, who propose to form a cavalcade, and come 5 or 6 miles and meet and escort me to his house— I told him I had remonstrated against this in a Letter to Mr Bryant last week— But he said they would come, and I promised to take the road to meet them— A young man named John Stocker Freeman came to ask for advice His father named Thomas Freeman, and his mother whose maiden name was Collins, came in 1820 from Leominster in the County of Hereford in England, leaving two infant daughters one of whom was named Mary-Ann—the name of the other he does not know— He was born in Boston in 1821. and in 1823. his mother died in childbed with a daughter who died also— His father about the same time went to see, and he has heard nothing from him for many years— He himself had been brought upon Charity, had been several years at sea, and is now a Journeyman boot and shoemaker at Quincy point.— He had written letters to his Sisters to ascertain whether they were to be found but had received no answer— He wanted advice— I advised him to write again to his Sister, and enclose the Letter to Mr Edward Everett requesting his aid to discover the Sister. He said he would.

5. IV:30. Tuesday  As I came into my library this morning the rain pattering on the windows and the wind howling round the corner of the house announced a Northeastern gale which continued till the afternoon, and then subsided without entirely clearing up.— The young man came again with a Letter to his Sister Mary Ann Freeman, Leominster County of Hereford, England, and one enclosing it to Mr Edward Everett our Minister in England asking his assistance to discover the sister, who he said might perhaps be married, and a certificate of the British Vice Consul at Boston Edmund A Grattan, dated the 19th. day of last July that Mrs Mary S. Smith of Boston personally appeared before him, and in his presence on oath declared that John Stocker Freeman, who had signed his name at the foot of the certificate, was to her certain knowledge the son of Thomas and Mary-Anne Freeman of Leominster in the County Hereford England, and formerly resident of Boston where the said John Stocker Freeman was born on the 23d day of September 1821.— The Deponent was uncertain whether the said Thomas Freeman were still alive or not but farther stated that the said Mary Ann Freeman (otherwise Mary Ann Collins[)] his wife, died in Boston in the month of March A.D 1823. The Letters to the Sister and to Mr Everett are well written, and the signature of the young man to the certificate is in a good hand. I promised to enclose these papers to Mr Everett, and would recommend the enquiries to his special attention— This was the only interruption of this day but I received from Nashville, Tennessee a Newspaper, containing Andrew Jackson’s first Answer to my address to the young men of Boston.— He is in great fury, but totally abandons the charge of the Erwin Treaty— I had been all the morning commenting upon James K. Polk’s Letter declaring his opinion in favour of the immediate annexation of Texas in which he assails me directly by name— And the remainder of the day and evening till 11 at night I was absorbed in writing a reply to Jackson’s letter to Robert Armstrong— The paper was enclosed to me by Boyd M’Nairy— Jackson denies positively that he ever advised the acceptance of the Sabine for the western boundary. Whether he equivocates upon the word advised, or has totally forgotten his interviews with me of 2. and 3. February 1819. The memory of violent men, is always the slave of their passions.— Jackson pledges himself to answer my charge further as soon as he can procure the Erving Manuscripts from Washington—

properties.dateline: Quincy Wednesday 6. November 1844. N. Bridgwater— Quincy.
properties.text: 6. IV:30. Wednesday.  I added this morning one page to my notice of Andrew Jackson’s first answer to my summons in the address to the young men of Boston. I sent Kirk with my compliments to Mr Lunt and invited him to go with me to North Bridgwater, which he accepted— I took him up at his house at 8 O’Clock and we rode through Braintree, West-Randolph, and a corner of Stoughton, to North Bridgwater—12 miles. At West Randolph about half way we were met by a cavalcade of about one hundred men, the leader of whom came up to the carriage, accosted me by name and announced that they were citizens of Norfolk, Bristol and Plymouth Counties who had come to escort me to the place of meeting; for which I returned to them my cordial thanks— They accordingly formed a line and preceded the Carriage to Bennet’s tavern at North Bridgwater— Here I found Mr Bryant the Chairman of the whig Committee who had invited me, with a great crowd of respectable-looking persons from all the neighbouring towns of whom the persons named in the margin were with Thomas French of Canton were nearly all whom I had before known. Many were introduced to me, among whom several Warriors of the Revolution with War worn and time worn faces and forms. At half past ten a procession was formed preceded by a band of martial music and we marched to the meeting house— Mr Seth Sprague junr. of Duxbury presided— They began with a hymn— The Revd. pastor of the Church made a prayer— Mr. Sprague read a written paper complimentary to me, and introduced me.— From a quarter past 11. to half past one. I read from the pulpit with my manuscripts on the Bible my address which was listened to with close attention and well received. Mr Phillips and Mr Sprague read for me Jackson’s Letter to Armstrong and other Newspaper extracts— There was sung another hymn—an afternoon meeting at half past two, at which Mr Phillips was to speak was announced, and we adjourned to a frugal and tempeate dinner at the Inn.— Immediately after which I returned to Quincy left Mr Lunt at his house, and reached home at half past 4. Evening visit from Dr. W. B. Duggan, who invited me to deliver a Lecture next week.

7. IV:30. Thursday.  Sun rose 6:40. Set.  There was a hard frost last night, and ice as thick as window glass was made on the ditch between my house and Charles’s— I saw the Sun rise from the corner of his house, and at 10. O’Clock left home and came in to Boston, leaving Louisa C. Smith, who proposes to pass a day or two with Mrs T. B. Adams.— I came immediately to my Son’s house N. 57. Mount Vernon Street. He had just returned from a tour to Nantucket and New-Bedford, where he has delivered electioneering addresses.— I went to the office of the Boston Courier, and gave Mr Buckingham the manuscripts of my address delivered yesterday at North Bridgwater—with the newspapers containing the Letters of James K. Polk and Andrew Jackson, and his charge about the Erwin Treaty— Buckingham proposes to publish the address on Saturday morning, and promised to send me proof columns of the paper to-morrow afternoon— I called at my Son’s office, and learnt that there is a second Letter from Andrew Jackson in answer to my address to the young men of Boston. This last is addressed to Blair the Editor of the Globe, and calls upon him for help in this controversy— There was great agitation in the streets, especially in State Street on the opposite sides of which are the Atlas and Times Newspaper Offices; before the doors of which crowds were collected awaiting the election returns from New-York— They were then highly favorable to the whig party— Dr. George Parkman called on me at my Son’s house— At 4. O’Clock we went and dined at Mr Samuel T. Armstrong’s, with the company named in the margin, excepting Mr Gorham Brooks, whom we found with Mrs. Charles on our return from the dinner— There was a very numerous democratic torch light procession this evening, who visited the dwelling house of Mr George Bancroft, the Democratic Candidate for the Office of Governor of the Commonwealth.— They were noisy but not otherwise disorderly— Soon after ten I retired to bed, and about midnight was awaked by the firing of 26. guns—the Io Triumphe of the democrats, on receiving the election returns from Albany.

8. IV:30. Friday.  I understood the meaning of the guns fired last night, on receipt of the election returns, from the western Counties of New-York, by the train of Cars from Albany. They settle the Presidential election, and James K. Polk of Tennessee is to be President of the United States for four years from the 4th of March 1845— What the further events of this issue may be—but it will be the signal for my retirement from public life— It is the victory of the Slavery element in the Constitution of the United States. Providence I trust intends it for wise purposes and will direct it to good ends— From the sphere of public action, I must at all events very soon be removed.— My removal now is but a few days in advance of the doom of Nature, and gives me time if I have energy to improve it, which will not be lost. I called this morning on Doctor Frothingham;—and just before reaching his door, met Mrs Isaac P. Davis who accosted me with grievous lamentation over the lost hopes of the election.— With Dr. Frothingham I examined and we construed the whole 16th. Elegy, of the second book of Properties—and we found that there is extant in English a translation in verse of this author, published in 1782. without the name of the translator— I called on judge Davis who condoled with me on the loss of the Presidential election; and also that in the list of stars in Rees’s Encyclopaedia Canopus is omitted— The judge thinks also that in Professor Williams’s account of their expedition to Penobscot to observe the transitthe star which they saw, and which he calls lucida Lyrae was in truth Arcturus— Immediately after dinner at 1/2 past 3. my Son left us to go by the railway cars to Haverhill to address a convocation of whigs there this Evening. I called at Libbey the jeweller’s shop with tufts of hair of Charles and his wife to be wrought into the signet Seal that I have procured for my wife. Mrs Gorham Brooks and Miss Henshaw visited Mrs Charles this afternoon; and Mr Brimmer the Mayor visited me this Evening. As I was passing by Dr. George Parkman came out from his house and walked with me home— Mr Tileston brought me proof Columns from the Courier Office of my North Bridgwater Address, and I passed the Evening with Mrs Charles in correcting it— There was another Cannonade this Evening for the Polk victory in New-York— Whig meeting this Evening at Faneuil Hall—and Daniel Webster’s Native American Speech.

9. IV:30. Saturday.  My Son returned this morning from Haverhill just after we had breakfasted. He attended a numerous whig meeting there last Evening and made a speech. He comes home much gratified that this is the last of the electioneering campaign. There was also an immense meeting of whigs last evening at Faneuil Hall in Boston Daniel Webster was there, and made a speech commencing with What though the field be lost! All is not lost &c— The depression and despondency of the whig party at the issue of the presidential election in the State of New-York is beyond all example or precedent.— A young man by the name of Wheeler from Rutland in the County of Worcester, came this morning to see me. Merely to gratify his curiosity— We conversed about half an hour, upon indifferent topics—but no politics— I recovered the arrears of my journals, and answered an invitation to dinner from Mr David Sears for next Thursday. Accepted. But I can have no tranquility in the city in the daytime. My address at North-Bridgwater was published in the Boston Courier of this morning. On examining it, I found a considerable number of errors of the press.— I read it over, and corrected as many of them as I perceived without finishing I went out—called at Libby the jeweller’s shop, and took the signet ring which I have procured for my wife, under the seal of which is intertwined the hair of my son and his wife. The seal is the lion crest bearing the cross and under it the initial A. Thence I went to the Office of the Courier; where I finished the revisal of my address, and bespoke fifty copies of it which were sent to me at my Son’s house— After dinner at 4. O’Clock, Benjamin came for me with the Carriage— Charles’s wife and Mrs Frothingham took a short ride of a quarter of an hour, and then I came out alone to Quincy, reached my house just at the dusk of evening— I sent the Carriage for Louisa C Smith at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where she has been on a visit, since I left her here Thursday Morning. She returned in about half an hour; and I spent the Evening in folding up copies of my two addresses to my Constituents at Braintree and at North-Bridgwater, and in reflecting upon the duty that will now devolve upon me, to retire for the short remainder of my days from public life altogether— There are still duties enough to occupy the rest of my time, and to prepare me for my closing scene.

10. IV:30. Sunday.  Sun rose 6.44. Set 4.44.  The Sun rose perfectly clear near the belfry of the Stone temple, by observation in November 1842. I found he rose directly behind the belfry on the 21st.— I shall be gone this year before that day— Mr Lunt preached this morning from 1. Corinthians 6:20— “Glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are Gods.” The Chapter from which this text is a clause of the last verse begins with a very severe reproof of the Christians at Corinth for going to Law with one another, not before the Saints their fellow Christians— The apostle declares that the saints shall judge the world—and this principle assumed thus early, and perseveringly pursued was doubtless the cause of the absolute power exercised during so many centuries by the Pope as the head of the Christian church This peremptory injunction never to go to Law with one another before infidel judges, was an unhinging engine which disabled to the extent of its influence all the roman tribunals of their power over the Christian sectarians. The Apostle then proceeds to declare that no person addicted to vicious morals, of person, property or good name shall inherit the kingdom of God. He then passes to a special, solemn, and deeply impressive charge against the sin of fornication, reminding them that other sins are offensive externally to the sinner himself but that this is a sin against his own body— He says they are bought with a price— That each one of them is the Temple of the holy ghost within him; not his own, but the property of God himself— Therefore says he glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God’s— This is a doctrine of angelic purity— On returning from meeting I found Mr Degrand at my house who dined and spent the day and evening with us till 9. O’Clock He brought out sundry newspapers, all confirming the fact of the total loss of the Presidential election— Mr Lunts afternoon sermon was from Mark 14.8. “She hath done what she could.” a Melancholy allusion to the condition of the present times, and to the disastrous issue of the Presidential Election— For the first time he alluded to the dismal prospects before us to the cause of human liberty, and the rights of petition and of protection— And he exhorted all his hearers to enquire of themselves whether they have done what they could for their salvation and preservation— Mr E. Price Greenleaf promised to call and visit my nursery with me to-morrow, and Mr Beale came and joined in lamentations with us at the Catastrophe which has befallen us.

11. IV:30. Monday  Thick fog in the morning. Thunder and Lightening with a sprinkling of rain in the afternoon— Evening calm, moderate damp cloudy— It was the day of election for Electors of President, and Vice President of the United States— For Governor, Lieutenant-Governor Senators and Representatives of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and for members of the House of Representatives of the United States in the 29th. Congress.— For this last office I was the candidate nominated by the whigs, with two opponent nominationsWright of Roxbury by the Democrats, and Appleton Howe of Weymouth by the Liberty Party. I passed the day under a scarcely doubting anticipation of the failure of my own election— Mr Spear is the author of a Treatise against Capital Punishment, of which he brought me a copy for sale, which I took. He told me he was a Clergyman in Boston, but his name is not in the Register of the present year.— Mr Ellis and Mr Durfee were here after dinner Mr Ellis to speak about the claims of William Barron and Amasa Dunbar at Washington, and Mr Durfee, with a large Quarto Volume of Autograph signatures to which he desired the addition of mine with some lines.— He wished also some separate signatures on a sheet of blank paper and I gave him one, and several upon cards.— Mr Ball is a surgeon dentist, a young man, and he came with a large quarto Volume, for autographs—blank; and he wanted to begin the book with mine. Just before noon I went to the Stone Bank and settled my balance there, and then to the town house where I tore off my own name from the whig ticket and deposited the remainder of the ticket in the ballot box. I gave my own name which I had torn off to Harvey Field at his request— In the Evening E. Price Greenleaf came in with report of the election returns from the adjoining towns of Braintree, Randolph and Hingham—more favourable on the whole than I had expected; yet not enough so, wholly to resolve my doubts I wrote in the evening a Letter to Edward Everett to enclose those of J. S Freeman, and One to Erastus C. Benedict Secretary of the New-York Historical Society, accepting their invitation to attend their 40th. anniversary meeting on the 20th. I wasted no small portion of this day in searching for Andrew Jackson’s answers to my invitations to him to dine with me in January and March 1819. and found two of them. He denies having had any communication with me in 1819.

12. V. Tuesday.  The following is the copy of the whig ticket voted for yesterday at Quincy, and for which I voted after tearing from it my own name, and pinning to the remnant of the paper the strip bearing the name of Samuel Curtis.  Whig ticket  The practice is for each voter to put into the ballot box the whole printed ticket, but every individual strikes out or effaces any name for which he chooses not to vote, and substitutes another name in its place— Candidates usually strike out their own names, but not always. There is no law, authorising the rejection of any man’s vote for himself.— The majority in the town of Quincy at the autumnal elections has been for several years democratic, consisting of transient Stone-cutters from New Hampshire— There were taken yesterday 719 votes. the number of registered voters in the town being 7Of the returns I only know that there were 345 for me, not a majority of the whole The Boston Atlas and Courier of this morning did not come by the regular mail, but I received a Courier under a blank cover— My Son came out from Boston with the Atlas, which has the returns from the whole Commonwealth except six towns— The whig ticket has been sweepingly successful.— The vote in the 8th Congressional District is 8041 for me 5322 for Wright 850 for Howe and all others. A result which I dared not expect and upon which I dare not attempt to express my feelings— Mr Lunt called on me to take leave on my proposed departure for Washington— I had no time to pack my trunks or assort my papers; but this afternoon at 4 O’Clock I left Quincy with my Son and Louisa C. Smith, who alighted at Mr James H. Foster’s, and I came to pass three days with my sons family at Boston.

13. V. Wednesday.  Confined to the house all the morning by the rain, but without any thing more than the journal of yesterday and making up a file of Letters received within the last three weeks, and which I have not found time to answer, to file, and scarcely to read.— I have now four or five days of leisure—not sufficient to answer a tythe of the Letters which I ought to answer if I could. I did not finish the filing and endorsing of them— Mrs John Angier of Medford was here, and I agreed to go and pass the Evening at her house next Friday— At noon I called on Doctor N. L. Frothingham, and passed an hour with him examining his Propertius— Burman’s Edition— The best extant— My edition, Baskerville’s quarto has nothing but the text, and the passage quoted in in G. W. Erving’s Letter, is in the 20th. elegy of the second book—in Burman’s edition it is the 16th. But we found no explanation of the difference— The Doctor asked me what had so much excited the attention of my mind to this passage of Propertius? I told him it was the quotation of it in G. W. Erving’s Letter, and its whimsical connection of it with the Texas question, and with Erving’s base and treacherous treatment of me I called at Mr James H. Fosters and saw Mrs Foster, her daughter Mary and Louisa C. Smith— I told Miss Smith that I had promised to go to Medford on Friday, and must therefore postpone our return to Quincy till Saturday At the Boston Courier Office I asked the return of the three newspapers with marked passages cited and inserted in my Address at North-Bridgwater— They sent them to me this afternoon— I found myself after dinner, drowsy and went out again, purchased small toys for Charles’s four sons, and called at judge John Davis’s— He asked me to go with him this Evening to the Wednesday evening club of which I was a member in 1790. and again in 1802 and until 1809. It was this Evening at Dr Francis Parkman’s and I promised to go.— Returning home, I directed BenjaminAndrews to go at a quarter before eight with the Carriage and take up judge Davis in Milton place and come for me to Charles’s house which he did, and I spent the Evening with the Club at the Revd. Dr Francis Parkman’s— There were about 30 persons present—among whom five or six Strangers— At half past ten I took judge Davis home, and then returned to my Sons house. I found judge Davis exceedingly gratified with my notice of the founders of the Plymouth Colony in my Address at North-Bridgwater.

14. V. Thursday.  I forgot to mention that yesterday Morning I visited Mr and Mrs Francis P. Stockton, at their lodgings in Summer Street—Mrs Le kain’s. He was not at home but Mrs Stockton received me— This morning, I went astray in the library and stumbled upon a Museum Criticum or Cambridge Classical Researches in two 8vo. volumes 1826. and in the second volume at page 140. I find a review of two Articles; publications at Milan by Angel May of fragments of 6. Orations of Cicero—inedited found on Bobian palimpsest manuscripts—one passage from which I copy here as truly Ciceronian. Pro Scauro p. 11. [“]Venio nunc ad testes in quibus docebo non modo nullam fidem et auctoritatem, sed ne specium quidem esse aut imaginem— Testium etenim fidem primum ipsa tollit consensio, quae lata facta est compromisso Sardorum et conjuratione cogitata. Deinde illa cupiditas quae suscepta est spe et promissione praemiorum. Postremo ipsa natio, cujus tanta vanitas est ut libertatem a servitute nulla re alia, nisi mentiendi licentia distinguendum putet”— This definition of liberty is by no means confined to the antient Sardians— I walked out at noon, purchased at Libby’s a signet ring, and took it to Mitchell to be engraved— He promised it for Monday morning. Call at Charles’s office and then at the Morning Chronicle Office where I saw Mr Joshua Leavitt and the Ex-Texian S. P. Andrews— I asked for my manuscript copy of the record in the circuit Court U.S. of the Antelope case. He said that Mr Torrey’s counsel at Baltimore Reverdy Johnson had it— Call at J. P. Putnam’s Office 19. Court Street— I had received a Letter from him with an application from the young men’s institute at Hartford Connt. for another address from me. I requested him to inform them of my regret that it would not be in my power—which he promised to do. I dined with Charles at Mr David Sears’s with the company named between two lines in the margin— Very pleasant Mrs Sears asked me if I remembered her father, (Jonathan Mason) as a student in my father’s Office in 1774.— I did— On our return home this evening we found Dr and Mrs Frothingham here, and Mr Degrand— Mrs Edward Brooks, and Miss Henshaw had been here before. John Kirke was here with the trees for Mr Angier— I sent W B. Reed copies of my 3. speeches.

15. IV.30. Friday  Morning visits from Harrison Gray Otis, and George Alexander Otis, men between whom there is no community, but of name; with the former of whom I have been in relations of personal intimacy and political controversy little short of three score years— For many years he acted a conspicuous part on the theatre of public affairs, and led in an unfortunate career of policy our native Commonwealth of Massachusetts— The result was to arrest him in his career of ambition, and he never reached beyond the Station of Senator of the United States, which he voluntarily relinquished, to move in the more contracted sphere of Mayor of the City of Boston; from which he also after short experience retired to affluent retirement in private life. He is abundantly wealthy, and has raised a numerous family, only one of whom has ever ventured on the stormy sea of politics, and meeting with adverse gales and some slight disaster, regained the shore and has not attempted a second voyage.— The father takes no longer any part in politics but lives, crippled with the gout, but otherwise in comfort, and the enjoyment of all that this world can afford, with two sons, one married daughter and several grand-daughter, awaiting in his 80th year his transition to Mount Auburn— My acquaintance with George Alexander commenced as a fellow passenger from London to New-York in 1817. Without an early classical education He has devoted his life to the literature of translation, which he has had the good fortune to make profitable. His translation of Botta’s history was eminently successful, and his Tusculan of Cicero have not proved a failure. He has unpublished translations of the other philosophical works of Cicero, and of the Offices—and also of Davila’s Civil Wars of France— He sat with me upwards of an hour—kind—courteous and incredibly flattering— Mrs Grinnell paid a morning visit to Mrs. Charles— I took to Dr Frothingham the volume of Ernesti’s Cicero, Boston Edition, containing the Dedication to Stiglitz— Call at Charles’s Office— Nobody there— At Cadmus’s 220. Washington Street— Letter of the 12th. from my wife at Washington— Answered immediately— I answered also two Letters from William Jackson of Newton. At 5. P.M. I rode with my Son 7 miles to Medford to the new house of Mr John Angier, where we spent the Evening, with a party of about 70. friends, family acquaintance and neighbours of Mr and Mrs Angier— His mother and Mrs T. B. Adams were there. His brothers Luther and Joseph—two Misses Osgood &c— We left the company at half past 9. and reached N. 57. Mount Vernon Street at a quarter past ten—
