16. V. Saturday.  Met at my Son’s office Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and examined and signed 6th. and 7th. accounts of administration as Executors of the last Will and Trustees of the Estate of Ward Nicholas Boylston. The 6th. extending from the last settlement till the death of Mrs. Alicia Boylston, 8. October 1843 and the 7th from that date to the present. I called at the Office of the Boston Atlas, where Dr Brewer gave me copies of the paper of 9. October 1844. containing my address to the young men’s whig club at Boston on the 7th. The address of 30. October at Braintree is in the Atlas of 2. November, and the address of 6. November at North-Bridgwater, in the Boston Courier of 9. November. These 3 papers embrace my defence against the infamous conspiracy of Andrew Jackson, George W. Erving, Aaron Vail Brown, and Charles Jared Ingersoll. I have by design taken this mode of appealing to my Constituents, to the world and to posterity— My constituents have answered and nobly vindicated my character.— In the same District where in 1842 I received only 5votes I have now received 8091 and where I had then a majority of less than 500 I have now a majority exceeding 1900— The voice of the world and of posterity is yet to be heard.— After a short ride with Mrs Charles, I came out with my son his boys John Quincy, and Charles Francis, and Louisa C. Smith— After dinner Charles and his two sons returned to Boston— Mr Nathan Procter Smith, with his wife, three sons of about 12 10, and 7 and a daughter of 9 came to see me— That, he said was all his object— He only wished that all his children should see me— He lives in Roxbury—the new part of the town, Eustis Street and does business in Boston, in connection with the great Western Railway.— Of this Class of visitors I have many, but do not feel myself much flattered by their motives. “Dulce est digito monstrari et dicier hic est”—says Juvenal, but it is pleasing only to vanity— The curiosity to see a person of great notoriety imports nothing favourable or friendly to him— It is mere selfish curiosity— This Evening I answered a Letter of B. A. Gould and 7 others, a Committee of the Boston Latin School Association of 1. Septr. last asking for information which they supposed me to possess but which I did not—and I wrote to my wife to enclose three bills of lading of articles shipped for Washington in the Schooner Columbia and the brig Mozart.

17. IV:30. Sunday.  Sun rose 6.53. Set 4:37.  From the S.E. corner of Charles’s house, the Sun rose one full disk North of the Temple belfry which performed a complete transit over the disk in 7 minutes. when the whole disk was behind the pillars of the belfry, the temple clock struck seven— True to the Sun to a minute— Last evening a Professor Church, a frenchman notwithstanding his name, accompanied by Dr Clark, an Episcopal Clergyman from Northampton, came with an introductory Letter from Revd Samuel K. Lothrop.— Professor Church is a teacher of the French language, upon a plan of his own,—and he wished me to examine his plan and give him a certificate of my opinion of it.— I told him that I made it a general rule, never to give certificates; and that if I did ever give one I had now no time for the examination— Dr Clark comes out to perform divine service to-morrow at the episcopal church where there is at present no Rector—Mr Robinson having been dismissed. This day Mr Lunt preached in the Temple from Luke 17.21. [“]For behold, the kingdom of God is within you.” This was the answer of Jesus to the Pharisees who enquired when the kingdom of God should come? It was immediately after the miracle of cleansing of ten lepers, only one of whom returned to glorify God; and he a Samaritan— In the verse immediately preceding the text Jesus says the Kingdom of God cometh not with observation— That is heralded with the sound of a trumpet. Mr Lunt said it was a Revolution in the human character— That it was the reign of righteousness and truth upon earth— Oh! how far yet from its consummation— Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse was from Philippians 4.5— “Let your moderation be known unto all men.”— He expatiated well upon the importance of this precept, as a lesson of Prudence.— It is not only moderation, but notorious universally known moderation— And yet how much more emphatic and solemn is the injunction, with the additional clause of the text, which Mr Lunt omitted—“The Lord is at hand” That your moderation should be known, is for your own benefit—propitiates the good will of others, and disarms enmity and malice— But the consideration that the Lord is at hand, reminds us our responsibility to God. It is the pure dictate of duty; and whether known to man or not cannot escape the notice of the Lord who is at hand— After Meeting I called and took leave of Mrs T. B. Adams and Elizabeth. Mrs Stebbins and John Foster— Visit from Mr and Mrs Cushing of Dorchester.

18. IV.30. Monday.  Occupied from the moment of rising till 11. A.M. in packing up for my journey to Washington, and then Benjamin F. Andrews brought me with Louisa C. Smith into Boston. John Kirk brought in our trunks in a waggon— I left Miss Smith at Mr James H. Foster’s door—called at Mitchell, the engravers and at Libby the Jeweller’s for the signet ring which I had bespoken and which was at last sent to me by Mr Libby, and received while we were at dinner.— I gave my English Signet ring with the cock and the motto “Watch” to my Son Charles’s wife— At his Office I endorsed my name in blank on the certificate for 30 shares, 3000 dollars of the Western Railroad Stock; and took with me to be executed at Washington the Deed to the Boston and Plymouth Rail-road Corporation of the Lands which they have taken of mine in Quincy— At my Son’s house N. 57. Mount Vernon Street—Mr Brooks—his son Edward, Mrs Sidney Brooks, Dr Frothingham, and John G. Palfrey Esquire the Secretary of the Commonwealth dined, and I took leave of them—and afterward of P. P. F. Degrand, who called in the course of the Evening— We had a pleasant dinner party, enlivened with literary conversation. I received an invitation to an Evening party next Friday from Mrs Francis Bacon a sister of Mrs Sidney Brooks; a Lady with whom I have no personal acquaintance— Of course my absence will make my acceptance of the invitation impossible. Before leaving Quincy this morning I planted in the garden, and in one flower pot a basket full of apples, pears, apple-seeds, peach and plum-stones, English-white Oak acorns, and shag bark walnuts from the old garden Summer house tree, which I have been gathering all the Summer and Autumn with the intention of planting them at leisure but no leisure have I had. From the same cause I leave my books and papers in confusion worse confounded— No part of my life has been more totally absorbed by toil than the four months and six days since I last returned from Washington I sent a message to Dr Duggan to inform him that I should not be able to deliver a Lecture at the Quincy and Milton Lyceum, and despatched the Letter to William Jackson, postponing the Address at Newton till next Spring

19. IV.30— V. Tuesday.  I rose in time to finish my journal of yesterday, and to breakfast before half past seven O’Clock— Then took a hack to the depot of the Worcester Railroad, and took passage in the day line by the Long-Island-rail-road to New-York— My Son accompanied me to the Car, and took leave of me in it— As did also Mr James Savage— I found there Dr Codman, Mr Young and Mr Ellis, delegates, my associates from the Massachusetts historical Society to attend the anniversary celebration of the New-York historical Society, to-morrow. We started precisely at 5 minutes past 8 as I supposed for Providence; but it had been the coldest night of the Season, and all the windows of the car were closed, and dew obscured— At 10. O’Clock the Car stop’d and I was surprized to hear we were at Worcester— The stoppage was scarcely for five minutes—and we proceeded in the same cars to Norwich where we crossed over the bridge of the Quinepaug swelling into the Thames; a stupendous work—we followed the Southern bank of the river seven miles down, where the Steamer New-Haven was in waiting to receive us— We noticed as we passed along the region of the Pequod War, and the reserve upon which the remnant of the Mohegan tribe yet dwell 3000 acres, and about 70 Souls.— We passed down the river, stopping at New-London only time enough to take in passengers, and in two hours and a quarter, with a bright Sun a smooth Sea and a chilling Northwester; landed at Greenport a small village on Long-Island— Here we took again the cars, at 3. O’Clock having dined in the boat and at 7 in the Evening alighted at Brooklyn—95 miles in 4 hours— We immediately crossed the ferry, took a hack and at half past 7. found ourselves (Mr Young, with a young Lady Miss Toppan of New-Hampshire, Mr Ellis and myself[)] at Bunker’s hotel or boarding house in Broadway.— Exactly 12 hours from my Son’s house in Boston— Dr Codman stop’d at Brooklyn— On the road I had much conversation with sundry Strangers, but chiefly with Mr Ellis, Minister of a Congregational church and Society in Charlestown, and a writer of sundry Articles in Sparks’s American biography— He is intimately acquainted with the history of the Pequod War, of which he mentioned to me many incidents, and is also much interested in the controversies in which Mrs Hutcheson so largely figured.

20. IV— VI. Wednesday— Rain— Dark Clouds and November gloom.  The visitors were so numerous and the transactions of the day so various, that they left scarcely a distinct impression upon my mind of any thing— Professor Mason as chairman of the Committee of arrangements of the New-York historical Society came early and informed me of the arrangements for the day. A Committee of 5 members of the Society with Mr. W. Beach Lawrence, a Vice-President, came welcomed me to the city— An interlude of no small note was the friendly visit of Coll. Bankhead to apprize me that Mr Samuel L. Governeur, was in possession of a Letter from General Jackson, fully approving the Florida Treaty— We dined at Bunker’s at half-past 3. and at half past four Carriages from the Society came and took me with Dr John Codman, Revd. Alexander Young and Revd. George E. Ellis to the Astor-House, where we took up Mr Leverett Saltonstall, and proceeded to the Library room of the University where the Meeting of the historical Society was held, the President Albert Gallatin being in the Chair. The numbers of the Society are unlimited, and the only business done, was the admission by an open vote sundry members, nominated at a previous meeting; and the nomination of sundry others among whom was John Jacob Astor.— The assembly was quite numerous and thronged the spacious apartment.— They then joined in a procession of Carriages to the Church of the Messiah, of which Orville Dewey is the Pastor, where an Oration was delivered by John Romeyn Brodhead upon historical subject— He has been an agent of the State to collect documents relating to its history in England, France and Holland—of which agency he gave an interesting account; interspersed with several passages of beautiful eloquence— The house is large, and was well filled— The Discourse was preceded by a prayer by Revd Dr. De Witt of the reformed Dutch Church. The closing benediction was by Dr Codman.— From the Church between 8 and 9. O’Clock the Society adjourned to the New-York Hotel where a magnificent dinner was prepared for 300 persons— Mr Gallatin had not gone to the Church; but presided at the table for about an hour, and then retired before the speeches began. Mr William Beach Lawrence presided the remainder of the Evening.— Mr Luther Bradish late Lieutt. Governor of New-York toasted me, or roasted me with a speech so fulsome that it overset all my philosophy, and I stammered a reply the only palliation of which was its brevity— The speeches followed till sometime passed midnight when I retired with my colleagues Saltonstall, Young and Ellis. Mr Samuel L. Gouverneur promised to call on me to-morrow Morning at 8 O’Clock—

21. VI:45. Thursday.  Alexander S. Johnson, Grandson of my long since departed brother Charles, was one of my visitors yesterday, and told me of the disastrous accidents which befell his father and his brother William about three weeks since—the father having been thrown out of a Chaise in which he was riding with his wife, and broken one arm, and sprained a wrist— And William having been overset in a Carryall, and sprained his ancle so as for some time to walk with a crutch— Last Evening Dr Wainwright who sat next to me at table, asked me if I was aware that Mr Gouverneur possessed a Letter from General Jackson to President Monroe fully approving the Florida Treaty in 1819— I said I was— He asked me, if I had received the information from or through John A. Hamilton. I said I had not, but was not at liberty to tell him from whom I had received it. He said the reason of his asking me the last question was that there had been some days since a conversation upon the subject in the Office of Mr Hamilton. About 11. O’Clock while at table I received a Letter fromBlakeman M.D. enclosing an old Massachusetts Pine-tree shilling, which he wished through me to present to the New-York historical Society— Dr. Blakeman was to me a total Stranger, but after consultation with Mr Lawrence, and Dr. Wainwright I presented the shilling and gave a brief summary history of the coinage of 1652. and I took the occasion to pay a tribute of respect to Albert Gallatin, which I had forgotten to do when up before.— This morning Mr Gouverneur called on me at 8. And told me that he had according to his recollection a Letter from General Jackson to President Monroe, written at New-York in February 1819. and speaking of the Florida Treaty—as universally approved. A confidential Letter from W. L. L. Brent to Mr Monroe intreating him to place no confidence and trust nothing to George W. Erving and a Letter from Thomas Jefferson to Mr Monroe speaking lightly of the French claim West of the Mississippi— He promised to communicate these papers to me on this return to Washington— At 9. O’Clock I crossed the river to Jersey city and took the train of Cars for Philadelphia— Mr Young and Mr Ellis came down and took leave of me at the ferry— Mr Blunt crossed the ferry and took leave of me at the Cars. Among my fellow travellers were Coll Talcott and Professor Bartlett of West Point— We reached Philadelphia at 5 P.M and took lodgings at Jones’s Union Hotel in Chesnut Street—

22. IV:30 Friday  Among the Passengers whom I met yesterday at the passage of the ferry boat from New-York to Jersey city formerly Paulus Hook, wasCogswell who was one of the Students at Harvard University in 1806. when I was installed Professor of Rhetorick and Oratory at that institution— He was one of the Committee of Students who requested a copy for publication of my inaugural address— I believe their chairman, . . . had then the reputation of being the first scholar at the University— He was then about 20.— He is now, within two or three years of 60— I should not have recognized him, but Mr Blunt introduced him to me; and he remembered the delivery of my Lectures— His career has been respectable, but not so highly distinguished or successful, as might have been expected. He told me he was now employed by Mr John Jacob Astor as an Agent for carrying into execution his donation of four hundred thousand dollars to the City of New-York, for a library— Our arrival at Philadelphia last evening was delayed by an accident which befell the corresponding train of Cars going from Philadelphia to New-York— Between Princeton and Trenton their locomotive engine ran off the track and stuck in the mud— Their train barred the passage to ours, and we were obliged to change our seats and take others in the train from Philadelphia, to which the accident had happened— The train which we left was taken by the passengers from Philadelphia for whom another engine was procured, and baggage enough to load a ship was mutually transferred. The detention was of about two hours and a half; and professor Bartlett more than once reminded me of the melancholy disaster which befell the train of Cars, between Amboy and Bordentown in November 1833. when he and his wife and two infant daughters were fellow passengers.— He said his wife and daughters who were much injured by the accident had all entirely recovered from its effects— This morning Coll. and Mrs Talcott, and professor Bartlett proceeded on their journey and Mr Huntington was the only acquaintance left me in the house— Ebenezer Tucker of New-Jersey heretofore a member of Congress now 87 years of age, visited me in the course of the day, and Mr Meredith of Baltimore dined with us at the Lady’s Ordinary— I received of George Rundle, York Street 61. dollars a final dividend of the Schuylkill permanent bridge stock, and at the Bank of North-America Chesnut Street an order on the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington for 240 dollars for 8. Coupons of interest on Cincinnati bonds— In the evening I went to the Chesnut Street Theatre and saw the Hunchback, and the President incog.

23. IV:30. Saturday.  Rain all Night— I rose to a minute in time to finish the record of yesterday, to breakfast and walk to the depot in Market street of the Railroad Cars for Baltimore. At 8 O’Clock they started; and at a quarter before 3. landed me in Pratt-street, Baltimore. As the Sun rose the rain held up; and the sky was all the morning clearing off— By the time we reached Baltimore it was throughout the hemisphere crystal clear and so continued for the remnant of the day. I left Benjamin F. Andrews, my help, with his spaniel dog at the depot to get his dinner at the United States Hotel, and to take care of the baggage, and walked to Barnum’s for a dinner— Missed my way, and strolled, till I met Lloyd N. Rogers, the first person whom I knew, after leaving Jones’s Union Hotel in Philadelphia.— He walked with me, bewailing all the way the issue of the election and left me at Barnum’s door.— At the Lady’s Ordinary they were at table, and there I met Commodore Ballard and Mrs Ballard, with a little girl 8 or 9. years old their granddaughter— The Commodore welcomed me with great cordiality; told me that it was a constant satisfaction to him that I had signed his commission, and remembered as I did, that in May 1836, he had given up at 11. O’Clock at Night his own chamber at Barnum’s, to me for a lodging, when there was not another in the house to be had.— He then took for the Night a bed in the chamber of Commodore Alexander J. Dallas then a fellow lodger here, but recently deceased as commander of the squadron in the pacific. After dinner, I returned to the depot and took a seat in the train of Cars for Washington, which started at 5. O’Clock for Washington City. at the relay house 8. Miles from Baltimore, the termination of the Cumberland railroad, Mr John J. Crittenden a Senator of the United States from Kentucky, and Mrs Crittenden, and W. C. M’Causlen a member of the House from Ohio came into the Car, and arrived with us at Washington soon after 7. by the light of the moon, almost rivaling the noonday. From the depot at the foot of the Capitol hill I walked home, and had scarcely entered the house, when Dr Thomas followed me— Mrs John Adams was confined to her bed, and my dear wife, though not in bed is afflicted with one of those stubborn nervous coughs which seem to deny respite or relief.— And thus on reaching home, I am called to mingle with the notes of gratitude for continued blessings the supplication for further mercies— Mr Cutts and his daughter came in soon after and spent an hour of the Evening here— And after the visitors were gone, I mused over the prospects before me; with the impression that they portend trials more severe than I yet have passed through—and with a reliance alone on him who rules above.

24. VI. Sunday—  My wife was quite ill great part of this day, but promisingly better this Evening.— I gave her this morning the signet ring which I purchased for her in Boston, upon the Cornelian stone of which Mitchell engraved the crest of the Lion bearing the cross, and under it the Letter A. with the hair of our Son Charles and his wife in a box under the stone— And I gave to my granddaughter Mary Louisa the signet ring which I procured for her, and on which Mitchell engraved the cock, with the motto “Watch”— And for the significancy of the device, at my request she read to me the 13th. chapter of Mark—the last verse of which is—And what I say unto you, I say unto all, Watch. I attended public worship this morning at the second presbyterian church, where Mr Knox preached from Luke 19.41. “And when he was come near, he beheld the city, and wept over it.”— There was something deeply saddening in this discourse. Jesus wept over the city because he foresaw and foretold the destruction of it which was so soon afterwards to ensue. Mr Knox remarked that there but two occasions in the life of Jesus, upon which it is recorded that he wept— This, and at the death of Lazarus before he restored him to life— That these tears were indications of the purest benevolence, and the most exquisite tenderness; all which is apparent— But the destruction of Jerusalem has no observable connection with their treatment of Jesus Christ. Judea was conquered by the Romans as other Nations were, and in the process of that conquest Jerusalem was taken and the second temple was destroyed— In foretelling this event Jesus affirms that if Jerusalem had repented and believed in him, she would not have suffered that dreadful fate; but the Judean war of Vespasian and Titus had no earthly connection with the life and death of Jesus of Nazareth. Mr Knox in the application of his discourse, put it, as an awful question to his hearers whether this city was not as guilty, and as deserving of the afflictive judgment of Heaven as Jerusalem was in the days of Jesus Christ; but he did not specify the sins which may draw down destruction upon it— Slavery is the great besetting sin of this city; but of that Mr Knox took no note— He complained that of 25 or 26 thousand inhabitants, not more than 3000 attended upon any religious exercises of public worship, a fact that seems incredible but otherwise the sins of this city are not more aggravated than those of the age in other populous cities, and that the vices of the age, and the sins of this Nation deserve a severe judgment of Heaven is too painfully true to be denied— May that judgment be averted, and the manners of the age and nation be reformed and purified. After dinner I attended at St. John’s church where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the 25th. Sunday after Trinity, and Mr Slaughter a Clergyman from Virginia preached from John 7.17. [“]If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself.”— Eclipse of the moon.

25. V:15. Monday.  I arrived here on Saturday Evening with a clear sky, bright moonlight, and the atmosphere of May rather than of November— Yesterday Morning it was yet warm; but the wind came round to the North-west and it was all day growing cold; and as I was returning from church last evening, between 5 and 6. O’Clock, I saw the moon just risen with the shadow of the earth already encroaching upon her disk— The eclipse was total and lasted upwards of three hours but the cold was so pinching that I could look at it only once or twice; and then less than five minutes at a time— This day has been of bright clear disqualifying cold— I unpacked my trunks, and immediately missed one or two articles, precisely those I wanted and left behind— It made a day of fruitless search and of wasted time. I walked out for exercise, and at the National Intelligencer Office saw Mr Gales in deep distress at the issue totally unexpected issue of the Presidential election— He is in despair and foresees that it must prove his irretrievable ruin. It has been accomplished by fraud through the Slave representation.— The partial associations of native americans, Irish catholics, abolition Societies, Liberty party.— The Pope of Rome, the Democracy of the sword, and the dotage of a ruffian, are sealing the fate of this Nation, which nothing less than the interposition of omnipotence can save. I asked Mr Gales to send me the Intelligencer, from the 14th. which he did, and I sent him the Boston Atlas of 2. Novr. and the Courier of 9. November containing my addresses at Braintree and at North Bridgwater which he had no read— After I came home, Mr Michael Nourse a ruling elder of the second Presbyterian Church called on me and enquired if I would consent to go as a delegate from that Church and Society, to the Sabbath day Convention to be held at Baltimore next Wednesday. I said I should feel honoured by the election, but doubted whether it would be in my power to go. The meeting of the Society was held at half past four this afternoon— I did not attend it but in the Evening the Revd. Mr Knox, and Mr Nourse came as a Committee from the Meeting to inform me that I had been elected a delegate from the Society to the Convention. I expressed my grateful sensibility for the honour conferred upon me, and promised to attend the Convention, if it should be in my power. I know not if this acceptance be prudent, but as an act of kindness to the Society and a testimony of respect for the Sabbath I believed it proper.

26. IV:30 Tuesday  I found myself unexpectedly absorbed in business unforeseen— Received a multitude of Letters among which one from my son at Boston enclosing a Letter to my wife from her Sister Mrs Harriet Boyd with six draugts by her upon me and my son, one for eighty dollars being her portion of the surplus of the Estate of Thomas B. Johnson ordered by the judge of the orphan’s Court last July to be distributed among the heirs. Another for 197 dollars 78 Cents due to Mrs Boyd on her annuity the interest on 5000 dollars, Mr Johnson’s bequest to her. Then three draughts each for 60 dollars by anticipation payable 14 January, April and July 1845. and one payable 14 October 1845—for 197:78. For all these Mrs P Boyd imploringly calls for 300 dollars immediately, to save her and her family from being turned out of house and home by the forfeiture of the Estate on which they live— I wrote to Charles to remit to George Boyd a post note of the merchants Bank Boston to be sent under cover to me, to be forwarded by me to him in two separate halves for 500 dollars—taking on myself the responsibility of the future payments as they shall become payable My wife insisted that 300 dollars of her first years annuity from her brothers bequest which Charles has invested for her should be pledged for the payment of the sums, advanced on Mrs Boyd’s draughts— I sent for two Justices of the Peace who came, Mr Clarke and Mr King who came and witnessed and took the acknowledgment of myself and my wife to the Deed of my lands in Quincy taken by the Boston and old Colony Rail-road, the consideration for which is left in blank to be filled up. I received also from John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, a Letter my credential as the representative of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts in the 29th. Congress together with a list, of all the votes returned—upwards of 14000. I called at the National Intelligencer Office to ask for a paper of 28 September and to offer my whole file of duplicates; but neither Gales nor Seaton was there. At the Clerk’s Office of the House of Representatives but French was gone home to dinner. I found Mr Mehan in the library— My wife was so ill this Evening that I wrote to Revd. Mr Knox to excuse myself for not going to Baltimore to-morrow— But she was afterwards better and persuaded me to go.

27. III— IV:30. Wednesday  At 5. I breakfasted, and rode to the depot of the train of Cars for Baltimore— Met there the Revd Dr Laurie, and Mr Knox whom I informed that my wife being better I had concluded to come to Baltimore, and attend the Sabbath day convention At 6. we started and at a quarter past 8. alighted at the depot in Baltimore— I walke to Barnum’s Hotel, and bespoke a bed chamber. Met there Mr Chambers of Chambersburg and Harmar Denny of Pittsburg and Mr Newkirk of Philadelphia, and sundry others delegates to the Convention— At a quarter before 10 Mr Knox called for me, and I went with him to the first Baptist Church in Sharp Street which we found filled with about 1200 delegates to the National Lord’s day Convention— Mr Hanmer the Minister of the Church moved that judge Willard Hall of Delaware should be chairman of the meeting to organize the Convention which was voted by acclamation and he took the Chair. Two Secretaries were chosen and a Committee of 5. Bishop Waugh, Dr Bond, Mr Stilman, Mr Atwood, and Mr Gideon, were appointed to submit officers and rules for the government of the Convention— While they were out, Mr Powell of Philadelphia was requested to address the meeting which notwithstanding some objections he did— The Committee soon came in and reported John Quincy Adams, President—seven Vice Presidents 1. Willard Hall, 2. Theodore Frelinghuysen 3. Dr Nott. 4 Bishop Waugh 5. J. A. Brown, 6. H. V. D. Johns 7. J. Kingsford—and four Secretaries, Harmar Denny C. W. Ridgely, C. A. Davis, and T. Stilman, which nominations were approved by an unanimous vote— I took the Chair and made a very brief address to the Convention; and the Committee on Officers and rules made a supplementary report of 8 rules— The first of which was that the Convention should meet at 9. A.M—sit till 1 p.m. adjourn till 3. P.M adjourn at 5. and meet again at 7. P.M.— There was some discussion whether the question should be taken upon all the rules at once, or upon each rule separately—after some debate a motion was made to take one question upon all the rules, which was carried by a large majority and they were adopted with only two or three dissenting votes— There was much discussion about a roll call of the members, and after an attempt to read over the names which it was found would consume more time than the Convention could spare a committee of enrolment was appointed, to whom all members having credentials were authorised to present them and members having no credentials were to be accredited upon their own declaration— A Letter from T. Frelinghuysen was read regretting his inability to attend the convention, whereupon James Clarke was appointed 2d Vice President in his place— Bishop Waugh, Methodist read a Letter addressed to the Convention with enclosed papers, but a Committee had been appointed to report the business to be acted upon by the Convention; and a rule required that all communications addressed to the Convention should be referred to the business Committee— They reported seven Resolutions the first of which was a general one, avering the duty of all men to remember the Sabbath and keep it holy. This started a snarling debate Mr Lemmon, a delegate from Baltimore, and Mr Magruder of Virginia, who insisted that the Sabbath being an abrogated Jewish institution, in no wise binding upon Christians. This was in substance nothing more than an objection to the use of the word Sabbath, instead of the Lords day; but they misunderstood it as an infidel attempt to break up the Convention itself— Attempts were made to silence Mr Lemmon and Mr Magruder— They were repeatedly called to order; Magruder was loudly hissed, and there were numerous calls to turn him out. I maintained them both in their right to speak, until they were heard through— A motion was made to lay Mr Lemmon’s amendment on the table, and question made whether that motion was debatable. I decided that it was, there being no rule to the contrary— It was accordingly warmly debated till the time for adjournment, immediately before which the question was taken and Mr Lemmon’s amendment was laid on the table by an apparently unanimous vote. At 1. O’Clock the Convention adjourned till 3.— As we were retiring Mr Lemmon put into my hand a printed paper, headed, Report for the Lord’s day Convention— I had forgotten in packing up my valise, to put in it—a pen—which reminded me of La gageure imprévue. I stop’d at a shop, and purchased a paper of Camel steel pens.— At Barnum’s they had dinner at 1/2 past 2. I found myself seated by Lloyd N. Rogers, but was obliged to leave the table, dinner half over, to take the Chair of the Convention at 3.— The first and 7. other resolutions offered by the business Committee were now passed in quick succession by unanimous votes before Messrs. Lemmon and Magruder came in— The Convention adjourned from 5 to 7. and sat again from 7 to 10.— The house crowded to its utmost capacity. Adjourned to 9. to-morrow morning

28. IV:15. Thursday.  I could not comprize in one page the journal of yesterday, nor finish the account of the day before breakfast— My wife had charged me to procure for her two handsome picture frames for the portraits of her eldest sister, Nancy, the first Mrs Hellen and of herself painted by Savage, before they were married— I went accordingly to the shop of Mr Fryer in Gay Street— My wife had named him to me, and the bar-keeper at Barnum’s had assured me that his shop was the best shop for that Article in the City— I found and bespoke the two frames for 20 dollars and directed them to be sent to the depot of the rail-road Cars, boxed up—this afternoon or to-morrow morning as I should thereafter advise— Precisely at 9. O’Clock I took the Chair of the Convention, of whom very few members were present Bishop Waugh of the methodist episcopal church made the prayer kneeling— The Revd. Justin Edwards Chairman of the business Committee presented successively a number of resolutions all having reference to the observance of the Lord’s day; and three several addresses to the Canal Commissioners to the Directors of Railroads, and to the People of the United States, all of which were read and adopted by the Convention without debate— Sundry members of the Convention offered separate Resolutions, which were referred to the business committee, then reported by them with such modifications as they thought advisable then read and adopted without opposition— In this way Resolutions recommending to innkeepers to close their barrooms on Sundays— To the officers of the army, exhorting them not to exact military service from the soldiers on that day, and a recommendation to the ministers of the gospel to preach a sermon once every year urging the faithful observanc of the day.— and there was a resolution expressing the regret of the Convention, that Congress should have within the last few years repeatedly have transacted public business on Sunday. As the essential business of the Convention was done, I resolved to return home this evening, and thinking it fair to leave judge Hall a turn to preside, I took leave of the Convention before adjourning at 1. O’Clock, upon which they passed a vote of thanks— I dined at Barnum’s—excused myself to J. P. Kennedy who had invited me to dine with him to-morrow, took the Cars for Washington at 5. found Benjamin at the depot, and walked home.

28. IV:15. Thursday.  I could not comprize in one page the journal of yesterday, nor finish the account of the day before breakfast— My wife had charged me to procure for her two handsome picture frames for the portraits of her eldest sister, Nancy, the first Mrs Hellen and of herself painted by Savage, before they were married— I went accordingly to the shop of Mr Fryer in Gay Street— My wife had named him to me, and the bar-keeper at Barnum’s had assured me that his shop was the best shop for that Article in the City— I found and bespoke the two frames for 20 dollars and directed them to be sent to the depot of the rail-road Cars, boxed up—this afternoon or to-morrow morning as I should thereafter advise— Precisely at 9. O’Clock, upon which they passed a vote of thanks— I dined at Barnum’s—excused myself to J. P. 29. IV:45. Friday  I called this morning at the Bank of the Metropolis—and deposited the order from the Bank of North America, for 240 dollars, which was entered to my credit as cash, and they gave me a new Bank-book, as I have mislaid my old one. Next at the Franklin Insurance Company Office I recived a dividend of 316.75 which I deposited in the Patriotic Bank— At the National Intelligencer Office I saw Mr Seaton, and returned two papers of the 18th. and 19th. of this month of which they had sent me duplicates but they had not a spare copy of the paper of 28 September last which is yet missing from my file— I brought up my journal but could write nothing else— From breakfast time till past noon upwards of three hours I was swallowed up in reading Newspapers, received this morning— The Baltimore Patriot of Yesterday, and Sun of this day contain detailed reports of the proceedings of the Lord’s day Convention till their final adjournment last evening— In the Boston Semi-weekly Advertiser of Wednesday the 27th. received under a cover endorsed George E. Ellis, there is a report of the proceedings at the 40th. anniversary of the New-York historical Society on the 20th. doubtless written by Mr Ellis himself, and in a spirit of kindness to me.— In the Brooklyn Evening Star of Tuesday the 26th. received under cover without indication from whom, there is a Letter dated at Quincy—Masstts. 23. November 1844. signed E. M. and giving an account of a visit to the grave yard at Quincy, and to the houses and chambers in which my father and myself were born— Of Mr Lunt’s 200th. anniversary discourses with my hour glass hymn— All these papers I read with a deep interest—was it egotism? vanity? pride? or excusable weakness If so, may it be forgiven!— I had a long visit from Mr Pakenham, the Minister from Great Britain— He said there had not been one line of correspondence between Mr Calhoun and him since the close of the last Session of Congress—nor to his knowledge between Mr Edward Everett and the British Government— He appears to apprehend no collision between the two Governments— Richard D. Cutts was here this afternoon, and Philip R. Fendall in the Evening— I gave him the newspaper copies of my three Addresses to the young men of Boston; to my constituents at Braintree and at North-Bridgwater. He is one of the very few men who will read them all.— A young man from Lowell by the name of Whittemore was here in great want.

30. IV:30. Saturday.  There is a great variety of business, public and private which passes over from one session of Congress to the next, and of which I have found it extremely difficult and not unfrequently impossible to keep the thread. In the intervals between the Sessions individuals apply for pensions, for petitions to Congress or pension claims new or old before Congress or the Executive Departments— I have kept since 1835 a docket of petitions, which have absorbed a vast portion of my time, besides publishing lists of them in the National Intelligencer— A want of system in keeping a day-book of all business under my charge whether before Congress or the departments has often made me lose sight of particular cases, and had the appearance and the results of neglect. Instead of keeping one continuous book I have scattered my minutes and memoranda over numerous quires of paper, and know not where to look for the one, I happen at any time to want.— I found this morning on my files of papers, three applications for pensions, and two for Cadet warrants, which required my immediate attention. 1. The declaration of Mary Jennison of Boston, widow of William Jennison 2. The Declaration of Hannah Allen, heretofore widow of Zebah Thayer—now of Roxbury—and 3. A Letter from Joseph Benedict—dated Utica 3. Octr. 1844. claiming a pension for his father, for service of his grandfather— The papers of these three claims I took to the Pension Office, and left them with the Commissioner James L. Edwards, who promised answers to them— I met Mr Frye who has removed to the seven buildings and I returned the visit of Mr Pakenham, the Minister from Great Britain— He told me he had made very little progress with Mr Calhoun in the Negotiation for the Oregon. And he avowed the claim of Great Britain to the Columbia river— I received a Letter of 4 November current from George Joy, Pentonville, London with sundry documents printed and manuscript, and I wrote to George Rundle to enclose the certificates of Schuylkill bridge Stock.

1. IV:15. Sunday.  Sun rose 7.— Set 4.39.  But I cannot see it here as at Quincy. The houses on the other side of the street intercept his rising and setting beams— I attended public worship morning and afternoon at the second Presbyterian church— Mr Knox was in the pulpit; but the morning preacher was Mr Nourse— His text was from Philippians 2.12—“work out your own salvation with fear and trembling 13. For it is God which worketh in you, both to will and to do of his good pleasure.” There is a compromise of doctrine in this text, between free will, and predestination— For as God worketh in us to will as well as to do, we may work out our own salvation by prayer for the will, as well as for action. Mr Knox gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday afternoon— Dr Justin Edwards preached in the afternoon, from Mark 2.27.— “The Sabbath was made for man”—and he went over all the topics, and repeated the arguments which he had held forth at the Lord’s day convention last week at Baltimore— There is error in the strictness of construction, which these persons give to the precept— Dr Edwards left out of his text the concluding words in the verse Mark 2.27.—“and not man for the Sabbath.” I quoted the whole last week at Baltimore, believing as I do, that the qualification is as necessary to the religious principle as the injunction itself.— Works of necessity and of charity are not incompatible with the holiness of the day. Dr Edwards gave notice that he should preach to-morrow evening at the Presbyterian church in 9th. Street on the same subject, and should then notice the objections to the consecration of the Sabbath drawn from certain passages of the New Testament— The argument upon which he most emphatically dwelt was the physical necessity of hebdomadal repose to the nature not only of man but of horses.— In support of which he alledged facts not altogether unquestionable to prove that men who labour or travel six days in the week, and rest the 7th. perform more work, and travel farther in a series of weeks, than men who allow themselves no intermission. And he said there was the same testimony with regard to horses— A more unequivocally authenticated fact is attested by the records of the New-York penitentiary that more than four fifths of the inmates of that establishment are persons regardless of the Sabbath— I received this morning a letter from my Son with half a post Note of the Merchants Bank Boston which I forwarded to Mrs Harriet Boyd at Green Bay, Wiskonsin Territory— And I enclosed to George Rundle Philadelphia the certificates of 600 dollars permanent Schuylkill bridge Stock. W Hellen took the Letters to the Post-Office.

2. IV:45. Monday.  28. Congress. 2d Session  Precisely at Noon John W. Jones Speaker of the House of Representatives of the United States, took the Chair and called the House to order— The roll was then called and 175 members answered to their names— 7. new members elected to supply vacancies were swore in— George W. Hopkins moved a message to the Senate to inform them that the house was ready for business, and Cave Johnson moved a joint Committee to inform the President that the two houses were assembled and ready to receive any communication he may be pleased to make to them— The Senate concurred by a corresponding Message— The members of the Committee on the part of the house were Cave Johnson and Joseph R. Ingersoll.— Isaac E. Holmes of Charleston South-Carolina moved the immediate appointment of a Chaplain— The Speaker told him there must first be a joint Resolution for the appointment of two Chaplains of different denominations, one by each house to interchange weekly— He then moved the usual resolution— John Pettit of Indiana moved an amendment, provided that the chaplains should be paid by voluntary contribution of the members without charge upon the people, and said he had prepared a subscription paper, and put down his own name for 5 dollars; and if any one would give more, he would engage to double any such increased subscription, and then he made a stump speech— M’Connell moved the previous question— M’Kay said there was a law authorizing appropriations to pay for chaplains, and Steenrod the appropriation for the present Session was already made— The Speaker said these objections came too late. Pettit’s amendment was rejected by yeas and nays 151 to 20. and Holmes’s Resolution was adopted without call for yeas and nays. I gave notice that I should to morrow move a Resolution, to rescind the 25th. rule which excludes the reception of abolition petitions— Dromgoole said my motion was not in order, but it was entered on the journal— Giddings thought they would trip me up on the point of order, and thought it would be necessary to move an amendment of the rules—but I assured him that rescind was the word.— Mary Louisa this day 16.— Mary E. E. Cutts dined with us.

3. III— VI:45. Tuesday  I was first up this morning at 3. O’Clock; but returned to bed and between sleeping and waking lay unconsciously till a quarter before 7. two hours and a half later than I should have done.— Last evening General Parker, Chief Clerk of the War Department called and spent an hour with me— I shewed him the Note from General Jackson of 25. Jany 1819. declining our invitation of him and his family to dinner, and asked him if he knew in whose hand writing it was. He said it was Coll. Robert Butler’s— The note accepting the invitation to dine on the 4th. of March 1819. is in another hand, not Jackson’s. Parker said he should know it if he could see it— But it is mislaid. I know not whether here or at Quincy— At the meeting of the house this day Cave Johnson from the joint Committee to wait on the President reported that they had performed that service, and the President had informed them that he would make a communication to Congress at 12. O’Clock this day. R. M. Saunders moved the appointment of the standing Committees which was agreed to— In pursuance of the notice I had given yesterday— I moved the following Resolution— [“]Resolved that the 25th standing rule, for conducting business in this house, in the following words—‘No petition, memorial, resolution or other paper, praying the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, or any State or Territory or the Slave trade between the States or Territories in which it now exists shall be received by this house or entertained in any way whatever’—be, and the same is hereby rescinded.”— I called for the yeas and nays— Jacob Thompson of Mississippi moved to lay the Resolution on the Table— I called for the yeas and nays on that motion— As the Clerk was about to begin the call the President’s Message was announced and received— A member called for the reading of the Message. I said I hoped the question upon my resolution would be taken— The Clerk called the roll, and the motion to lay on the table was rejected 81 to 104— The question was then put on the resolution and it was carried 108 to 80.—blessed ever blessed be the name of God!— The President’s Message was immediately afterwards read and some debate followed how to dispose of it— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and 10000 copies of it to be printed— After some miscellaneous business about 3 the house adjourned. General Parker was again here this evening, and I received two pension certificates from the Commissioner of Pensions.

4. IV.45. Wednesday.  I received from the pension office last evening two certificates; one for Mrs Hannah Allen formerly widow of Zebah Thayer, which I despatched this morning to Dudley Williams at Roxbury—and the other for Mrs. Mary Jennison widow of William Jennison, which I sent this morning to my Son from whom I received her declaration 26 Septr. last— After I had written to Charles to search for Jackson’s Note and G. W. Erving’s Letter of 3. May 1817. I found them on a small file of Letters on my table, and I cut off the paragraph of my Letter to my son asking him to search for them— At the house 4 additional members took their Seats— Several notices were given of asking leave to introduce bills among the rest by Burt of a bill to repeal the duty on cotton bagging and gunny cloth—by James A. Black, a bill to regulate the pay of the Army, and for other purposes—by Phoenix a bill to repeal the duty on rail road iron— By Dana, a bill to abolish the franking privilege and to reduce the rates of postage— I required that these and all such notices should be read— Duncan of Cincinnati offered his bill for holding all the elections of the electoral colleges on one and the same day throughout the Union. The rule required that he should ask and obtain leave to introduce the bill, and that it should be called up with Resolutions— He moved a suspension of the rules, and called for the yeas and nays, of which there were none, 172 ayes— His bill was read twice, and an hour’s debate sprung up what should be done with it— The debate was superfluous there being no opposition to the principle of the bill. At last it was ordered to be referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and to be printed— Holmes of Charleston S.C. then moved to proceed to the choice of a chaplain— At the first voting there were seven or eight candidates nominated among whom a methodist named Daley, from Indiana, who obtained 41 votes, the highest number for any candidate then— I had voted for Doctor Muller, the pastor of the Lutheran English Church in this city; but he had only 16 votes.— At the second vote Mr Daley obtained 64 votes. I voted for Mr Hale a son of Nathan Hale of Boston, who is preaching here at the Unitarian Church—but he was not more successful than Dr. Muller— At the third vote, Mr Daley got 104 votes and was chosen— I was one of the voters for him, to get through a tedious process— The house then adjourned— I received this Evening a Letter from Mr Allan B. Magruder of Charlottesville Virginia, with an explanatory Article in the Baltimore Sun, and his thanks for my impartiaty at the Lord’s day Convention.

5. IV:45 Thursday  I had a morning visit from Robert Owen of Lanark, a man with whom I first became acquainted in London in 1817. A speculative, scheming, mischievous man. He had then succeeded in accumulating a large fortune by forming a community at Lanark in Scotland, consisting of poor labourers but who were said to prosper into competency and affluence and contentment while they made his fortune— But he was ambitious of working his system upon a larger scale, and he came to this country full of the scheme of new modeling human society. He formed an establishment, in the State of Indiana, named New Harmony, and delivered discourses on the new organization of Society; and trumpeted abroad his Utopia till it fell into ruin—his establishment was left a wreck, and he went back to his own country to practice dupery again there. He had however acquired a large landed property, which his Son Robert Dale Owen was left to manage; and he after strolling about the country preaching infidelity and prostitution, till they found themselves threatened with Lynch Law by the rabble, and parted— Fanny Wright now calling herself Madame D’Arusmon and going home to Dundee; and Robert Dale Owen returning to Indiana, a demagogue of the first water, till he has wormed himself into Congress with such fellows as Pettit, and Henley, and John W. Davis, and Andrew Kennedy, and Proffit, the scum and dregs of the political cauldron— Robert Owen and Fanny Wright have now come again to this Country, and he apparently as crafty, crazy as ever— He said he wanted to have a long interview with me, and I promised to receive him any morning from ten to twelve. At the War Department I left Jonathan Amory’s Letter applying for a Cadet warrat for his son Thomas C— I compared the handwriting of General Jackson’s note accepting my invitation to dine on the 4th. of March 1819—with that of a Letter from him to the Secretary of War of 1. Feby 1819. and they appeared to be the same— The House after sundry notices given at half past 12. Adjourned over to next Monday. Lieutenant Ord of the army called on me, and requested my atten to a claim of his brother Pacificus Ord to compensation for services in a public office, against which he says I voted at the last Session of Congress for want of satisfactory evidence in its support— Mr Elliot was here this evening and gave me a list of whigs and democrats who voted for and against rescinding the 25th. rule.

6. V. Friday.  Mr Robert Owen came again this morning, and Mesmerized me for the space of an hour and a half with his lunacies about a new organization of Society under the auspices of the two most powerful Nations on the face of the globe—Great Britain on the Eastern, and the United States on the Western Hemisphere. The materials he says are abundant; and the arrangements are all of simple and easy execution— He has prepared a plan in which all the details are set forth with the minutest accuracy.— It is now in the hands of Mr Pakenham, but he will ask him to return it and will communicate it to me for my examination— It is a plan for universal education, for which the Smithsonian fund may provide the means without interfering at all with my views— After the establishment of the system there will be no War and no such thing as poverty— Universal competency will be the lot of all mankind; and want will be unknown.— All this I had heard twenty-five years ago, and the humbug is too stale.— His last departure from this Country he says was in 1830. when, by his agency, General Jackson and Mr Van Buren, settled all the differences between this Country and Great Britain— Since then he has been negotiating in Mexico, in Austria and Prussia, and has been working five hours a day upon his great plan which he has now brought to maturity— I asked him if he was acquainted with the Fourier plan of a community, he said yes; and personally with the man— He was no more than a Clerk in a Merchant’s Counting house, ingenious and fanciful, without experience of the world or knowledge of mankind— Dr. Mayo was here and told me that he meant to answer Andrew Jackson’s indirect attack upon him, about the Letter to Fulton, in his imploring Letter to Blair the Editor of the Globe— Mayo had not seen my reply to Jackson’s Letter to Armstrong in the North Bridgwater Address— I gave him a copy of the Boston Courier containing it— He said that Jackson was the greatest liar that this Country had ever produced and that the Committee on the Fulton claim had proved it upon him— Daley is a coloured man who brought samples of Gunpowder and black Tea which he brought with him from China. Mr Fischer came with a complaint against M’Nulty the clerk of the house for speculating in his purchases of Stationery— I called at the Patriotic Bank and drew 200 dollars by Check. Visits from J. P. Kennedy and R. C. Winthop Evening with Walter Hellen at the concert of Swiss Campanologians.

7 IV.45. Saturday.  I should have done much business this day at the War and Navy Departments and in the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives, in overhauling the unfinished business of former Sessions of Congress to be replaced upon the Calendar— But Sloth creeps irresistibly upon leisure, and a walk of about half an hour was my only substitute for a visit to the Department and to the house— Mr Kellogg is the President of a College at Galesburg in the State of Illinois, travelling I suppose for the purpose of collecting contributions; but he asked none from me. He alledged no other than curiosity, and said that his college had commenced in 1837 as a school for teachers, preparatory for college, and had about 140 pupils— Since 1841. it had become a college, having now three classes and expecting a fourth next year—ten students to each Class— Mr Patterson, a member of the house from Rochester, New-York called and urged me very earnestly to come out with a severe declaration in the house against the Liberty party-abolitionists— I distrust very much the advice of Mr Patterson— I told him I thought the Liberty party had taken the most effectual means to demolish themselves; and as they had repelled and denounced me, it would have an appearance of private and personal resentment if I should retort upon them— They had done all the mischief in their power— It is irreparable— There may be an occasion upon which I may without impropriety express my opinion of them; but I shall not seek it— Among the Letters that I received yesterday was one from New-York dated 4. Decr., the writer of which says that canvassing a few days since with Governor Poindexter at the Galt house in Louisville he Poindexter said the morning when Jackson had the interview with me concerning the Florida Treaty he had been at Poindexter’s room, and on leaving it said that it was to fufil an engagement to meet me and Mr Monroe on that subject. But it was to meet me, and not Mr Monroe; and this is an anonymous Letter— I had morning visits also from Mr Thomasson and judge Pyrtle, from Louisville, Kentucky. the latter is here in attendance on the Supreme Court.

8. V. Sunday.  I attended public worship in the hall of the house of representatives, where Mr Tuston, the chaplain of the Senate began by giving out to be sung Watts’s hundredth Psalm, reading by two lines at a time; setting the tune himself, and requesting his hearers to join him as far as practicable— He then made a short and fervent prayer—read the 12th. chapter of Paul’s epistle to the Romans, and preached from Philippians 3.3. “For we are the circumcision which worship God in the spirit, and rejoice in Christ Jesus, and have no confidence in the flesh.” Mr Tuston in this as in many other of his discourses, very earnestly disclaimed all sectarianism of forms, and all bigoted attachment to peculiar modes of worship— He said there were two points upon which he had no doubt that every person professing the name of Christ of whatever denomination would agree— 1. To worship God in the spirit; and 2. And to place all his hopes of salvation, alone upon the merits of the redeemer— Mr Tuston’s manner is peculiarly tender and affectionate to his hearers, and in this he conciliates their favour rather than by the copiousness the vigour or the ingenuity of his intellect.— The Epistle to the Philippians is a heart searching exhortation to concord—written in prison—plaintive but not desponding—rather boastful of himself and glorying in his sufferings.— It is almost entirely about himself and expresses gratitude to them, as the only church that had contributed to his personal support— I perceive Mr Tuston’s inducement to the selection of his text— After dinner at St John’s church, Mr Pine read the Evening service for the second Sunday in Advent. The second lesson of which was the 12th. chapter of Romans which Mr Tuston had read this morning— Mr Pine preached a short Sermon from Ephesians 1.18. “The eyes of your understanding being enlightened, that ye may know what is the hope of his calling.”— Mr Pyne is a pleasing preacher and a very intelligent and amiable man— As I was returning home from church I was overtaken by Mr Peter Hagner, who came in and passed a quarter of an hour with me. In the evening General Daniel Parker called and brought with him a number of papers from the files of the War Department in the handwriting of his staff officers—he offered to leave them with me, but I declined keeping them— Visits from Mr Phoenix and Mr Moseley.

9. II.30— V:15. Monday.  Sleepless night, caused by breakfasting on coffee yesterday morning, and drinking a cup of tea last evening.— A sluggish, drowy, torpid day succeeds.— At the house, Mr Tuston opened the day with a short studied prayer— On the reading of the Journal the standing Committees were announced. The Speaker has again appointed me chairman of the Committee of Manufactures— Thomasson came and told me that he and another anti-Texas members of the Committee of foreign Affairs at the last Session have been removed and that the Committee now are Texas. The reading of the journal was no sooner finished than Hammett of Mississippi, began to move a resolution for referring to a select Committee so much of the President’s message as relates to Texas— Dromgoole told him that he had a series of Resolutions ready to distribute to the several standing committees the various topics of the message, for which purpose he should move to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Hammet immediately gave way. Dromgoole made his motion, and the house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Cave Johnson in the Chair— Dromgoole presented ten Resolutions distributing the Message to as many standing Committees— Only one question was taken upon the whole series of Resolutions, and they were adopted in a lump. Dromgoole then moved that the Committee should rise and report which was done—and the report was adopted without a word of debate. But before passing Dromgoole’s Resolutions the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union had taken up Duncan’s bill for holding the election of the Presidential Electors, on one and the same day throughout the Union— This gave rise to a dull and tedious debate chiefly raised by Elmer chairman of the Committee of elections, of which the Committee soon got tired and laid the bill aside. In the Clerk’s Office, I looked up the bill for the relief of Joseph Holmes, and the owners of the Schooner Industry.— This Evening Mr Samuel Hoare called on me and told me the particulars of his expulsion by mob violence from Charleston South-Carolina, where he had been sent as a Commissioner to protect the personal rights of coloured citizens of Massachusetts imprisoned under a Slave-law of the State. He barely escaped with life and limb— I approved the whole of his conduct, and advised him to see the other members of the delegation from Massachusetts before proceeding home. Mr Markoe called to invite me to a meeting of the Institute, but I declined—

10. IV:30. Tuesday  Mr Robert Owen brought me this morning a small bound printed book, by himself, a second edition, London 1841. entitled a Developement of the principles and plans on which to establish Self-supporting home-colonies— He left it, with me, and said he would call for it again to-morrow— From the cursory glance at its contents which is all that I can bestow, I find it a new edition of his old exploded projects— At the house I gave notice of my intention to ask leave to introduce a bill for the relief of Joseph Holmes and the owners of the Schooner Industry. After some other interlocutory motions Giddings asked the Speaker what was the regular business of the day, and he answered the call of the States for Petitions— Giddings then called for the Order of business and the Speaker announced Petitions in order from the State of Maine.— There were none from Maine— One or two from New-Hampshire. The call came at once upon Massachusetts. I had only three petitions to present. 1. from John P. Andrews of Salem for the promotion of universal peace— Referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs. 2. from Edward Jarvis and J. Wingate Thornton Committee of the American Statistical Association, a memorial concerning the errors in the census of 1840— I moved its reference to the Committee of Statistics of the last Session if it still existed, and that it should be printed.— The Speaker said that was a select Committee only for the Session and did not now exist— I then moved the reference to a select Committee of 9 which was adopted—but objection was made to the printing— Preston King called for its being read. The Clerk read about 5 minutes—till they tired and dispensed with the further reading.— a motion was made to lay the motion to print on the table—carried 101. to 79.— 3. Petition from A. B. Kingsland and 4 other residents in the City of New-York for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— I moved its reference to the Committee on the district. Black of Georgia objected to its reception. Brown of Indiana moved to lay the objection on the table, lost by yeas and nays 90 to 99. Question on the reception of the Petition 107 to 81.— Tibbatts moved to lay the petition on the table—lost 88 to 99 and it was referred to the Committee on the District— Much matter for reflection on these proceedings.— The call for petitions proceeded till they came to Ohio—and when Giddings rose a motion to adjourn was made and carried— John Connell was here this Evening.

11. IV.30. Wednesday—  Mr Owen came again this morning for his book. I told him I had cursorily looked over as much of it as my time would allow, and that I had not been able to bring my mind to the approbation of his plan— He went over the same preamble that I had heard from him 27 years ago in London; which he had afterwards crowded upon me year after year here, when I was Secretary of State and President, and from which I have hoped for the last fifteen years that this Country was forever delivered.— He said he wanted his book now; but he would send it to me again to be examined and studied at my leisure; for it required profound study to understand it— It was to change the basis of human society; to put every individual of the human race in the proper place to promote his own happiness, and needed only to be put into operation to accomplish its purpose. At the house Douglas of Illinois gave notice that he would at an early day move for leave to introduce a bill to establish a new territory with a strange name— Houston of Alabama moved to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Bill N. 2. reported at the last Session from the Committee on the Territories— Duncan insisted upon the preference to his bill for holding the election of Presidential electors throughout the Union one and the same day. Houston yielded the precedence— The house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and first took up Duncan’s bill— Elmer and Hannibal Hamlin still nibbled at the Bill, till Duncan proposed an entire substitute for his bill accommodated to their projected amendments. It was adopted by the Committee, and laid aside to be reported to the house—but Dromgoole was still dissatisfied, and offered another entire substitute of his own, which the Speaker decided came too late, but said it might be offered in the house. Houston’s Bill for reducing and graduating the price of the public lands was then taken up— It proposes to authorise the sale of all the public lands which have been 5 years upon sale for one dollar an all that have been ten years upon sale for 75 cents—all that have been 15 years in the market for 50 cents, and all that have been 20 years on hand for 25 cents an acre— This bill was supported by Houston, by Sample and John W. Davis of Indiana, and opposed by Collamer of Vermont, and by Vinton of Ohio— It will break up the whole system of the sales of the public lands, and will give them away— Mr Hawley was here this evening.

12. IV:45. Thursday  Much of this morning was consumed in a fruitless search for the pamphlet statement of the proceedings in the United States Courts in the case of the Amistad Negroes There are numerous documents relating to that case to oppose a bill and report from the Committee of foreign Affairs at the last Session of Congress, essentially necessary, but which I have not now at hand— At the house, Douglas of Illinois gave notice of a motion for the purchase of certain copies of Greenhow’s history of Oregon California &c— The name of the new Territory which he proposes to establish is Nebraska— Levy the delegate from Florida, obtained an order to print 5000 copies of the Constitution of Florida reported in 1839.— The call for petitions was resumed.— Giddings presented successively 7. abolition petitions, memorials and resolutions and objection was made to the reception of them all.— Rhett of South Carolina, enquired if the question of reception was debateable—the Speaker answered that it was, whereupon Rhett said he wished to debate it— They were all laid over accordingly one day for debate, except a memorial from Ashtabula County for the abolition of the Slave-representation, which was laid on the table by yeas and nays 135 to 54.— Augustus C. Dodge, delegate from the Territory of Iowa presented a memorial asking admission into the Union and a copy of their Constitution which after some discussion was referred to the Committee on the Territories— The Committees were called for Reports, but the only one presented was by Charles J. Ingersoll Chairman of the Committee of foreign Affairs.— A joint Resolution for the annexation of Texas to the United States, in exactly the same words with a joint Resolution presented two or three days since to the Senate by George M’Duffie of South-Carolina— The Resolution was read twice, referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union and Ingersoll gave notice that he should call it up for consideration, on Monday the 23d. of this month— The annexation is to be a complete ratification of the Treaty signed on the 12th. of April last, and rejected by the Senate— Ingersoll moved also the printing of 5000 copies of the map of Texas which was agreed to— Winthrop who is a member of the Committee of foreign Affairs gave notice that the report of the Committee was not unanimous; that no discussion of it had been allowed in the Committee and that all he could do was to protest against it, as unconstitutional in form and substance, and tending directly to the dissolution of the Union— Mr Frye spent the Evening here—

13. V. Friday.  A budget of Newspapers every morning from various quarters, draw my attention to articles upon all sorts of subjects and wear away my time like the melting of a candle till I am obliged to attend my duty at the house without leaving upon my memory any thing but a blank— I reached the capitol this morning at a quarter past 11— I went into the library room of the Supreme judicial Court and borrowed the 15th. volume of Peters’s Reports containing the case of the Schooner Amistad and her African Negroes— I found M’Kay and Romulus M Saunders in conclave there together.— The librarian there asked me if I was born on the 11th. of July— I said I was.— He said that his reason for asking the question was that it was his own birthday, fifty years later. I went into the Hall where the Supreme Court were in Session, and saw the seven judges in their chairs—Taney, Story, M’Lean, Wayne, Catron, M’Kinley and Daniel, and Richard H. Wilde of Georgia was arguing a cause before them— At the house, the select Committee on the Memorial of the American Statistical Association concerning the errors in the census of 1840 was announced. John Quincy Adams of Massachusetts, Robert Barnwell Rhett of South Carolina, Kenneth Rayner of North-Carolina.— William H. Stiles of Georgia, William B. Maclay of New-York, Francis Brengle of Maryland, Shepherd Cary of Maine, and Caleb B. Smith of Indiana—and Henry A. Foster of New-York. The Speaker laid before the house sundry communications—from the President and the executive Departments and with them a set of condoling resolutions of the corporation of the city of New Orleans, upon the Catastrophe on board the Steamer Princeton— They reminded me of the deputation from Troy to Tiberius to condole with him on the death of his Son, many months after the event; which he answered by condoling with them for the death of Hector— Dr Duncan called up his bill for holding the election of electors of President and Vice President and Vice President on one and the same day throughout the Union— Dromgoole, and Campbell of South Carolina, and Rhett, annoyed him with amendments till he tried but failed to carry the previous question.— Adjourned over to Monday. Doctor Sewall was here this Evening.

14. V:15. Saturday—  I had intended to visit the Offices of the War and Navy Departments this morning upon private business, but a succession of visitors absorbed my time till it was too late.— An old widow woman by the name of Thompson, came with a written recommendation in the name of Mrs Wickliffe wife of the Postmaster General, to charity— Her plea was touching by its simplicity—and urged in language evidently betokening former ease and comfort and actual urgent want— Mrs Royall’s Sally came too for a year’s subscription to her Newspaper now called the Huntress—a tax of charity in another form— I had a morning visit in another form— Morning visit from Mr Giddings of Ohio, with four members of the Pennsylvania delegation, all honest and honorable men.— A person by the name of Harriman came and asked for a copy of my Address at Braintree to which Charles J. Ingersoll has published an answer— He said he had been engaged as an editor and writer for newspapers in sundry places, and he was now connected with the Baltimore Patriot— That he wished to give some account of Ingersoll’s publication, and for that purpose to see my address which gave rise to it— I gave him a copy of each of the three papers containing the addresses of 7. October 30 Octr and 6. November, at Boston, Braintree and North Bridgwater. I wished to have some conversation with him on the whole subject but Mr and Mrs Marks came in, with a Letter of Introduction from Mr Phoenix. They are a young couple recently married, to reside in the city of New-York, visiting here for curiosity, and Mr Phoenix told me yesterday that they had expressed a desire to see me, and that he would give them a line introductory to me, for which I thanked him— Mr Daniel P. King with his two daughters and Mr and Mrs Marsh of Vermont were also visitors but did not come in— I took a walk before dinner— Met Mr John P. Kennedy, and walked with him to his lodgings at Mrs Whitwells on Capitol Hill Saw there, Mr and Mrs Grinnell, Senators Evans and Miller, and General Scott.

15. V. Sunday.  About Sunrise this morning, the Globe of last Evening was brought to me containing the address of Aaron V. Brown “to the public at large and to the Constituents of the Hon. John Quincy Adams in particular.” This is the third of the gang of conspirators who opened their batteries on me in the Globe of the 20th. of March last, and whom I exposed in my addresses at Boston—Braintree and North Bridgwater— The Lion and his two Jackals are now out— The first tool of Jackson George W. Erving is yet to be heard from— I must reply at leisure to them all. But the whole tissue of falsehood of Jackson’s Erwin Treaty is abandoned without an attempt to support it— I attended public worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives where Mr Tuston preached from Luke 22.31. [“]And the Lord said, Simon, Simon, behold, Satan hath desired to have you, that he may sift you as wheat; 32. But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not”— Mr Tuston speculated after his own manner upon the extraordinary circumstances under which St. Peter was prayed for by Jesus Christ himself; and started an enquiry whether it was a special personal, and exclusive favour granted to Peter, or a general blessing bestowed upon all believers. That there was some specialty in it was beyond a doubt because he was accosted twice by name—Simon—Simon—but as the whole life of Jesus was one continued dispensation of favours and he went about doing good, there was encouragement for every one to hope that he too in his troubles and trials, his temptations and distresses was though unconsciously guarded and sustained by the prayers of the redeemer of the world.— There is cheering benevolence in the thought, and internal evidence that it sprang from a tender and affectionate heart— Two young men brothers by the name of Tracy, were introduced to me after the service by a member from Connecticut.— After dinner I attended Church at St. John’s, where Mr Pine read the Evening prayer for the 3d. Sunday in Advent and preached from 2. Corinthians 5.17. [“]Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature; old things are passed away: behold all things are become new”— A rational essay upon regeneration with an eloquent and pathetic account of his own experience. St. John’s church took fire this morning just before the morning service began; but was extinguished so that it was not interrupted

16. V. Monday.  This day a grate for burning Lehigh Coal was put up in my writing chamber instead of the open hearth and chimney corner in which for the last six winters I have been in the practice of burning wood— Few persons can imagine how gravely the comfort of my life is affected by this trivial incident of mere personal habitudes— Seven months of the year from the first of October to the last of April, I can write only by the side of a fire— For as long a time, I need the convenience of a morning and evening lamp; from 6 to 8 hours every day.— These are the hours of labour for the day—the hours of solitude and of toil.— I must light my fire and my lamp every morning and my capacity to write depends upon the temperature of the atmosphere operating upon my sense of feeling.— The experiment of the coal fire is now again to be tried; heretofore it has not suited me so well as wood— Mr Giddings, Mr and Mrs Tilden and Mr and Mrs Hamlin paid me a morning visit— At the house, the first business was the question upon the engrossment of Duncan’s Bill, for holding the election of Electors of President and Vice-President of the United States on one and the same day throughout the Union— Duncan demanded the yeas and nays and they were taken 187 ay—and 1. Nay—Woodward of South-Carolina— James A. Black only of the South Carolina delegation voted for the bill— Burt, Campbell, Holmes and Rhett did not vote. The bill was then passed without an opposing vote— Burke of New-Hampshire moved a suspension of the rules for a motion to print 10000 copies of the majority and minority reports on the Rhode-Island Insurrection memorial—yeas 103—nays 87. motion lost. Weller asked leave to introduce a bill to extend the right of suffrage in the city of Washington— Campbell objected, that there was a bill before the house reported by the Committee on the District containing the same provision. Weller moved and carried a suspension of the rules—62 to 124. Weller introduced his bill, and pressed for its immediate passage; but objections were started in his own gang, and the bill was referred to the Committee on the District.— Duncan moved and carried a suspension of the rules to introduce a bill for establishing the territory of Oregon and other purposes, which was referred to the Committee on the Territories. The annual reports of the Secretary of the Treasury on the finances with the estimates, and of the Commissioner of the general Land Office were presented to the house. Phoenix moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the warehouse bill, but could not get a quorum to vote. Adjourned before 3.

17. II.45— VI.15. Tuesday.
